narrative:
You're at the University, doing guard duty for a special museum exhibition sponsored by the Merchant's Guild. The artifacts on display were unearthed from an archeological dig near the city of Demonsgate, and the focal piece is an ancient suit of armor made of thousands of links of steel. It's seen better days, but is in good condition for something crafted millennia ago. The placard next to it says that it belonged to an ancient leader with legendary luck who never fell in battle.

The day passes uneventfully, and your voice is sore by the end from reminding people not to touch the chainmail. The curators pack up the exhibits and give you your payment, wheeling the display out to the courtyard for transit to the next city on the schedule.

You're about to step out towards the Sleeping Lion for a drink when you spot a steel link on the ground—it must've fallen off the armor you were guarding. You scoop it up and feel the heft in your hand... those ancient warriors weren't fooling around.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Call after the curators and return it to them.

outcomes.narrative: The link reattaches easily and the armor is loaded into the back of the transport carriage. The curators thank you profusely for your perceptiveness and are sure to put in a good word with their sponsors.

options.label: B
options.narrative: It won't be missed. Keep the link for good luck.

outcomes.narrative: The steel link has softened with age, and you're able to bend it to nicely fit around your finger. It feels somehow right to bring a piece of a legendary warrior's armor back into battle, albeit on a smaller scale.
effects: If a character owns "Steel Ring" 102, they gain 15 gold. Otherwise, gain the "Steel Ring" 102 item.

narrative:
The difference between rich people and poor people is that rich people have enough money to pay someone else to solve their problems. A wealthy businessman has set his sights on some real estate on the border of the Coin District. Unfortunately for him, it's owned by a particularly obstinate old Savvas who has no intention of giving up its home for a new shop or apothecary or restaurant or whatever dazzling new property the businessman has in mind. The businessman has tried everything and after being refused, again, he's turned to you as a last resort.

"I'll give you ten gold just to knock on the door and remind it I want to buy the place. Thirty if you can convince that crusty Savvas to take the deal." Seems like a good job either way.

You walk up to the Savvas' door and discuss your plan amongst yourselves.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Turn on the charm and explain why the businessman's deal is an excellent offer.

outcomes.narrative: You give a broad smile to the Savvas and lay out why the businessman's offer would be an excellent opportunity. "It sounds much more reasonable coming from you than that block-headed businessman. I'll sign."
You attempt to convince the Savvas, but it refuses outright. "I already told that ninny I'm not going anywhere! Find some other old rock to bother."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Threaten the Savvas to encourage it to leave.

outcomes.narrative: The Savvas attempts to slam the door in your face, but you push inside. You start plucking a collection of vases off the wall and "accidentally" dropping them. "Stop! Stop! I'll sign! You monsters."
"Get off my property!" You try to force your way inside, but the Savvas effortlessly conjures a gust of wind that knocks you back into the street.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Pocket the payment and head back to the Sleeping Lion without knocking.

outcomes.narrative: Let the Savvas stonewall the businessman some more. You report that your negotiation was a failure and take the payment without doing a lick of work.

narrative:
An enthusiastic crowd has gathered around a lone magician in the New Market. She adeptly produces silks and snowbirds from an empty hat, divines a merely thought-of card, and finds coins behind the ears of nearby children. The building audience is delighted by her presentation, clapping and laughing at her jokes.

"It is time for the main event! Children and the sensitive or infirmed, I invite you to look away... All other viewers, behold!" She dramatically rips a red curtain off a painted wooden box. The sides are pierced to the hilt by a dozen curved swords, embedded in every direction. She opens a pair of padlocks on the side to reveal the interior: sure enough, blades occupy every available space, leaving no room for much else.

She begins to draw the swords one by one, demonstrating each is real and solid with a firm twang against the cobblestones.

"Now, I'll need a full-sized, corporeal volunteer... Quatryls, Vermlings, Aesthers, and Harrowers, you can sit this one out."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Raise your hand (select which party member is volunteering now).

effects: Read %game.section:63.2%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Watch the trick closely to see how it's done.

outcomes.narrative: Watching carefully, you deduce there must be a series of mirrors that reflect the blade handles despite appearing to pierce through. You discuss it later at the Sleeping Lion and are pleased you figured it out.
You watch the blades go in, the blades come out, and the volunteer emerges unharmed. Even after everything you've seen on the battlefield, this? This is clearly true magic. You erupt in applause.

narrative:
It's rare that you're called in for such high-profile work, but you're being paid ten gold each to staff extra protection for a visiting nobleman. The town guard was supposed to be running the security detail, but the nobleman wound up on their bad side after promoting "rebellious ideologies."

You're making a path through the crowd to allow him to enter the town hall when you spot it: a glimmer of steel at the crest of a nearby rooftop. The unmistakable THUNK of a crossbow confirms the threat—you have just a split second before impact into the chest of your charge.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Leap in front of the crossbow bolt to save the nobleman.

outcomes.narrative: You were paid for protection, and you're as good as your word. It takes just a shift in your stance, and the crossbow bolt intended for the nobleman hits you instead.
effects: Select one character to permanently decrease their maximum hit point value by 1 and gain %game.trait:hero%. Note both on their character sheet now, then read %game.section:27.1%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Call out a warning.

outcomes.narrative:
You cry out before the impact, but it's no use: the crossbow bolt finds its mark dead-center in the nobleman's chest. He slumps to the ground and is dead long before help arrives. The assassin uses the commotion to slip away.

It's a good thing you always ask for payment up front.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with any two factions of your choice.

narrative:
"Hey, looking for some cash?" A smarmy-looking Vermling with a mug of ale slides into your booth at the Sleeping Lion. His hair is unnaturally slicked back with a transparent oil, pulling his eyebrows a bit too high.

"You've been preapproved, just got word this afternoon. Came here straightaway to let you know. You've been looking at some shiny new toys in the shops, no? Some cash could make a big difference in your survivability out there."

Wary, you ask what the catch is.

"No catch. Just a loan. You get 50 gold today. You pay back a little interest here and there. You'll barely even notice, you'll have so much extra lying around." You inquire about the interest rate, and just who is offering this loan.

The Vermling clicks his tongue. "It's a lotta math, beads on the abacus. I would focus on the today, you might not even be around tomorrow. Maybe you die? Maybe you retire? A lot of maybes, I think. Don't worry your head about it."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Accept the money.

outcomes.narrative:
If someone offers you 50 gold, you take 50 gold. The transaction is very simple and doesn't even require paperwork. It's apparently a family business and they'll just keep track and remind you about interest payments as needed.

"Pleasure getting you signed up, here's your new money." The Vermling hands over a pouch that looks less impressive than you expected. "Bonecruncher will let you know when it's time to collect. Until then, just live it up!"

...Bonecruncher?

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse the loan.

outcomes.narrative: It takes some repetition, but you finally make clear you're not going to take this mysterious, anonymous loan. When he hears the finality in your voice, he shrugs, dropping the smarmy smile. He throws a few coins on the table for his drink and leaves the Sleeping Lion without another word.

narrative:
Down an alley shortcut, you come across an unusual addition: a Valrath, bound and gagged, lying by the side of the road. You roll him onto his side and his frantic eyes confirm he's still alive. A note strapped to his chest in excellent handwriting reads:

"To the Town Guards: This man was apprehended removing jewelry from nearby homes. Govern him accordingly.

By the verdant light of the scarab, The Green Carapace"

You see a pair of guards patrolling down the alley in your direction, but it doesn't seem like they've spotted you in the dark yet. The bound man's guttural groans suggests he's trying to say something. You pull down the gag and he wastes no time:

"That crazed vigilante got me all wrong! You've gotta let me go. I'm—listen. You're like me, right? Just trying to get by in this city. I can help you! I... I've got jewelry. Magic jewelry. You untie me and I'll tell you where it is. It's all yours!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Untie the man.

outcomes.narrative:
A knife makes quick work of the silk ropes tying the man down, and you help him to his feet. He's badly bruised and in no condition to run, but you still keep a firm grasp on him. All it takes is a smile to the unsuspecting guards and you're in the clear. True to his word, he pulls a small glimmering earring out of his pocket and hands it to you.

"I knew you were like me. Good working with you. And watch out for that green psycho, they're everywhere these days."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Shout for the guards.

outcomes.narrative:
You alert the passing patrol and they quickly apprehend the criminal.

"Another one by the Green Carapace. Third this week, don't know when this guy has time to sleep." The other guard answers quickly: "They're a Harrower, I don't think they need to sleep. Tell you what, though, I appreciate their help. Somebody needs to smack some sense into these thieves."

There's a small bounty for the criminal, and it doesn't look like the Green Carapace is going to show up to collect it. The guards hand it over to you in thanks.

narrative:
You're taking a shortcut through Town Hall when an assistant approaches you. "Excuse me? Could you please assist me? We need an unbiased opinion." You follow her into the central rotunda, where you find the council in session.

Councilwoman Vale furrows her brow at the sight of you. "Surely there are others that would be better suited to providing insight?"

Councilman Greymare interjects: "It's a fine choice. Mercenaries are the lifeblood of a city, particularly one where the military is demonstrably inferior to the services a sellsword can provide." His words trail out like thick barbs against the pro-military councilmembers.

"So be it," Vale continues, ignoring the comment. "Mercenaries, speak for the populace: is a functional economy more important than security? Does the average citizen of Gloomhaven care more for their pocketbooks or their safety?" The councilmembers lean in to hear your response.

options.label: A
options.narrative: The economy is the most important function of government.

outcomes.narrative:
You attempt to provide an even-handed response about the importance of both aspects of civic life, but the true test of a city is not how it threatens its populace, but how it supports their opportunities to better their own lives.

"Thank you, mercenaries, for such a compelling argument. I think we'd all agree that, without a vibrant market for goods and services, a city is little more than a transient police state." Councilman Greymare looks pleased. By the nods, it's clear the listeners have been hearing only the aspects that support their own arguments. Politicians.

options.label: B
options.narrative: The defense of the city is the most important function of government.

outcomes.narrative:
You attempt to provide an even-handed response about both aspects of civic life, but the true test of a city is whether it can defend its borders and its people against threats to their lives. Livelihoods are necessarily secondary to this primary government goal.

Councilwoman Vale gives the faintest hint of a smile. "Truer words have not been spoken, mercenaries. Your city thanks you for your contributions both in oration today and in your own efforts to defend Gloomhaven."

narrative: "Which one of you thinks they're all that?" A drunken Quatryl patron at the Sleeping Lion steps up to your usual table, wavering as he addresses you. His eyes pass in an out of focus, and it's not clear who he means to be accosting.

narrative:
The Sekhem Gardens are a massive enclosed greenhouse in the Traveler's District. Exotic plants and humid air make for an attraction to all walks of life, but the primary visitors are the Valraths that take comfort in the oasis-like natural beauty of their ancestral home. Temperatures inside are high enough to make even most Valraths sweat, but Councilwoman Vale doesn't show a drop of perspiration as she winds an iridescent blue vine along some trelliswork.

"I've discovered some unusual legends." She expertly weaves it in and out, tracing the glazing of the window. "Or rather, my daughter did. She spends altogether too much time with her nose in a book." The councilwoman snips the end of the vine, tying it to the trellis with a velvet ribbon.

"I am told of a tower between the Watcher Mountains and the Dagger Forest, that a machine of war there challenges all comers. If it is true, you are to defeat it, dismantle it, and bring it to me. I suspect that, like most knowledge committed to books, it is fanciful hyperbole. But regardless, you will see it investigated." She makes it sound much less optional than most people who hire you.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Ask to keep the machine if you can defeat it.

outcomes.narrative: "I am pleased by your readiness to wield such a device, as many do not have the stomach for war. All of my endeavors in this life are in pursuit of greater peace for Gloomhaven." She tilts her head in acknowledgment, and you can't help but feel a sense of pride. "If you will champion such a cause in the defense of Gloomhaven, I would expect nothing less than your service in its use."

She raises an eyebrow. "If it is as dangerous as the legends claim, it will be best managed in the hands of those loyal to the city." There's no question that she's sizing up your trustworthiness. "Prove yourself and I will consider your request."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask for access to the city armory to prepare for the quest.

outcomes.narrative: "As the city's armory is the finest collection of materials for war, it is no surprise to hear your request. I'll see to it that First Shield Harmon permits you access."
effects: Collectively gain any one item from 001-014.

narrative:
"Okay, don't freak out. This is a totally consensual thing that is happening, and I need everyone to just stay calm, okay?" You're standing in the apartment of Xain, a local Orchid barfly who frequents the Sleeping Lion. Also standing in Xain's apartment is a full-sized sun demon, dumping light into the room and crouching to fit under the low ceiling. It quietly watches the proceedings.

"Mercenaries, meet Sunny. Sunny: these're the best mercenaries at the Sleeping Lion, at least on short notice. Great—hit it, Sunny." Sunny picks up a metal paperweight from the bookshelf and compresses it tightly within its brightly-glowing hands. You avert your gaze, but when it's done, you see the paperweight has been reformed into a tiny, perfectly-formed replica of a man-made island with unintelligible contraptions sticking out of it. Xain closes his eyes and touches the display with a fingertip, interpreting the object.

"Sunny says bugs have taken over some specialty forge built by his kind. Help Sunny clear out the infestation, and it'll use the forge to make you something amazing." Xain opens his eyes and looks at you. "Deal?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help Sunny clear out the infestation.

outcomes.narrative:
Not entirely sure of the protocol, you attempt to mime acceptance at Sunny. Sunny holds out a sun-drenched hand in response, focusing the energy to a singular point and deftly slicing the display into something new: a diorama of a sword. It returns to a resting position, eyeing you closely without apparent emotion. Xain closes his eyes and touches the miniature.

"Sunny says it knows how to make some kind of fancy sword with the forge. Get the bugs out, and Sunny will use the facility to sinter it for you." Xain's eyes pop open, and he looks grumpily at Sunny. "You're giving away the sword? Then you and I need to rework our arrangement."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Demand to speak with Sunny alone.

outcomes.narrative: You ask Sunny a series of questions with Xain out of the room. It responds with intricate dioramas, and by touching each, you can tease out the meaning of the psychic patterns that created them. You gather that Sunny met Xain after being trapped in his belt buckle, a story which doesn't get elaborated on. The two formed an unlikely alliance when Xain offered to help clear the Sintering Forge in exchange for using the manufacturing facilities. Xain impatiently returns to the room. "Well?"

With Xain out of the room, you attempt to communicate with the Sun Demon. Sunny melts many objects from around the room into dioramas, but you can't make sense of any of them. Xain returns after a few minutes, exasperatedly surveying the destruction. "Well, this looks productive. Ready to help?"

narrative:
You're greeted with a gust of cold air: crawling through the windowsill is your old friend the Wildfury. They tumble unceremoniously to the floor, brushing some dirt out of their fur.

"Sorry, I think someone changed the lock. I would've knocked, but... I didn't." They sit on the edge of the bed that used to be theirs before retirement, seemingly unaware of just how filthy the pelts they're covered in are. The Wildfury produces a piece of jerky, chewing as they speak. "Loggers disturbed the spirits of the wilds. I need your help to calm them, or destroy them."

It's not clear whether your old friend is referring to the spirits or the loggers. They toss the end bit of the jerky onto the floor without finishing it, then raise an eyebrow at your concerned reaction. "What? Vermlings never eat the last bite of food. Bad luck. This way you always know there's more somewhere."

They hop off the bed. "We remove the blight or we suffer the consequences. So? Will you help me?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Help your old friend calm the forest.

outcomes.narrative: "Good, we'll need some supplies. Food, mostly. We need to attract some friends." They scramble up the window ledge, then pause before popping through. "And more jerky. I'll meet you up there."

options.label: B
options.narrative: The Wildfury will have to do this alone, you draw the line at killing loggers.

outcomes.narrative: "Hmph. Well, there's good reason I stick to the wilds. At least if you feed someone, you get some measure of loyalty." The Wildfury leaves the way they came, and fresh-sawn logs continue to flow into Gloomhaven.

narrative:
Rain tumbles from the sky, driving most of the citizenry to drier confines indoors. You're heading back home from the Sleeping Lion when you see a portly man in a black cloak nearly dragging a limp teen through the alleyways.

The cloaked man notices you approach and moves to block your view. "Ah, sorry, my friend took a spill. I will ensure he returns home safely from here. Thank you for your interest, regardless." You push him aside easily enough to get a better look, and the teen he's carrying slumps face-down into a puddle. You prod him with the edge of your boot and he stirs, sitting upright and sputtering water. He looks just to the side of you as though he's seeing something that isn't there.

With uncanny stilted movement, the teen nods to you. "Yes, thank you for your interest. I'll be returned home safely."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Let the cloaked man return the teen home.

outcomes.narrative: "Thank you for your understanding. My poor friend will not cause such trouble again." The portly man places his cloak protectively over his charge, disappearing into the night.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse to release the teen to the cloaked man.

outcomes.narrative:
You help the nearly-drowned teen to his feet. The portly man steps forward, "I assure you, there is no reason for alarm—" he reaches out to grab the teen, and you shove him to the ground, splashing him into the muddy runoff. He dabs his face with a black handkerchief, and with a dramatic clearing of his throat rushes off to somewhere without another word.

No sooner than he's out of sight than the teen seems to come out of his daze. "Thank you, I was telling that man about the Sect when I started feeling winded... then everything got cloudy. I could've sworn he said the word 'sacrifice' right before everything went black." He shakes his head, pushing away whatever he has the displeasure of recalling. "The Sect is doing such important work, I feel the need to tell any who will listen. I don't want... thank you. I don't know where I'd be without you."

narrative:
"This is the greatest invention ever created!" A Quatryl has set up a display stand on a streetcorner, tapping a black cane on the ground in an effort to draw a crowd. "Behold!" With a flourish, she yanks a curtain off a curious, brass-bound box.

"This marvel—using the exacting powers of science—can induce the feelings of drunkenness without a sip of alcohol or inhalation of smokes of any kind! Tend a bar without spirits, enliven a party without consequence. Gather round, and experience the wonder!" With that, she reaches up and throws a brass-handled lever on the side of the contraption, and the box gets noisy. The box is noisy. BRRRrr. BRRR! It's noisy—the, the box.

Your near the box and it's noisy and you feel noisy.

"Oh no, no no—that's not right."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Throw the lever down.

outcomes.narrative:
You stretch out and throw the lever down. Down is up and up is, oh, wow, do you feel sick. But at least the sky is where is should be. Now if it would just stop moving.

The Quatryl, choking back a gag, addresses the crowd sheepishly. "Sorry, sorry, that... oh wow, that really was turned up much too high. But—but think about how potent it is!" The crowd doesn't seem impressed.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Throw the lever up.

outcomes.narrative: You stretch out and throw the lever up. Unfortunately, what you believe to be the direction you want to push the lever is so, so wrong. With a lurch, the machine turns on even stronger, sending the gathered crowd reeling. When the Orchid finally gets control of her machine, no amount of apologies will make up for the distress of the crowd, and she packs up and scurries off as quickly as her still-wobbly legs will let her.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Throw up.

outcomes.narrative:
There's no mistaking the feeling of relief, but the results wind up all over the machine. With a gurgle, it stops all at once.

"My machine! It just needed some tweaking..." You continue on your way rather than stick around to be berated, confident you made the right decision.

narrative:
You hear screams from the south as you approach the docks.

A group of women run toward you in a panic, nearly knocking you over as they race by. One of them shouts: "An invasion!"

You hurry to the docks and find a crowd of workers on edge, armed with makeshift weapons and circling one particular pier.

Standing at the far end of the wooden planks is a group of Lurkers—terrifying crab-like monsters as big as an Inox and equally ferocious. Except these Lurkers don't appear to be hostile. They are simply standing on the dock, clacking their claws in a strange rhythm.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Raise arms and fight the Lurkers back into the sea.

outcomes.narrative: The crowd parts as you approach the dock with weapons drawn. You step onto the soft wood and the Lurkers turn toward you and stop clacking. They all hiss and brandish their claws in aggression. You charge forward and meet the threat head-on, hacking away at their carapaces until they scuttle off the dock and back into the water.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Approach the Lurkers cautiously and attempt to communicate with them.

outcomes.narrative: The crowd parts as you move toward the dock with both confidence and care. The Lurkers notice your approach and continue to clack in your direction. You call out to them and ask why they are here, but all you get in response is a change in tempo of their clacking. When you express confusion, they clack again in frustration and scuttle back into the ocean. The crowd is very impressed that you managed to ward off the creatures without using force.
effects: Gain 2 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

narrative:
You're standing in the cramped room of Pinter Droman, a fledgling Quatryl inventor. Stacked to the ceiling are plans, parts, and pieces of various machines in half-built stages. He wastes no time launching into his issue.

"I bought this off a Vermling—they're the ones most likely to acquire these things, you see. It's an old ledger showing mining routes. Compare them to what's still in operation today, and there! Right there! This tunnel is on the old maps, but not on the current ones." Pinter flips a magnifying glass down from his visor, leaning in close to the paperwork strewn across his desk.

"But this rock is dense—it's more like what you'd find in the mountains to the north than the ones around here. You couldn't cut into it even with the tools of today. If there really is a mine there, then they used technology that exceeds our own. Imagine what we could build! Gather that for me, would you? I'm sort of between incomes at the moment, but I can compensate you with my inventions."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Accept one of his inventions as payment.

outcomes.narrative: "Ah, this is a Pinter Droman original! May it never explode, unless you need it to explode, in which case may it explode spectacularly."
effects: Immediately gain the item from the random item design.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask to browse through his unfinished blueprints.

outcomes.narrative: "Certainly, please, take your time. They're all equally useful, I assure you. I'm just a bit pinched on gold at the moment, so I can't build everything that comes to mind myself." You sort through the blueprints and scrawled diagrams and narrow it down to a few that look promising.
effects: Draw 3 random item designs and choose 1, returning the other 2 to their deck.

narrative:
The acrid smell of smoke assaults your senses. The university's southern annex is on fire. Citizens are fleeing every direction in panic, hindering relief efforts. If no one intervenes, it's likely to spread, and the town guard hasn't yet arrived.

"You're going to do something, right?" A pair of street-denizens rushes up to you, ready to assist. One is an older gentleman who looks a bit crazed, but his build suggests a strength about him. The other is a meek younger woman who looks quick on her feet. "Tell us where to go and we'll help!"

options.narrative:
Distribute your characters, along with the older gentleman and the younger woman, among the following tasks:
Herding the panicking citizens.
Entering the burning building to rescue people.
Attempting to temper the flames.

When everyone is assigned to tasks, flip this card over.

effects: Read %game.section:75.4%.

narrative:
You spot a member of the Sect, a group of curious individuals who worship demons, picking produce at a shop in the New Market. He's pointing at decadent displays of fruits and honeyed sweets, each of which is piled into his cart by the shop keep. The store owner loads the last of the selections—a crate of plump red radishes—onto the scales for weighing. "That will be... 10 gold."

The Sect member twists within its clothes and removes a leather satchel of coins, passing it over to the store owner for counting. Before he gets to the exit, though, the store owner speaks up, concerned. "Hey. Hey! I don't know what this is, but either you pay, or I'll summon the guards." You peek inside the satchel and see a variety of dirt-encrusted gold coins, none of which are recognizable as currency. The Sect member looks to the store owner and then to you, pleading.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Offer to pay for the produce in exchange for the coinage (requires 10 gold).

outcomes.narrative:
You step in and pay for the Sect member's purchase before the store owner can raise the alarm. "You shouldn't help them. Monstrous people, those Sect members. I heard they're trying to summon Demons right into Gloomhaven. They needle you to join their cult one day, and then, the next, they're ripping you off with this filthy scrap. I wish the market would ban them entirely, let them shop in the Sinking Market with the rest of the detritus. Do you want this?"

You take the bag of coins to a dealer in the Coin District, whose eyes widen at the sight. "These must be a thousand years old, perhaps more! Yes, of course I'll take them."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Support the store owner in demanding proper currency.

outcomes.narrative: The Sect member bolts out the door with an armful of produce. You're left with no other choice but to give chase into the New Market streets. He's no match for your speed, and in no time at all you've tackled him to the ground, spilling expensive produce everywhere. He thrashes against you, trying to snap his jaws onto your forearm. A quick blow to the forehead knocks him out cold, and the town guard arrives a few moments later.

narrative:
"Excuse me, mercenaries?" A silver-cloaked man approaches you, a brooch of fresh flowers pinned to his jacket. The sickly-sweet perfume he carries overwhelms you as he rushes up.

"There is a crate that will be exiting Gloomhaven momentarily... the gentlemen at the gate will not open it, yes?"

Is he asking you or telling you? A trickle of black liquid leaks out the side of his mouth, and he dabs it with a black handkerchief. "If you can assist in its exit, you will be compensated. Well? Compensated."

The guards will give extreme scrutiny to anyone with his odd behavior, but it should be no issue for you to push the crate through as supposed supplies for a mission.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Help the cloaked man get his crate through the checkpoint.

outcomes.narrative:
As regulars transiting in and out of the city, you chat with the guards for a few minutes before they wave you and the crate through without inspection. An hour later, your silver-cloaked friend catches up to you further down the road.

"Well. Done? You have crate." The cloaked man smiles a disconcerting grin, cracking it open and handing you a pair of boots from the rows stowed inside. "They will remember. Don't forget." You can't quite tell if it's a threat.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Alert the guards to the fishy behavior.

outcomes.narrative:
You give the guards a subtle look, tapping your thumb against the side of the crate. They catch on immediately, and, with some whispered instructions, wave you through.

When the silver-cloaked man later catches up to you, the guards spring out of hiding, clasping him in irons. He snarls at you, spitting black ichor. "Demons remember! Don't forget." The guards thank you for your help in getting this demon sympathizer off the streets, and are even kind enough to look away while you grab a set of contraband boots from inside the crate. It's a nice tip.

narrative:
"Perhaps you do not understand, she is the most beautiful girl to have ever walked this earth, and her eyes are like stars sparkling in a summer's breeze! I care not what my father thinks or what her witch of a mother believes—I must wed her! I simply must!" Greggory Greymare, teenage son of pro-merchant Councilman Greymare, has flopped unceremoniously on a fainting couch in his father's estate. He's called you here to buy your services in delivering a love letter to Nectar Vale, the teenage daughter of pro-military Councilwoman Vale—the archnemesis to his father's dealings. He's prattling on instead of paying you so you can be on your way.

"I would give all my possessions for a look into her eyes. My father would admonish me, surely, if he knew the depths of my heart. Her own mother would surely forbid our union should she hear the beating of our two chests in time. Will you help me? What would it cost to deliver this simple letter of love to my sweet Nectar? Fifteen gold?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Deliver the note to Nectar Vale.

outcomes.narrative: It's evening before Nectar is outside her mother's manor and watchful eyes, browsing the markets in the Coin District. You approach her and are stopped by her handmaiden before you explain the situation. Nectar's eyes light up at the mention of Greggory, and she tears open the letter immediately. She reads through it twice before clutching it to her chest, tears of joy dotting her eyes. "Yes, of course I'll marry him!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Show the note to the boy's father, Councilman Greymare.

outcomes.narrative: You immediately hand the note over to his father, Councilman Greymare. "It's good that you've brought this to me, I'll see to it that this foolishness is taken care of. He will understand and obey his father."

options.label: C
options.narrative: Show the note to the girl's mother, Councilwoman Vale.

outcomes.narrative: You march the letter over to the Sekhem Gardens, where you find Councilwoman Vale entertaining a few Valraths over tea. She reviews the message then excuses herself to speak with you. "That monstrous merchant and his family will never lay a finger on my daughters, mark my words. I absolutely forbid it! You have proven yourselves a valuable asset."

narrative:
A group of Merchant's Guild tax collectors are winding through the stalls of the Sinking Market. The central collector is a balding man with a bronze pin on his lapel. He's flanked by two wiry associates wearing well-fitting suits. "Taxes," he states matter-of-factly, a leather ledger in hand.

The grocer expresses his frustration: "I just paid you jokers! I can't make a profit with all the nonsense 'taxes' your guild applies."

The tax collector speaks some pre-rehearsed words: "Taxes today pay for improvements tomorrow. Pay, or hawk your wares outside the protection of the Sinking Market. There's plenty of real estate outside the city."

"Protection? It's the Sinking Market! The whole thing is sinking into the bay! I've moved my stand twice this year!" The grocer grabs a meat mallet and brandishes it at them. Taken aback, the tax collectors approach you with a proposition: "Mercenaries, right? Help us collect what's due the merchant guild, and we'll compensate you."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Help the tax collectors recover the taxes they're owed.

outcomes.narrative:
The Merchant's Guild provides valuable services to these people, and everyone needs to pay their fair share. You step forward with the stern look your enemies learned too well, and after a moment of consternation, the grocer turns over a handful of coins to the tax collectors.

The collectors give you a nod, handing over a few coins for your assistance. "It is unfortunate some merchants only respond to threats of violence. Truly a base outlook, but thank you for your efforts."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Help the grocer drive off the tax collectors.

outcomes.narrative: You step up to show this group of shakedown artists just how little their "protection" really means. You grab the central collector by his collar and stare straight into his eyes. He stammers an apology and assures you the error must be in his ledger. "I'll fix it—I'll fix it immediately." The stand operator looks delighted.

You intercede on behalf of the grocer, and after some brief protests, the three tax collectors brush you off and head off to harass someone else. The grocer breathes a sigh of relief, thanking you for your help before turning back to selling his wares.

narrative:
After a long night helping load a merchant's caravan, you head through the Sinking Market to pick up payment for your efforts. Your employer made clear they were heading out to Jhinda at noon, so if you want the gold before they leave town, you'll need to hurry. You're hustling as best you can when a frail, white-haired woman approaches you and grabs you by the arm. She reeks of grime and sewage, and passersby are turning their noses up in disgust.

"Rats! So many rats! I don't know where they're coming from, but they're living in my cellar! They ate through three jars of my preserves just yesterday!" She tugs weakly at your sleeve, which leaves a noticeable dirty mark. "I've asked dozens of mercenaries, but they've turned me away because I can't pay enough! Please, can you help me?"

If you don't find the merchant in the next few minutes you won't get paid for last night's work.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell the woman you can't help her and find the merchant who owes you money.

outcomes.narrative:
You shake the woman off and explain as best you can that you can't assist her right now. You make some vague promises about trying to find her later, but it's no use: soon the woman is bawling in the street, lamenting that no one will help her and how the rats will kill her in her sleep, then feast on her corpse. The whole speech is very graphic, and passersby begin to give you odd looks, wondering what you could have done to upset the poor woman so intensely.

At least you catch the merchant in time to collect your payment.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Help the woman and forgo collecting payment for the merchant's work.

outcomes.narrative: You take pity on the poor woman and follow her back to her home, a ramshackle dwelling half-sunk into the muddy foundation. Sure enough, a family of three Vermlings has illegally moved into her cellar, living off her meager food supplies. You make a big show of reporting them to the guards and they begrudgingly pack their things to go. The old woman thanks you profusely and pays what she can.

narrative:
The citizenry know to never cross the painted orange line that circles the Void, a black sand field in the north of Gloomhaven. Anything that crosses the line turns to a coarse black dust in a shower of sparkling lights.

Despite the danger, it's the central component of a celebration unique to the city. Today is the holiday known as the Spectral Jubilee—an evening for the populace to pack shoulder-to-shoulder to sing carols and toss their burdens into the Void. Supposedly, the more meaningful an object you sacrifice, the larger the spectacle of sparkling lights it produces.

Tonight is the Spectral Jubilee. If you have something to contribute to the unending darkness, you can do so, but if you came unprepared, there are plenty of vendors ready to make some coin by selling meaningful possessions.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Select an item of yours now to throw in (you will lose the item).

outcomes.narrative: You cast your item as hard as you can into the Void. It tears your item to coarse black powder, producing a swirl of indigo light that catches your eye before vanishing. You feel a weight lifted and are excited for what the next year brings.
You toe just over the orange safety line and throw your item into the Void. As it disintegrates, it produces a lightshow that can't be seen anywhere else. You smile, excited for the coming year.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pay a vendor for a meaningful item of theirs to throw in (requires 15 gold).

outcomes.narrative: You purchase a velvet dress from a vendor who assures you it belonged to a woman very dear to him. Sure enough, it produces a fantastic shower of sparks as the Void consumes it, and a cheer rises up from the crowd.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Enjoy the event but do not participate yourself.

outcomes.narrative: You don't resonate with anything for sale, so you instead watch the offerings of others.

narrative:
You were supposed to help guard a spice delivery, but a more enticing (and frankly, lucrative) scenario presented itself, and you won't have time. There are plenty of mercenaries looking for coin. Why not hire them to do your work while you take a cut?

There's the Jaws of the Lion, the best-known mercenary company in Gloomhaven. They also operate out of the Sleeping Lion, but they established their footing before you and can command high prices.

There's the Sin-Ra Syndicate, a shadowy organization whose calling card is a skull on a spike. They typically run their own nefarious operations, but have been known to accept jobs to keep their coffers full.

Or you could employ the Four Crosses, a crass mercenary company whose leader sports a red mohawk. They're rough around the edges, but it's a simple enough job, even for them.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Hire the Jaws of the Lion.

outcomes.narrative: The Jaws of the Lion are consummate professionals—your employer even sends a thank-you note for employing such sharply-dressed mercenaries (he particularly liked one of their fancy hats). They're the best of the best. Your employer even kicks in a hefty bonus, but there isn't much left after giving the Jaws their cut.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Hire the Sin-Ra Syndicate.

effects: Read %game.section:72.4%.

outcomes.narrative: You hear word the next day that the delivery was ambushed by thieves in transit. The Sin-Ra operated with ruthless efficiency, and while the robbers were killed, so were any witnesses, including the delivery driver. Your employer isn't pleased, but still pays for protecting the cargo. It's decent money, even after giving the Sin-Ra their cut.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Hire the Four Crosses.

outcomes.narrative: Boring security work doesn't need good manners. The delivery gets ambushed in transit by thieves, and the Four Crosses take a serious beating before being able to drive them off. Better them than you: it couldn't have happened to a more deserving group.

narrative:
"Someone's coming, juice it!" You round the corner of the alley and hear footsteps escaping in the distance.

Heavy rain has turned this backstreet into a series of pockmarked muddy puddles. At your feet is a slumped figure discarded unceremoniously between old crates. You've seen enough dead bodies to recognize the motionless heap in front of you as a recently-deceased Orchid man, a trickle of blood winding its way between the cobblestones beneath him.

The attackers are long gone, and tracking them in the rain doesn't look promising.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Loot the body.

outcomes.narrative:
In the man's clothes, you find a whopping forty gold, which you grab before the guards arrive. The next morning you're greeted at your door by the largest Savvas you've ever seen—a true walking mountain.

"You took Bonecruncher's money." The notorious loan shark known as "Bonecruncher" has made a name for himself around town, and you certainly don't want to be on his bad side. "Don't worry, he doesn't want it back right now. Seems like he's taken an interest in you, so I'll be taking interest from you from now on." It turns to leave, ominously concluding with, "see you soon."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Alert the authorities.

outcomes.narrative: The guards thank you for reporting it promptly, and after they take a statement, you're free to go. You hope they're able to find whoever did this and bring them to justice.

Two days into the interrogation, the guards are even more convinced you're the killer. They even found blood on your boots, which you tried to explain was from an unrelated scenario. Eventually they release you with a court date. Hopefully you'll have better luck with the judges.

narrative:
A reporter for the Haven Herald has been buying drinks at the Sleeping Lion for a few nights now, clearly hunting for a story. He's well-known for twisting interviews to paint his subjects in a negative light, and the regulars are wary enough to give him nothing.

You managed to avoid him yesterday, but he's back again this evening and is even more persistent. He sits down at your table.

"Listen, I know you know who I am. But all I'm looking for is an interview about what the life of a mercenary is really like. You talk with me for ten minutes, and I'll buy your time. That's your job, right? People pay you for your time. How's ten gold sound? Think of it like any other job—but instead of stomping spines I just want you to tell me about the work you do day-to-day. Sound fair?"

He pulls out a notebook without waiting for an answer. "So... who do you work for most of the time?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell him you usually work for the Merchants.

outcomes.narrative: He takes copious notes, but you come out of it feeling like you avoided any hot-button issues. Well, at least until you read the morning paper, which paints the Merchant's Guild in a miserable light. They're not pleased with the attention.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Tell him you usually work for the Military.

outcomes.narrative: He takes copious notes, but you come out of it feeling like you avoided any hot-button issues. Well, at least until you read the morning paper, which paints the town guard in a miserable light. They're not pleased with the attention.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Tell him you usually work for the Demons.

outcomes.narrative: He takes copious notes, but you come out of it feeling like you avoided any hot-button issues. Well, at least until you read the morning paper, which paints the demons in an accurate but miserable light. They're not pleased with the attention.

options.label: D
options.narrative: Tell him you're not interested in talking, even for ten gold.

outcomes.narrative: "Some mercenaries. I guess if it doesn't involve cutting someone open, you're not interested, huh? Jerks."

narrative:
It's the lavish birthday party of Bonecruncher, a local loan shark. Suddenly, an explosion rocks the venue.

You find Bonecruncher, blood running from a gash on his forehead, shouting at Aerin, Brint, and Cade, his three grown children. The source of the explosion is a smoldering pile of detritus that used to be the gift table. "One of you brats just tried to kill me! This is why I didn't have more of you runts! Which of you... who..." He promptly collapses to the floor from the blood loss. An enormous Savvas starts administering medical attention. In the chaos, you pick up the following information:

Neither Aerin nor Cade brought a red gift, and both have a younger sibling.

The eldest brought a yellow gift.

Cade is not the oldest.

Before you can make sense of it, an Aesther in an unusual hat steps out from behind you. "Hello, something of a whodunnit. Gripping. The important bit is that each child brought just one gift—a green one, a red one, or a yellow one. The green detonated: find out who brought that, and you have your culprit."

options.narrative: Determine who attempted to kill their father, then flip this card. (Say the name aloud now.)

outcomes.narrative:
The Aesther in the unusual hat cracks a smile. "Delightful, very good. Cade brought the green gift, loaded with not-quite-enough explosives. A costly mistake for what could've been a clean patricide."

Bonecruncher begins to stir. "Is that true?" Cade turns a shade of green that matches his gift, and Bonecruncher turns to you. "We'll handle this within the family." In thanks, he hands you a mostly-not-burned gift, and that's the last you see of Cade.

The Aesther tips his hat. "The name's Detective Elsewhere. Good to make your acquaintance!" With that, he steps into a portal and is gone.

"No, I told you it was the green gift—a gift given by Cade, the middle child. Aerin is the eldest with the yellow gift, and Brint the youngest with red. Cade went to so much trouble loading that gift with explosives, he certainly deserves the credit for attempted patricide."

Bonecruncher begins to stir. "Did you try to make this my last birthday?" Cade turns a shade of green that matches his gift, and the muscle-bound Savvas bodyguard leads the family away.

The Aesther shrugs. "Better luck next time, I suppose. Be seeing you." And with that, he steps into a portal and is gone.

narrative:
A Quatryl mail carrier is stopped just inside the gates to Gloomhaven, arguing with the town guard. "I don't have the mail stamp. I've been on the road for weeks—I had to fight a polar bear to bring this here. Nothing else is going through that pass until the thaw, months from now." You step up and ask what the problem is.

The guard turns to you and explains, if only to reduce the crowd watching the scene unfold. "She lost her mail's certificate of passage. Without the documentation, she'll need to pay an import tariff equal to the value of the goods in transit."

"You're not going to find some other idiot to make the trek up to Frosthaven to collect the missing paperwork—it's a miracle I made it back at all. It's mail! Look at it! I'm not smuggling thistle!"

"I'm sorry, but we'll need to open each of the packages and confirm the value. I'll issue you a receipt, and you can retrieve your belongings at the town hall after the tariff is paid."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Intercede on her behalf.

outcomes.narrative:
You pull the guardsman aside and explain that interference with the mail system impacts everyone in the city. You vouch for this carrier and strongly recommend he lets her through, even without the required documentation. He sheepishly nods and waves her past.

"Finally! Now, where can I get a drink around here?"

You pull the new guardsman aside and attempt to explain he's giving the town guard a bad name. "She's welcome to take it up with the council members. What's next? A warband claims they forgot their diplomatic sigil and I allow them to set up camp in the town square?" You roll your eyes and leave them to work it out.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Support the guard in following protocol.

outcomes.narrative:
You keep the gathering crowd back and let the guard do his work. It takes nearly until dark, but he opens every package and records a complete manifest of the contents. Crude weapons, exotic pelts, and many, many satchels of assorted herbs.

"If she doesn't come up with the paperwork in forty eight hours, the entire lot will be impounded and put towards the city. I'm sure it won't come to that, though."

narrative:
"Hey, you want to make some easy cash?" A man with scarred hands and a weathered look approaches you, casting a cautious look back over his shoulder.

"I'm new in town, came in from White Oak a few hours ago. My wagon broke down and I just need to get enough money for repairs to get back. I've got some personal belongings I'm looking to offload, but my reputation with the shops around here isn't as good as back home, so they're lowballing me. Could you sell this stuff for me? I'll give you a cut."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sell the man's goods for him.

outcomes.narrative:
His belongings turn out to be an odd mismatch of items: three new pairs of leather boots in different sizes, a set of copper mugs, an antique vase, and other sundry objects.

The shops are used to you dragging in piles of stuff from your adventures, and they don't bat an eye. You split the proceeds with him and he gives a gruff nod in thanks.

His belongings turn out to be an odd mismatch of items: three new pairs of leather boots in different sizes, a set of copper mugs, an antique vase, and other sundry objects.

It takes the better part of the afternoon to get everything sold, as many shopkeeps refuse to purchase what they perceive as stolen goods. By the time he takes his cut, there isn't much left.

effects: Read %game.section:22.1%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Report him to the authorities.

outcomes.narrative: You flag down the nearest guard. When you turn to point the man out, he's already fled. The guard confirms they've seen an uptick in criminals trying to find unsuspecting people to fence their goods for them. He thanks you for the report.

effects: Read %game.section:93.2%.

narrative:
Pacing the floor of his estate before you is Councilman Greymare. The urgent invitation you received didn't have any details, but you're not one to turn down a chance to visit Gloomhaven leadership. He beckons you over.

"Hurry, everything is falling apart!" As if to punctuate his statement, you hear the shout of a woman from the room behind him, followed by a thunderous crash. The councilman gives a sigh before continuing.

"I have an emissary here from the Eastern Continent. Their delegation has been staying under my roof, in my care. This afternoon was supposed to be the presentation of a gift of rare star iron." He wrings his hands as another loud crash can be heard from the room.

"Perhaps you are familiar with Gloomhaven's very own Harrower vigilante, the Green Carapace?" You've heard the name. "A half hour ago, they broke into my parlor and stole the chest of star iron! And in the process, they attacked the esteemed delegate, reducing them to..." The councilman spots something crawling out from under the door and instinctively goes to smash it, stopping himself at the last moment. He ushers it carefully back inside.

"Well, the vigilante dissolved the delegate into a sea of bugs."

"Perhaps that's a bit dramatic. The esteemed delegate Buzar is a Harrower, so they're normally made of bugs. They're just normally bugs that can... talk." Councilman Greymare cracks the door open to give you a look inside at the horrifying sight: thousands of bugs crawl across every visible surface. A fainting couch features most of a Harrower, a sentient hive-creature made of insects, but it's clear they're not in control of most of their body. Buzzing through the air and draped all over the cushions is a black carpet of undulating legs and mandibles. An Orchid woman in the traditional garb of the Eastern Continent rushes about, trying to corral the insects.

He closes the door, visibly disturbed by the sight. "Where is my valet? We need more containers." He tugs on a nearby closet door but is thwarted by the lock. "Blast it. Where is Apollon!?" He starts down the hall when the closet door clicks open from the inside, and a slim, olive-skinned man stumbles out and falls to the ground.

"Ugh... the Green... Carapace, they attacked me. I tried to stop them..." Apollon gives a ragged cough, and from the way his wrist is hanging, it looks broken.

The councilman looks mortified. "Not you too! The chest of star iron is set to be presented in two hours' time—that gift will secure our trade route for the next decade! I've got the house cordoned off, the chest can't have left the grounds. Find it before then, or this will be a diplomatic nightmare!"

options.narrative: Interview Apollon, the battered valet.

effects: Read %game.section:57.1%.

options.narrative: Interview Buzar, the incapacitated diplomat.

effects: Read %game.section:77.5%.

narrative:
"Fill the gauntlet! Fill the gauntlet!" A guardsman is approaching passersby and asking for donations to build upgrades on the eastern barracks. He holds out an old iron gauntlet and generous (or perhaps, sufficiently irritated) citizens drop a few coins in as they pass.

"You there! Would you care to help fill the gauntlet? A proper barracks is an important part of protecting the city!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Donate a few coins.

outcomes.narrative: You drop a handful of coins into the gauntlet and the plink of metal against metal brings a smile to the guard's face. "Thank you, friend! We'll see to it it's put to good use protecting fine citizens like you!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Politely refuse to support the town guard.

outcomes.narrative: You shake your head and walk past, and the guard quickly turns to other targets.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Aggressively and loudly refuse to support the town guard.

outcomes.narrative: You take several minutes to deride the panhandling of the military, the effect on morale, and several exceptionally unkind things about the guards' presence in the city. You make clear in boisterous terms that the military presence begging for help from common citizens is a perfect metaphor for how they handle every problem, unable to do even something as simple as manage their own finances. The guard's friendly demeanor turns to absolute mortification by the time you wrap up ten minutes of dressing him down. A small group has gathered to watch the spectacle, and you finish with a few short words about why your preferred faction should be in charge.
effects: Gain 1 reputation with Merchants Guild or Sect.

narrative:
It's well past midnight as you finally make your way home from your last adventure. On the way to a warm bed, you hear whimpering emanating from a side street and go closer to investigate.

"Two of us, one of you! That's two counts of resisting arrest! Whaddoyou think that adds up to?" A pair of guards have cornered an unfortunate Vermling in an alley. With a chuckle, the guard continues, "I'd guess fifteen years in the Ghost Fortress, were we to turn you in. So, instead, why don't you just give us what's on you, and we'll forget all about this."

The Vermling tries to squeak out a reply. "I didn't take anything!"

"You took this alley tonight, that's enough," the guard replies with a laugh. It's cut short as they suddenly realize you're standing there. He instantly softens. "Hey, listen, let this one slide, and we'll put in a good word with the boss."

options.label: A
options.narrative: These two are a disgrace to the military. Turn them in to their commanding officer.

outcomes.narrative: The next morning, you make a full report to the watch captain, who in turn escalates it up the chain. The dirty looks of the two guards as they're forced to turn in their badges during the investigation is payment enough, but the appreciation of the higher-ups doesn't hurt, either.

options.label: B
options.narrative: No sense in tarnishing the guards' good names over a momentary mistake. Turn a blind eye.

outcomes.narrative:
You agree to keep quiet on what you saw, but insist the guards put in a good word for you with the military brass. They're clearly appreciative of your good sense.

You do wonder what will happen to that Vermling, though.

You take a page out of the guards' book and demand they sweeten the deal for your silence.

You agree to keep quiet on what you saw, but insist the guards put in a good word for you with the military brass. They're clearly appreciative of your good sense.

You do wonder what will happen to that Vermling, though.

narrative:
The Void is a troubling area in Gloomhaven—a vast, barren expanse of black sand amid the bustling streets of the city. No one enters the painted safety outline around its perimeter.

On a trip to the University, however, you see a young girl playing past the warning line near the edge of the Void. Before you can warn her, she trips and falls onto the sand.

She immediately emits a blood-curdling scream and begins to tear at her skin.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Run to the girl and attempt to pull her out of the Void.

outcomes.narrative: You grab the child and lift her clear of the haunting area. She is still screaming madly when the Aesther in your group lays a hand upon the child in deep concentration. Slowly, the crying subsides, and the child gets up and runs off.
effects: Gain 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

outcomes.narrative: You get the child off the sand as quickly as you can, but it doesn't do much good. The girl screams and screams, no matter what aid is administered, half of her face having taken on the sand-like texture of the Void itself. Eventually, a schoolteacher scoops her up and you continue on your way.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Watch and make note of the Void's effects on a living creature.

outcomes.narrative: You watch to see what happens to the girl, making mental note for future reference. Her skin turns ashen and begins to flake away. She tries to stand, frantically brushing a thick black dust from her clothes as they fall away. Onlookers quickly rush to her aid, but it's clear half her body has been permanently scorched by the Void's corruption. You know some friends that would find this research helpful.

narrative:
You decide to spend your evening slumming it at the Brown Door, a dive bar in the Old Docks. Sitting at the back of the room, you see an old man hunched over a set of glass beads. He somberly invites you to sit at his table, eager for the company. He pours some beads into his fist, placing the rest carefully into his breast pocket.

"Care to guess how many beads I have in this hand here? Get it right and I'll make it worth your while. It's tougher than it looks!"

He laughs, nodding to himself as though he's said something funny. "It used to be simpler. Simpler, yes."

options.narrative: Collectively guess a number between one and five. (Say the number aloud now.)

outcomes.narrative: The old man opens his hand with a weary flair and a smile. "Tell me, was it a lucky guess, or did you hear them? No one has heard them in a long while, since before Roland tore apart this city. Tell me you heard them! It's been so long!"
Choose one:

effects: Tell him you heard them - Read %game.section:15.5%.
Tell him it was a random guess - Read %game.section:40.5%.

outcomes.narrative: The old man pops open his hand to show three gleaming glass beads. He snickers, as though it was a joke you should've seen coming. "The voices really are gone." He looks despondent enough, you pick up his tab for the evening.

narrative: Do not allow anyone else to see this card.

effects: When you have determined the face of the purse-snatcher, read %game.section:81.3%.

narrative:
You spot a young man just outside the Temple of the Great Oak carrying a small parcel under his arm. He approaches a few nearby groups and walks off dejected. He catches your gaze and moves your way.

"Excuse me, I'm supposed to deliver this to someone affiliated with the Merchant's Guild. The directions weren't ideal... or, really, directions at all. You wouldn't happen to know where to find them, would you?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Why yes, that's us!

outcomes.narrative:
You proudly state you work with the Merchant's Guild, and would be happy to accept delivery.

The smile disappears from his face as he draws a thin blade from his package. In a flash and with expert precision, he thrusts it at you. He manages a few good hits before he runs off.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Admit you're not in good favor with the Merchant's Guild.

outcomes.narrative:
You politely explain that you're not in good favor with the Merchant's Guild, and wouldn't be able to direct him to anyone pertinent. The young man smiles a grin through a set of too-white teeth.

"Not a problem, I'll assure you you're better for it... I'm sure someone around here can accept delivery."

narrative:
One of the local barflies stumbles over to your table, a semi-drunk stupor over her face. Words tumble thoughtlessly out of her mouth.

"Did you know that I have a glass eye?" She loudly exclaims to no one in particular. She leans down to give you a better look, and sure enough, her right eye has a clear glassy sheen. Now that you've noticed it, you can't unsee it.

"It's a really good one. You don't even know which one it is, huh?" If you weren't sure before, her bloodshot real left eye gives a bit of a twitch and removes all doubt. She grabs your arm, helping you to extend a finger and dragging it closer to her face. "Poke it. Poke which one you think it is! You'll never get it right." She stares directly at your fingertip.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Poke her in the left eye.

outcomes.narrative:
So as to not damage her confidence in her prosthetic, you reach out and touch her squishy, warm, left eye. You give it a couple of moist taps to confirm. A smile creeps across her face until she can't hold it in anymore.

"Hah! That's my real one!" She pops out her glass eye, expertly rolling it across her knuckles—a feat even for someone sober, but she does it with practiced effortlessness. "Best glass eye in Gloomhaven! You pop two of these in a Harrower, and it could pass for human, no question!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Poke her in the right eye.

outcomes.narrative: There's only one way to get this right for certain. You extend two fingers and poke her in both eyes at once. "Owww! What'd you do that for!?" Some upset onlookers make clear you need to make it right, so you buy her a drink. It's enough to let everyone get on with the evening.

It's pretty clear which eye is fake, and you're not one to take a dive on a direct challenge. You extend your finger and poke her right in the glass. "Pfft. Lucky guess, that's all! I know you can't tell, no one can."

narrative:
Sometimes people pay a mercenary for their strength, and sometimes they pay for their discretion. You've picked up a simple job to ferry a sealed envelope from the Boiler District to the Sinking Market, and you asked exactly the right number of questions: none.

They said if you prove yourself here, there's more work in the future. Fifteen gold for an hour's work? Easy.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Deliver the envelope to the address as agreed.

outcomes.narrative: You hand off the envelope to a hooded man in the Sinking Market. With a nod, he drops a sack of coins in your hand, and he doesn't seem in any rush as you take the time to count it. He thanks you for your help and says they'll call again if they need you in the future.

options.label: B
options.narrative: People don't pay like this to deliver love letters. Open the envelope.

outcomes.narrative: You tear open the envelope and find detailed logs of guard movements throughout the Boiler District. The notes detail hours where security is lightest, and the shifts most likely to allow activities to go unnoticed. The records are weeks of work, and you can only imagine the value they'd have in the right hands. You could alert the guards or earn yourself a favor from a faction of your choosing.
effects: Gain either 2 reputation with the ruling faction or 1 reputation with any one other faction.

narrative:
You meet with a group of Quatryls, Inox, and Vermlings at the University researching the power core you recovered from the arcane library's construct. Probes run across the shiny object, leaded lamps flickering various indicators as they run one experiment after another.

"We're close to a breakthrough, I can feel it." The lead researcher looks like they believe it. "We'll just need a little more time, or a little more... investment." A loud POP sounds from the device nearest the power core, followed by a stream of soot-laden smoke. You see the researcher is getting antsy. "We've gone through considerable resources trying to power it on again, and resupply has been difficult."

The researcher shakes her head, walking back over to the testing. "Good news, though: have I told you that Councilwoman Vale has agreed to let you test the weapon once it's complete?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Encourage Councilwoman Vale to increase the researchers' funding.

outcomes.narrative: You visit Councilwoman Vale's office to plead for more funding. Her valet shoos you away with the assurance that it's a very important matter to the councilwoman, and you can be confident she'll look into it right away.
effects: Check one box below. If all boxes are checked, read %game.section:131.2% and remove this card from the city deck.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pay for the needed parts yourself.

outcomes.narrative: You ask how much it would take to accelerate the analysis. "Oh, we need some additional radiance crystals, cabling certainly, and some additional protective equipment." A small fire starts at the back of the lab, and a Vermling casually dumps a pot of water on it—it's clear this isn't the first time.
effects: The party may lose 10 collective gold per box to check any number of boxes above in Outcome A. If all boxes in Outcome A are checked, read %game.section:131.2% and remove this card from the city deck.

narrative:
Bonecruncher, the local loan shark, doesn't offer much in the way of hospitality when you visit him in a ramshackle building in the Boiler District. Occupying the only remaining chair in the room is a massive Savvas bodyguard that feels so unthreatened by your presence, it's reading a newspaper. Bonecruncher rips a mouthful of meat off a bone, throwing the remainder to a pair of vicious-looking dogs.

"I recently got a cargo ship from someone who won't be using it anymore." Bonecruncher doesn't elaborate, picking a hunk of meat from between his teeth with a long fingernail. "But I have a problem: my shipments keep getting raided by enterprising pirates. So, I have a proposition for you. Get on board. Keep my next delivery safe. Do this for me, and I'll give you 150 gold, each."

You're surprised at Bonecruncher's sudden generosity until he continues, "...in the form of forgiving you and that Sawbones friend of yours' debt to me."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Accept Bonecruncher's offer to clear the debt.

outcomes.narrative: You swallow your pride and accept Bonecruncher's "generous" offer. If it really does get you off the hook for repayment, it's worth the time.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Demand he pay for your services in gold, same as anyone else.

outcomes.narrative:
You tear the newspaper out of the bodyguard's hands, shredding it with a scream. The Savvas guard looks surprised—even the dogs look confused, shying away behind the desk. You grab a half-finished drumstick off Bonecruncher's plate and lock gaze with him, biting it in half and swallowing, bone and all. A stillness falls across the room.

Just when the silence becomes unbearable, Bonecruncher breaks out in a belly laugh. "Hah, you're crazy! Anyone ever tell you that? I like crazy. Alright, I guess I can throw in a few coins for your effort. Don't let anybody ever tell you Bonecruncher isn't kind."

You attempt to bargain for payment, but Bonecruncher rolls his eyes, and the bodyguard finally gets off its chair to escort you out. The massive Savvas isn't rough about it, but you can't help but feel it's just because it doesn't consider you a threat.

narrative:
The shrill screams of the populace were a bad sign. The giant drake perched on top of the library was confirmation this was going to be a rough afternoon.

"I have not killed a human in many hours now, you have nothing to fear!" Those who can run break into a dead sprint, others take cover behind whatever buildings they can find. "I am looking for a group of polite mercenaries, perhaps you can—oh please, stop that incessant screaming! I said QUIEEEET!" A gout of flame bursts from his mouth for emphasis, although you note it wasn't directed at anyone intentionally.

He spots you amidst the commotion. "Ah, there you are! I thought I might find you in the perceived safety of your walled city. Obviously not much good against, well..." he raises his wings and gives a light shrug. "In any case, I am calling in that favor. I have come to request a meal, at your expense." Someone screams in horror.

"No, I don't mean you." The drake narrows his eyes then raises a brow, suddenly unsure. "Unless...? Is that a customary meal in this place?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Bring the drake to a meal in the Traveler's District.

outcomes.narrative:
The drake follows you as you wind through the city, until you reach the central courtyard of the Traveler's District. While its initial approach left the populace terrified, its presence now commands a good deal of curiosity. You offhandedly note that the drake is seeking a meal.

An hour later, a queue has formed: quality vendors each waiting their turn to offer the drake a sample of their dishes. "The seasoning is impeccable... mmmMm... is that arrowvine? And these tiny radishes!" For weeks afterward, visitors come in the hopes of a repeat performance—one which you're thankful you don't need to orchestrate.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Bring the drake to the Sleeping Lion.

outcomes.narrative:
His torso blocks the entirety of the side-street, and only his head fits through the doorway, but the drake turns out to be a fun drinking companion. The bartender rolls out a fine barrel of juniper ale, and the meat pies are fresh this afternoon.

Hours later, the usual crowd is swapping stories with their newest, largest friend, who is responding with boisterous advice. "No, you cannot be serious. He—hic!—did not say that to you. You could do so much better than him! Burn his house and move on, Janet." As the sun begins to crest the hilltops, the drake finally passes out, blocking the door. The patrons are happy to climb out the windows so as to not disturb him.

narrative:
"All rise!"

The chamber door opens, and in funnel three ivory-masked arbiters. Their identities are well-known—they're borderline celebrities in the public sphere—but tradition dictates their faces are hidden while meting out justice. It's the day of your hearing, and you've arrived early in the hope of getting in the arbiters' good graces to talk your way out of your criminal accusations. It doesn't work well.

"I recognize you..." the central arbiter leans over the podium. Their demeanor suggests they don't mean it in a good way.

The bailiff shouts over the din of the crowd: "Justice will commence momentarily. Please be seated. If you are among the accused, prepare yourselves accordingly. May your truth fear no open flame."

OTHERWISE: Choose an option as normal.

options.narrative: Hire a representative to act as your counsel before the arbiters (requires 10 collective gold).

outcomes.narrative: You hire local counsel, a doting old Orchid who speaks with a slow drawl.

effects.narrative: The arbiters let you off with just a stern warning.

outcomes.narrative: You explain as best you can and throw yourself on the mercy of the court. They let you off with just a fine and a stern warning.

narrative:
You're staffing the high-profile wedding of Nectar Vale to Greggory Greymare. As the children of councilmembers, this is the event of the year. You're here to check invites at the door and keep the undesirables out. They've even provided clean white gloves to wear... fancy.

Basseloff, the pompous Quatryl bard who has somehow garnered a following, shows up and presents his invite. "The pleasure is all yours, now let me through."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Allow him to enter.

outcomes.narrative: The invitation looks to be in order, so you unclip the leather gate-rope and allow him to step aside. He scoffs a bit. "I cannot fathom what took you so long. Perhaps literacy isn't a requirement for door-guards!" He suddenly catches the eye of Councilman Greymare and instantly drops his indignation. "Willem! It is a pleasure to see you!" They disappear into the crowd.
effects: Resolve event C-42 now.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse him entry.

outcomes.narrative:
You inform Basseloff that his invitation is counterfeit and that he will not be granted admittance. His eyes widen like two porcelain plates. "WHAT DID YOU SAY TO I, BASSELOFF, THE GREATEST BARD THAT EVER LIVED?"

You start to escort him from the premises when Councilwoman Vale rushes over. "What is the meaning of this? Why have you laid hands on our esteemed guest?" She is both trying to admonish you and pacify Basseloff, who appears on the verge of a stroke.

"THESE BRIGANDS REFUSED ME ENTRY! THESE—THESE TONE-DEAF CRITICS MUST BE EXPELLED IMMEDIATELY! I AM BASSELOFF!"

Ten minutes later you're informed your services are no longer needed.

narrative:
The next guest is a young woman with an elegant, form-fitting velvet dress. She ascends the staircase to the venue and looks to you to remove the leather rope to allow her inside. "Hi, I'm here for the Vale wedding?" You ask for her invitation.

"Oh, sure! Yes, I have it here." She thumbs through her purse and produces it.

"Looks like it'll be a fun evening - you must see all sorts of celebrities coming through here!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Allow her to enter.

outcomes.narrative: You wave her through and can see the excitement on her face. An hour later, Councilwoman Vale and the wedding planner drag the young woman back to the entrance, fury in their eyes. "Did you let this reporter through the door? Did you even look at her invitation? It's nonsense. It doesn't even have the groom's name spelled correctly!" The young lady rushes down the stairs and out of sight. "You're fired."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse her entry.

outcomes.narrative:
You point out that the invitation is clearly a fake, and you refuse to let her through. She immediately drops the act, desperate.

"Please—I just want to see, to experience this. I spent a month's salary on this dress, I—I'm begging you, I won't say a word, no one will know I'm there." You look unmoved, and she scrambles around the interior of her purse. "I have coin. I can make it worth your while. Please!"

effects:
Accept a bribe to allow her entry.
Read %game.section:84.3%.
Refuse her entry. Read %game.section:40.4%.

narrative:
"Hey, aren't you the mercenaries who took a crossbow bolt to the chest to protect that nobleman?"

A dock worker looms over your table in the Sleeping Lion, pointing at you with wonder in his eyes. "Is it true the doctors said you'd never lift a sword again?"

More people stop and stare at you. This has become a common occurrence since the nobleman was saved, who has seemingly spent every waking minute telling anyone who will listen about the mercenary that bravely stopped his assassination. You invite the gathering crowd to pull up a chair and hear your retelling of the tale.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Remind the crowd that it was quite a traumatic incident, and a drink would be helpful, if they'd be so kind. (Requires %game.trait:hero% or %game.trait:friend-of-the-hero%).

outcomes.narrative: You recount, tastefully, just how incredible your performance was that day. The split-second that changed the fate of the nobleman's life, and your own, intertwining the two forevermore.
