You explain the fear, the momentary internal debate that gave way to your own grievous injury protecting another. You explain the hardship—again, tastefully—of your recovery, and in no time at all, people are buying you drinks. By the end of the evening, a pile of tips has built up in front of you.
effects: Each character without %game.trait:hero% or %game.trait:friend-of-the-hero% gains %game.trait:friend-of-the-hero%.

outcomes.narrative: You relay the story you've heard a hundred times: the tale of your friend protecting a nobleman in complete disregard for their own safety. It's a good story, but it misses a bit of the punch by being told second-hand, and you can tell the crowd is just being polite by the end. A few folks are appreciative enough of the diversion to tip a few gold your way.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain they must be mistaking you for someone else.

outcomes.narrative: "Oh, sorry. Right, yeah... I thought you looked like someone who used to hang out with... never mind."

narrative:
Waiting outside the Sleeping Lion, you find two gruff enforcers. "Glad we ran into each other, Bonecruncher has been asking about you. Time for a payment on that debt of yours, huh?" One of the enforcers casually brushes his hair back, tying it up with a length of thin chain in preparation for your response.

"You didn't forget about your debt, did you? Don't worry, Bonecruncher's got a real good memory, he won't let it slip." He cracks his knuckles menacingly. "Pay up."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Attempt to avoid paying.

outcomes.narrative: "Oh, our mistake. Enjoy your evening."
You break out in a dead sprint, and the enforcers can't keep pace. You hear them shout after you: "We'll catch up eventually!"
effects: Add this card to the city deck as the fifth card from the top.

outcomes.narrative: It's a good fight, and by the time they finally tap, out everyone involved is bleeding, panting and sore. "There'll always be more. You'll pay, you'll see."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pay interest on your debt.

outcomes.narrative: "Thank you for remaining in Bonecruncher's good graces, much obliged." The duo shake you down for what you're carrying, helping themselves to your savings. "And it's always nice to keep track of who's good for a debt."
effects: Each character loses half of their gold (rounded up). Each character without %game.trait:indebted% gains %game.trait:indebted%.

narrative:
You come back to your room to find your door knocked off its hinges, and all your personal belongings scattered around the floor.

"Cozy, I like it." Perched on top of your bedsheets is a massive mountain of a Savvas, rocky torso and arms flexing as it stands to greet you. A swirl of red flame idly flickers in its chest, demonstrating this Savvas has complete mastery of fire. With a body that titanic, you don't know what need of magic it would have.

"Bonecruncher told me you didn't cooperate with repayment." The Savvas surveys your room with mild curiosity. "When people pay, the system works. If people don't pay, the system breaks down. This is just a reminder to cooperate." It snaps its fingers, and your bed ignites with a gout of flame. You rush to put it out before it spreads and when you turn back, the Savvas has already gone. Attempts to find the Savvas prove fruitless.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Report this to the authorities.

outcomes.narrative: You flag down a passing guard, who promises to look into the matter. A few days later, at the barracks, you're told the investigation has determined it was a passing Vermling thief—they've already caught him, he confessed, and he's been sentenced to six months in the Ghost Fortress. You try to explain it wasn't a Vermling, but a Savvas, and the guard looks away, suddenly nervous. "It's above my pay grade. We did recover some of the funds, hopefully that helps put this matter behind us."
effects: Add this card to the city deck as the fifth card from the top.

outcomes.narrative: You flag down a passing guard, who promises to look into the matter. Checking in at the Barracks a few days later, you find the report was conveniently misplaced. "You said it was related to a missed payment to Bonecruncher? Sometimes these things happen... you should pay off that debt, if you know what's good for you."
effects: Add this card to the city deck as the fifth card from the top.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Reinforce your door.

outcomes.narrative: After a few hours effort, some very long nails, and heavy planks of oak, you've rebuilt your door stronger than it was before—let's see anyone try to break through that!

narrative:
A light knock at your door reveals Apollon, Councilman Greymare's attendant. His arm is bound in a sling, resting uselessly against his side.

"Mercenaries. Might I come in? The night air is cold, and it carries words to curious ears." You oblige his request. When you last saw Apollon, you had identified him as the Green Carapace, a masked vigilante, and were kind enough to keep his secret.

"Our mutual friend has discovered some unsettling activity near the docks. It's important that someone address it immediately to prevent any further loss of life. Unfortunately, I'm in no condition to attend to it myself right now." He uses his good arm to gesture to the sling, the bones still recovering from his fight with Buzar. "Given the limited pool of people aware of... ahem, I was hoping that you could make an appearance where our friend cannot." He jingles a stout bag of coins. "Surely you have time to spread the verdant light of the scarab."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Ask that he throws in a training session with his "friend."

outcomes.narrative:
Apollon's arm may be broken, but he's a trained fighter and can still pose as a challenging sparring partner. He shows you some moves he's perfected in the field and you spend a few hours swapping combat stories.

Before he departs for the night, he explains the mission: "It's been too long since the Green Carapace has been sighted, and rumors of its demise are spreading. The Sin-Ra are producing some sort of poison serum in a warehouse by the docks—I need you to make a mess of their operation and pose as the vigilante while you do it. Keep fear going in the hearts of evil... it would be unfortunate for my progress to backslide."
effects: Each character gains a perk mark.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Negotiate an additional fee for maintaining his secret.

outcomes.narrative:
"Then I'll pay for two jobs: rescuing the distressed, and sealing your lips." He hands over a mountain of coins.

Before he departs for the night, he explains the mission: "It's been too long since the Green Carapace has been sighted, and rumors of its demise are spreading. The Sin-Ra are producing some sort of poison serum in a warehouse by the docks—I need you to make a mess of their operation and pose as the vigilante while you do it. Keep fear going in the hearts of evil... it would be unfortunate for my progress to backslide."

narrative:
First Shield Harmon wraps up the briefing outside a suspected gang hideout in the Sinking Market: "Our intel says there's crates inside: one is full of stolen gold, the others rigged to explode. Secure the room and we'll determine which is which." On their signal, you push inside.

You notice the door is booby-trapped a second too late, detonating a charge that ignites the room. The other guards fall back, but through the fire you spot them: four crates, each identical. One holds gold. The others, more explosives.

With no time for analysis, you select one of the crates at random and push through the growing flames towards it. Before you can reach it, though, a ceiling beam tumbles down, crushing two of the other crates. The damage triggers explosives inside them, further destabilizing the building. There are just two crates left, and fire is licking at your heels. You'll only have time to open one.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Open the first crate you selected.

outcomes.narrative: A member of the medical team patches you up outside, tending to your wounds. First Shield Harmon slaps you on the back, prompting a coughing fit. "Unfortunate you picked an explosive crate instead of the stolen gold. Odds were just against us. We'll get those thieving bastards someday, though, you'll see."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Switch to the other crate.

outcomes.narrative:
A guard finishes brushing the soot off your back, engrossed in your story. "Really impressive, you only had a twenty five percent chance of finding it under those conditions."

Another guard chimes in: "It would've been fifty percent, wouldn't it?"

The first guard shakes his head. "No, hang on—would it have been seventy five percent?"

You leave them to argue and hand the recovered gold over to First Shield Harmon, who is uncharacteristically smiling.

"Let's make a deal: I'll give you a cut of your findings for your help, and you get some well-earned rest."

narrative:
"Thank you, thank you for coming so quickly." The nobleman looks around to confirm the street is empty before inviting you inside. There, in the middle of the room, is the corpse of a thief, a pool of blood staining the rug below.

"He broke in, I was terrified. I got the drop on him, but it could have readily gone the other way." The nobleman looks pretty shaken by the encounter, getting a far-off look. He quickly snaps himself out of it, continuing, "In any case, it would be politically inconvenient for this to get out. I'm sure this is something you encounter frequently, given your sort of work. Can you help me?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Call in your contacts to remove the body.

outcomes.narrative: You arrange to have some Vermlings stop by and they quickly drag the body out the back door and down into the sewers—you suspect it won't resurface.
You flag down a passing guard patrol and they complacently nod along. The whole matter is very discrete and done before daybreak.
You produce a small urn of powder, tracing it around the body. With the strike of a match, a full-sized flame demon appears and incinerates the corpse.
It just takes a bit of gold to keep people's mouths shut and get the corpse out.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Take care of its removal yourself.

outcomes.narrative: You roll the corpse up in the rug to move it. Gloomhaven has enough unmonitored alleyways that it'll be a long time before it's discovered.
effects: Read %game.section:101.5%.

outcomes.narrative: The nobleman looks concerned as you have trouble hefting the corpse out the door.
effects: Read %game.section:93.1%.

narrative:
The Merchant's Guild tax collectors are winding through the stalls of the Sinking Market. The central collector is a young man with a brass pin on his lapel. He's flanked by two other disheveled associates, each wearing ill-fitting suits. "Taxes," he states matter-of-factly, a brand-new leather ledger in hand.

The frustrated grocer starts yelling: "I just paid you idiots! You don't help merchants—you're just bill collectors now!"

The tax collector speaks some pre-rehearsed words: "Taxes today pay for improvements tomorrow. Pay, or hawk your wares outside the protection of the Sinking Market. There's plenty of real estate outside the city walls."

"Protection? It's the Sinking Market! It's sinking into the bay! I've moved my stand twice this year!" The grocer grabs a meat mallet and brandishes it at them. Taken aback, the tax collectors approach with a proposition: "Mercenaries, right? Help us collect what's due the merchant guild, and we'll compensate you for your time."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Help the tax collectors recover the taxes they're owed.

outcomes.narrative:
You step forward with the stern look your enemies learned too well, and after a moment of consternation the grocer turns over a handful of coins to the tax collectors.

The collectors give you a delighted nod, handing over a few coins for your assistance. "I'll remind them just how helpful you were as soon as I return to the office!" The collectors quickly make their way off to other business.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Help the grocer drive off the tax collectors.

outcomes.narrative:
You look up and down the "tax collector" before you and notice the minor inconsistencies—a brass pin rather than bronze, and an ill-fitting suit on what should be a sharply-dressed collector. It's an excellent dupe, but these are some clever con men trying to pick up coin for themselves. When confronted, they quickly drop the act. "We, the uh—the Merchant's Guild, that is, because I speak for the Merchant's Guild, the uh—taxes are free today, thank you!" The kids bolt.

The grocer's eyes widen, and he passes off some delicious fruit as thanks.

narrative:
The shopkeep addresses you with urgency the second you walk into a high-class establishment in the Coin District. "Sorry, excuse me. There is some business I must attend to across town—would you be willing to man my shop for a few hours? I'll reward you handsomely." Without other plans, you shrug and agree.

Hours later, you have a newfound appreciation for just how often someone walks through, touches everything, and buys nothing. Finally, the door opens to reveal four mercenaries you recognize as the Four Crosses, a rival group that operates out of the Brown Door, a seedy pub in the Old Docks. The leader is a red-haired brawler with a mohawk who has always rubbed you the wrong way.

"Whoa—aren't you those mercenaries from the Sleepy Lion? You so poor you have to run a shop between gigs?" His friends chortle, but before you can respond he spots an ornate battle axe on display. "That. I want that. How much?"

You happen to know it's 20 gold.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell him it's 20 gold.

outcomes.narrative: You let him know the price and he drops the coins on the counter, grabbing the axe before you've even had a chance to count it. "I guess you were too busy sweeping the shop to bother buying this beauty. Well, good luck finding work—I'm sure things'll turn around for mercenaries as good as you are!" He holds back a laugh as the group departs. A few hours later, the shopkeep returns, relieved you're still there. He offers you a discount on anything in the store.
effects: Each character may immediately purchase one item from the available item supply for half price.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Tell him it's 40 gold.

outcomes.narrative: You tell him it's double the actual price. "That's... basically everything I have." He looks a bit sheepish. "Whatever, I still want it." He drops the 40 gold on the counter and turns to leave. "Good luck staying open with prices like these. You're lucky I'm super rich and can afford it!" He intentionally bumps a display of pole arms to the ground on his way out, eliciting laughs from his friends. A few hours later, the shopkeep returns and offers you a discount on his wares. You don't mention your "enhanced" pricing.
effects: Each character may immediately purchase one item from the available item supply for half price.

narrative:
"Help!" A young soldier stumbles out of a darkened alley, whimpering as a pair of Orchids seize him and drag him back into the shadows. You dash into the alley, where the Orchids have the soldier pinned against the stone wall. All three of them wear pendants in the shape of a trident rising through a spiral—the symbol of the Sect.

"Please," the guard cries, "They're gonna kill me!"

One of the Orchids growls. "He joined the Sect. We told him our plans, showed him our hideouts, taught him our secret codes..."

"And then he tried to run," the other Orchid finishes, punching the soldier in the gut. "We can't let him go and spill everything to the military."

"The Sect is crazy! They're a cult!" the soldier pleads, "I didn't know what I was getting into. Please, I swear by the Oak I'll never tell—OOF!" He coughs as the Orchid lands another blow.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Explain to the deserter that it's too late to back out now.

outcomes.narrative:
"Okay, yeah, okay," the guard nods, finally accepting the inevitable. You tell him it's not so bad being a part of something bigger than himself, and the Orchid bruisers slowly release him from the wall. As soon as his feet touch the ground, though, the soldier tries to make a run for it—but skewers himself on an Orchid's outstretched dagger.

"What a waste," the Sect enforcer says to you as the young soldier slumps to the ground. "Thanks for trying, anyway."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain to the Sect enforcers that it's not too late to keep their teeth—if they let the kid go.

outcomes.narrative: You tell the Sect enforcers that their faith must be weak if they believe the city's coming salvation could be brought down by one kid. They grumble and back down, letting the guard escape with his life.
The Sect enforcers drop the soldier and turn their attention to you. The fight is short; your opponents are strong, but they're common back-alley brawlers—you kill monsters for a living.

narrative:
"The Sinking Market is sinking." A white-and-brown Vermling stands in your path as you travel north to the Boiler's District. She speaks with authority, wearing a rough robe and a long, drooping necklace made of copper wire and thick-braided horsetail. You tell her that the Sinking Market is supposed to be sinking—that's why it's in the name—and there's nothing you could do about it anyway.

But the Vermling shakes her head. She explains that large, deep pits have begun to suddenly open along the market, swallowing shoppers and even entire merchants' stalls. "We hear a grinding and a rumble from below, and then the earth swallows us," the Vermling says. "We from the gutters can't pay, but you must help."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help and descend into one of the sinkholes to investigate.

outcomes.narrative: You climb to the bottom of a sinkhole, where you discover a wide, freshly-dug tunnel. You follow it to the end, where you find a group of earth demons digging toward the West Barracks. They turn and charge, and you're forced to kill them before they grind you into the tunnel floor.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Get the city guards to do it instead.

outcomes.narrative:
"Can't pay" is your least favorite trait in a potential client. The guards are paid to protect the city-let them handle it. You approach the officer in charge of the military presence in the Sinking Market.

The officer groans dramatically. "I can't," he whines, "but you look like a hearty bunch. Can I just pay you to handle this?"

"Can't pay" is your least favorite trait in a potential client. The guards are paid to protect the city-let them handle it. You approach the officer in charge of the military presence in the Sinking Market.

The officer puts up a fuss, but eventually admits that yes, it is his job to investigate. He dispatches a small crew of soldiers, who return with reports that the sinkholes were caused by earth demons digging a tunnel toward the West Barracks. You don't get paid, but at least you didn't have to get your hands dirty.

narrative:
The alarm bells blare across the watchtowers, and the citizenry look around in confusion. Before you can assess, a panting town guard recruit on crutches comes rushing up to you. "True Shields! True Shields!" He gulps air between sentences.

"It is you, thank the Oak! First Shield Harmon and Spymaster Argeise and... well, basically everyone are out on annual training. And—and we're under attack from Inox warbands! It's such terrible timing!"

You suspect this is no mere coincidence... the Inox you've met in the wilds are cunning enough to know exactly when Gloomhaven will be at its most vulnerable.

"I saw what your group did at the Battle for Gloomhaven. Can you assume command of the troops? Without your help, I fear we'll be overrun!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Yes, we'll lead the remaining army.

outcomes.narrative:
You rush to the city walls and see an Inox warband mounted atop sturdy garralevs ready to breach the Northern Gate. Only twenty guards were left behind while the others train. They range from expert marksmen to those too infirm to join the field exercises.

"True Shields!" an exhausted runner sputters out. "We spotted a smaller force massing outside the Western Gate—it may be a surprise attack!" You'll need to divide the forces to defend the city.
effects: Read %game.section:5.1%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Surely the army can do the one thing it's supposed to do on its own. Refuse to help.

outcomes.narrative: You've done more than your share of defending Gloomhaven already. You head to the Sleeping Lion, content to let the professionals handle it. It takes a week to clean up after the attack breaches the walls, but at least you're not nursing wounds.
effects: Until the next scenario is completed, no character may buy or sell any item, enhance a card, or retire.

narrative:
You're walking in the Sinking Market looking for possible work when you're approached by a dirty-looking boy. He's given you leads in the past on a number of mercenary jobs.

"I need some help, and I really don't know who else to turn to," he begins. "All of us here in the Sinking Market are in a bad way. Our houses are collapsing, our water is foul, and we don't even have enough money for food.

"We're dying here, and the city is doing nothing to help us. You have friends in high places in the Merchant's Guild, right? They own this whole area. Please, there has to be someone you can talk to."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Talk to the highest ranking people you know on the Merchant's Guild about revitalizing the area.

outcomes.narrative: You head to the Coin District and meet with a member of the Merchant's Guild you've had dealings with before. He looks at you skeptically, but says he will see what he can do about making the area more livable.
Every merchant you try to talk to about the issue laughs you out of the room. Why help others when there is no profit in it for them?

options.label: B
options.narrative: Offer to put the boy up in better accommodations on your own dime.

outcomes.narrative: You can't do much politically for the boy, but you have the funds to bankroll him yourself. You put him and his mother up in better housing in the Boiler's District. It's not as safe as you'd like, but at least he won't have to deal with flooding anymore. Maybe these little acts can make a difference.
You can't bankroll his life, but you do what you can to help him out of the rut he's in. While he hoped for more, he thanks you for the help you provide.

narrative:
You're passing through the Sinking Market when you see a stallworker point you out at a distance to some inquiring guards. The group rushes over to confront you.

"You there! Halt! Lay down your weapons." The guards look visibly jittery, and one thumbs the pommel of his sword, looking for an excuse to draw it. "By order of the town guard, you're under arrest for conspiracy against Gloomhaven, sedition, and accusations of treason."

Great. Trumped up charges thanks to not playing by the town guard's rules.

options.label: A
options.narrative: A guard's only as loyal as his last paycheck. Pay off the guards.

outcomes.condition: Lose 20 Collective Gold (Or 10 gold if %game.trait:persuasive% or Military reputation > 9)
outcomes.narrative: You offer to pay your fines right now, without involving that messy judicial system. The guards agree and quickly pocket the money.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Follow the guard's instructions.

outcomes.narrative: You turn yourself in to the mercy of the guards. It takes several days locked up in the Ghost Fortress before your case is heard, and even then, it takes everything you have to convince the council members reviewing your file that there isn't sufficient evidence to convict you. By the time you're released a week later, the guards are having a good chuckle. Seems they've "misplaced" some of your coinage.
effects: Each character loses half their gold.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Run for it.

outcomes.narrative: You shove the foremost guard to the ground and take off sprinting. You're able to lose them in the crowded streets, for now.
effects: Place this card back on top of the city deck.
Place it one card deeper for each instance of either trait you have.

narrative:
You're walking down an alley following a successful evening at the Sleeping Lion when you spot him: a figure shrouded in darkness blocking your path. The Quatryl calls out an ominous greeting in a haunting tone:

"There is no justice in this world but that borne from power. The Merchant's Guild sought your aid, and you spurned it. You have displeased power, and it is lashing out, with me as its imperfect instrument."

He clicks a device strapped to his wrist and the alleyway crackles with blue energy. In long, impossible steps, the figure launches forward, vanishing mid-stride only to appear again and again, hundreds of times, as a kaleidoscope of himself. The sequence is impossible to track, each step an eruption of blue lightning. In a final flash he is upon you, twin daggers drawn and angled at your throat.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Fight the Merchant's Guild bounty hunter.

outcomes.narrative:
"Do not lament your position, for you are playing your role, just as the Guild does. Power is a fearful place, as it must protect itself, lest it lose all it has. Your existence challenges power, and balance must be restored."

The fight lasts just a few seconds, but it feels like fending off an army's worth of attacks, dagger strikes slashing you repeatedly. With a crackle of final energy, the alleyway goes quiet. You hear a voice reverberate from the rooftops: "The Guild fears that which it cannot control. Until you meet my blades again..."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Attempt to reason with the Merchant's Guild bounty hunter.

outcomes.narrative: You shout something about his contract being outdated, and he gives pause, looking down at the device on his wrist. "My apologies. Time is difficult for me to track, and I fear you are correct: my endeavor is past necessity. It serves no purpose to murder you today. An example need not be made."
You offer to pay off your own bounty to avoid the fight. "Power can be fear, flesh, or funds. Can you afford the price to restore balance?"
effects: You may pay 5 collective gold per reputation with the Merchants Guild below 3 you have.

narrative:
Ever since the new leadership was installed, there have been grumblings. Sure, the streets are safer. There's a quiet peace, and no one is willing to speak up for fear of toppling the precarious instability it rests on. Crime is down, and most folks are indoors before dark. But there are grumblings.

You're contributing today's wages to the Sleeping Lion when you overhear them: newcomers talking in hushed tones at the next table. It's only snippets, but you're certain you hear the words "silent" and "rebellion," followed by some furtive glances around the room. No one else seems to have noticed.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Make it clear that speaking up against the leadership isn't welcome here.

outcomes.narrative: You walk up to their table with a disarming smile, then kick the table into the stomach of the man on the far side. In no uncertain terms, you describe how this bar helped put the very leadership they're plotting against into power, and you'll stop at nothing to protect it. The dissidents cast terrified looks amongst themselves, bolting for the exit at the first sign you'll let them leave without a beating.
effects: Gain 1 reputation with the ruling faction.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Present yourself as sympathetic to their plight.

outcomes.narrative:
You order a round of juniper ale and hand-deliver it to their table. They're instantly suspicious, but after a few hours of talking (and a few more rounds on your tab), they give each other careful looks and test the waters:

"We're assembling a team of people... people interested in taking back power for the citizens of Gloomhaven. There's a man named Loop, he's been organizing a resistance—I think he'd like to meet you. You seem like good people, the kind of people Gloomhaven was founded by. Will you join us?"

You nod, and plans begin in earnest.

"The silent will have a voice."

narrative:
It's taken weeks of effort and trust building, but you've finally ingrained yourself in the resistance cell plotting to strike back at the government. You settle into your seats in a basement under a bakery as the leader, a Valrath by the name of "Loop," addresses the rag-tag gathering before him.

"We have lived under the yoke of oppression, docile cogs in a machine that exists to grind us to our bones and discard the dust. Our masters care not whether we live or die, merely that we comply. No more." The speaker looks to be barely out of his teenage years, but speaks with an impassioned fury.

"There is no value to life except that which is put towards a worthy cause. For some, our choices today will call for payment on those lives, but know that for each of us that falls, it will be a life well spent. We are the resistance. We are the silent, and the silent have a voice. We will reclaim Gloomhaven for all who come after us! Sleep well, we strike at dawn."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Rise up against the oppressive leadership of Gloomhaven.

outcomes.narrative: The first strike is waved off as an inconvenience, but as the coordinated explosions begin to rock government buildings, word spreads quickly: Gloomhaven is not safe for those in power, and the citizenry have the rudder to steer the course of their lives. You can see it on faces in the town square—there is hope. There is something for the government to fear.
effects: Lose 2 reputation with the ruling faction. Gain 1 reputation with each other faction.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Betray the resistance to the city's rulers.

outcomes.narrative: You head out from the meeting and go immediately to your contacts in Gloomhaven's ruling class. With the information you gathered, it's a simple matter to round up the dissidents from their beds before the morning strike, allowing the citizenry to sleep soundly for another day, none the wiser of the threat to the safety of the city. The silent have been silenced.
effects: Gain 2 reputation with the ruling faction.

narrative:
You've returned to the cramped basement below a local bakery that has been taken over by the self-styled "silent resistance," a group of Gloomhaven citizens that are rising up against the government. Before you sits Loop, a young Valrath with piercing gold eyes and a charisma that motivates the people to action.

"They have the money, the men, the power. But we have righteousness. We have chaos. And we have you." Loop gestures at a map of Gloomhaven on the wall.

"There is a weak point in the lifeblood of Gloomhaven. Here." His finger rests on the Silent Bridge, the one path across the Still River in Gloomhaven. "This bridge allows passage for the caravans from the capital and from all of civilization reach the wealthy of Gloomhaven. Without it, there is no route over the Still River for several days ride—the river is our greatest silent ally. But I recognize a mercenary exists to be paid: how can I reward you for your assistance in destroying the Silent Bridge?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Ask for payment, up front, in gold.

outcomes.narrative:
"Wisdom to ask for compensation up front—no one knows what tomorrow brings but change." He draws a series of marks on the map of the Silent Bridge, detailing its weak points. "The foundation of the bridge predates Gloomhaven's recent founding. It was built with the old ways, in the old fashion of permanence. We will bring it down with the power of chaos." His eyes flicker deep black, and he opens his palm to reveal a swirl of azure energy.

"They won't know what hit them."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse payment for the mission.

outcomes.narrative:
"Grace is not limited to the nobility, thank you. I assure you the resources will be put to nothing but the improvement of our home." He draws a series of marks on the map of the Silent Bridge, detailing its weak points. "The foundation of the bridge predates Gloomhaven's recent founding. It was built with the old ways, in the old fashion of permanence. We will bring it down with the power of chaos." His eyes flicker deep black, and he opens his palm to reveal a swirl of azure energy.

"They won't know what hit them."

narrative:
There was no overt, sweeping change from blowing up the Silent Bridge—a few days of chaos before reconstruction efforts began in earnest, but the difference amongst the commoners is electric. The leadership has been put in their place, and the real power of the populace has made itself known.

You step into the cramped bakery basement that houses the Silent, a rebellious group who you assisted in taking out the bridge and making the people's will known. Loop, the charismatic young Valrath that organized the effort, welcomes you with a smile and a wince. His hand remains bundled with gauze bandages, a casualty of the mission that doctors suggest will never fully heal.

"Donations continue to come, many from unlikely sources. We have more than we can spend. How would you recommend we apply our meager earnings?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Give it to us.

outcomes.narrative: Loop's gold eyes flash, leaving him with a bit of a smirk. "If I didn't know the good those hands have produced, I would take you for a scoundrel. But I know you will put coin to trouble wherever you go. Take it, and may you further give voice to those who cannot speak."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Distribute it to the unfortunate.

outcomes.narrative: With strained movement, he rises from his seat, dumping a purse of coins across the table. He speaks loudly, drawing the attention of others across the basement. "You heard these mercenaries—even when offered to line their own pockets, they seek to lift us all." He invites his followers to the table. "Take this, and spread it where needed. Let us be a force for the commoner where Gloomhaven's leadership has failed."

narrative:
"That's close enough." At just past midnight, you find yourself in an alley behind the Sleeping Lion. A hooded figure is several paces away, conveniently standing in shadow despite the moonlight. An unsigned note inexplicably appeared at your table an hour ago, addressed to "Valiant Heroes," and leading you here.

"Councilman Myte. He thinks he's above the law." The voice sounds strained, as though he's trying to mask his speech with a veil of baritone. Still, it sounds oddly familiar. "But there is evidence, if you know where to look. If you know the right questions." The figure points to a twine-wrapped package leaning against the wall, which you gingerly pick up.

"He uses them, then they disappear. You've done well for this city. There are things I know. Things I see. But I cannot be in all places. Read the package. Wield this, and govern him accordingly. I will try to get you more when I can." With that, he recedes into the shadows, heels clicking away against the cobblestones.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Let the mysterious informant depart.

outcomes.narrative: You rip open the package and find a logbook. The pages detail eight young interns working for Councilman Myte, each of which never made it to their two-month review. Clear records detail dates and times for payments, but the ledger shows the final payments were never made. You stow the book in your satchel and consider the best time to use this information.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pursue and unmask the mysterious informant.

outcomes.narrative:
If someone wants to use your services, you want to know why. He has a head start, but you close the gap to the hooded figure. You grasp at his cloak and attempt to tackle him to the ground, but he deftly twists and rolls, leaving you holding nothing but fabric. Whoever this is, they're well-trained. He smashes a vial of something into the wall beside you and a choking gas leaves you panting. When it clears, he's gone.

Waiting to regain your breath, you tear open the package he left. Inside is a logbook of records which details Councilman Myte hiring interns, then their subsequent disappearance just before they reach their third month of employment. Curious.

narrative:
After an hour of waiting in a well-appointed, overly perfumed lobby, you are invited into the working quarters of Councilman Myte. You draw the doors closed behind you as you enter, sinking into the soft kivak-leather seats. The office is warm, a pleasant fire roaring in a too-large fireplace at the side of the room.

"Please excuse the delay, my intern is new and failed to alert me. To what do I owe the pleasure of such company today? I am always willing to meet with my constituents." The plump Orchid smiles a charming smile that sends a shiver through you.

You spread the logbook showcasing the disappearances of his interns on his desk, thumbing through the pages. The color drains from his face. "Where did you get this?" He sneers, hate bubbling through him. "No—never mind. What do you want? I'll pay anything for it."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sell it to him for 30 gold.

outcomes.narrative: "This is the original, but if you have made any copies, I will assure you it is the last mistake of your lives. You will find me a pugnacious adversary." He opens a desk drawer and aggressively tosses a coin purse towards you. You take the time to count it, slowly. When all is confirmed, he snatches the logbook and casts it immediately into the fire. "Now get out of my sight!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Sell it to him for a favor for your preferred faction.

outcomes.narrative: "Yes, fine. Fine! I will see to it that your requests are effected. Now, the book—and this had best be the only copy, or you will find my reach, and my anger, knows no bounds." He snatches the logbook and casts it immediately into the fire. "Now get out of here."
effects: Gain 2 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Refuse to sell it to him—you merely want him to know you have it.

outcomes.narrative: A week later, you return to your lodging to find the room has been overturned—your belongings are scattered everywhere, and a sticky black sludge has been poured over your bedsheets. There's nothing to confirm who you owe the visit to, but you have a decent hunch. Still worth it.

narrative:
You've just come through the city gates from your latest excursion when a cautious figure starts walking in lockstep with you.

"Psst! Hey! I hear you've got something of interest on Councilman Myte. I'm a reporter for the Haven Herald."

You feign not having heard her and continue on your way—no point in leaking something to the press before you can get to the bottom of it yourself.

"Hey. Hey!" She jogs alongside you to keep up with your brisk pace. "The people have a right to know who is representing them. I've been tracking this story for weeks and all I need is the smallest bit of evidence—heck, even anonymously—so I can break this wide open. I think he's been killing his interns. Don't they deserve justice? It'll never be traced back to you."

She stops, letting you get a few feet away, then follows up with her best and final argument: "I can pay."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Accept 25 gold in exchange for the logbook of evidence.

outcomes.narrative: You open the paper the next day to read the explosive piece about Councilman Myte, but can't find it anywhere. You do find an obituary mourning the loss of a young reporter found dead in her apartment, though.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse the reporter.

outcomes.narrative: You brush the young woman off, refusing to give up your intel in pursuit of some splashy story. You'll find justice for those interns your own way.

narrative:
"Come in, friends! It's time." Your old friend-turned-councilmember invites you into their office. The room is well-appointed in a style befitting the former mercenary. "Help yourselves to anything in the cabinet, the imported Darkwater is quite nice."

You find your way over to a set of chairs, and your old friend leans in close.

"I've been doing some digging on my fellow Councilman Myte. He is scum—murderous scum, I'd wager. I've had evidence, but I haven't been able to definitively prove any of it in a way he couldn't flex his political power to get out of... until now. I've spent hundreds in gold tracking his movement, bribing anyone who ever interacted with the man. I think I know where the bodies are buried. Quite literally." You can't help but feel this sort of skullduggery truly suits the new councilmember.

"Political power is useful, but I've reached the point where I need the strength of a mercenary to finish this. I can't get my hands dirty anymore, but I could think of no one I trust more than you."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help your old friend take down Councilman Myte.

outcomes.narrative:
"If my source is correct—and they'd better be, for what I paid—there's an unmarked graveyard not far from here, in the Corpsewood. Councilman Myte makes a trip that direction every other month, which coincides directly with when he gets a new intern... and his old one goes missing. The last one was a young woman, excited for the opportunity to work for a council member. Her mother said she wore a necklace with a feather on it."

Your old friend looks away for a moment, then steels their resolve. "It's distasteful, but I need you to find her." The council member grits their teeth. "Bring a shovel."

options.label: B
options.narrative: It's been a while, so remind the esteemed councilmember that mercenaries don't work for free.

outcomes.narrative:
"Right, of course. I wouldn't dream of sending you off without an advance." You're not totally convinced the newly minted politician wasn't angling for a favor. "If my source is correct—and they'd better be, for what I paid—there's an unmarked graveyard not far from here, in the Corpsewood. Councilman Myte makes the trip that direction every other month, which coincides directly with when he gets a new intern... and his old one goes missing. The last one was a young woman, excited for the opportunity to work for a council member. Her mother said she wore a necklace with a feather on it."

Your old friend looks away for a moment, then steels their resolve. "It's distasteful, but I need you to find her." The council member grits their teeth. "Bring a shovel."

narrative:
You're heading out the city gates when you're pushed aside by some gruff-looking guards. They're cordoning off a pathway for some returning high-ranking official coming into town, and for security reasons, they won't be able to let you through until the VIP passes.

After a few minutes delay, you finally catch a glimpse: to your great surprise, it's none other than your old mercenary-friend-turned-politician. You wave and after security confirms the connection, you're granted an in-person audience.

"Friends! How is mercenary life treating you?" You recount a few quick anecdotes as aides and citizens stream past, each earning a nod or a handshake from the new councilmember. After a few moments, they drop the political veneer and it's like you're talking to your old friend again. "Tell me—I've had some difficulty really getting a handle on how Gloomhaven is faring. What's the word from the streets?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell the councilmember that life for the average citizen is hard.

outcomes.narrative:
You give a list of grievances. Your old mercenary friend takes copious notes, and it seems like they sincerely want to help. "Thank you—that grounded perspective is what I've been missing. I'll do everything I can to help."

When you finally part ways, you can't help feeling like you encountered a celebrity—one that can actually make a difference.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Tell the councilmember that taxes are too high, and it's stifling shop sales.

outcomes.narrative:
You explain that the taxation of the merchants has prevented them from making enough profit to bring new goods into town, and everything for sale has grown stale. The council member takes copious notes, and it seems like they sincerely want to help. "Thank you—that grounded perspective is what I've been missing. I'll do everything I can to help."

When you finally part ways, you can't help feeling like you encountered a celebrity—one that can actually make a difference. You've just started on your journey when a mousy council aide catches up to you, panting. "Excuse me! The council member asked that I get this your way immediately!" It's a wrapped box with a note from your old friend.

It reads: "Let's each make Gloomhaven better our own way."

narrative:
You head to the Sinking Market, hoping to find some cheap supplies, when you are surprised to see a crowd gathered in the distance. You push your way through and see a host of dead bodies in the street, covered in insects and strange pustules on their skin.

Nearby, a woman screams in terror and runs away. Other more curious onlookers inch closer, trying to get a better view of the grotesque scene.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Help dispose of the corpses as quickly as possible.

outcomes.narrative:
You ward everyone away while you load the bodies onto a cart, take them outside the city, and burn them. You return to a group of guards who don't appreciate disposing of dead bodies before they can investigate them.

You wash and manage to pass for clean. Well, at least as clean as normal.

You ward everyone away while you load the bodies onto a cart, take them outside the city, and burn them. You return to a group of guards who don't appreciate disposing of dead bodies before they can investigate them.

Hours later, you find an odd growth on your arm. Lancing the pustule produces a murky liquid that reeks of sewage. It passes, but not soon enough.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Investigate the corpses.

outcomes.narrative:
You approach the corpses with morbid fascination. The number of insects is alarming, as are the diseased sores.

You call out an invitation to the skittering creatures covering the corpses. The assembled crowd watches in horror as they skitter up your cloak and into your being. Consumption never felt so good.

You approach the corpses with morbid fascination. The number of insects is alarming, as are the diseased sores.

The disease spreads throughout the Sinking Market, killing many more people. Supplies grow scarce.
effects: Until you successfully complete a scenario, the cost of purchasing all items is increased by 5 gold.

narrative:
You enter the grand foyer of the Wayward Inn to visit your old friend-turned-Innkeeper, but are met with an unfamiliar face at the reception desk. A well-dressed Vermling sits cross-legged, a pen in hand as she completes some paperwork. She greets you with a smile as you approach.

"Oh, hello! Welcome to the newest—and finest—establishment in Gloomhaven. Do you have a reservation?" You explain that you're just there to visit the innkeeper, who you used to adventure with.

"Oh! You must be the mercenaries! Boss hasn't been around the last few days. Went to go convince the people at Crossroads Station to send people our way instead of to those big, established inns." With a snap of her fingers, she pulls a sealed envelope from under the desk. "Boss did say to give you this if you came around." You tear open the envelope.

"Went to Crossroads Station. Something's wrong out there. If you're reading this, it went bad. Come find me."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell the Vermling concierge what's going on.

outcomes.narrative:
"Oh, so it's a rescue op?" The Vermling swivels around in her chair. "Probably want the mission room, then." She pulls a lever under the reception desk, and the wall to your right slides open, revealing a veritable armory of weapons and equipment hidden behind an ordinary-looking wall. "Boss is a little... cautious. Still keeps some weird hobbies. Guess you can't take the mercenary out of a person, really."

Across the wall is a blueprint for something you haven't seen before. The Vermling concierge sees your interest. "Boss was working on that, says it'll be pretty great when it's finished. You're welcome to it if you think it'll help. Just bring Boss back safely, yeah?"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Don't alarm the Vermling concierge with your concerns.

outcomes.narrative:
You thank the Vermling concierge for her time and avoid hinting that anything is amiss. "Thanks for stopping in. I'll let Boss know you stopped by."

If your old friend needs help, you'll answer the call.

narrative:
In the middle of an intersection stands an older gentleman, frantically pawing through maps of the area, a heavy canvas bag on his hip. He finally decides on a direction, only to stop a few steps in to re-evaluate. He's getting nowhere, and none of the passersby seem interested in getting tangled up with whatever is troubling him.

He makes eye contact with you and tries again. "Excuse me, my delegation is arriving soon and I am supposed to secure housing. I was told to go to the Wayward Inn in the Traveler's District, but I can't find it for the life of me. Could you give me directions?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Direct him to the Wayward Inn.

outcomes.narrative: The Wayward Inn, owned by none other than the Greymare family, isn't hard to find, even for someone who hasn't visited Gloomhaven before. It's the most prominent structure in the Traveler's District, with a purple roof that crests high over other buildings to ensure a guest's view by a wide margin. You direct the old man northward and he gives a thankful sigh of relief, handing over a few coins for the trouble.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Encourage him to go to a new inn run by an old friend of yours instead.

outcomes.narrative:
It's an opportunity to support your friend's new business, so you'll take time out of your day to help make a sale. You walk the gentleman over to your old adventuring partner's inn, assuring him it'll be a much better—and more cost effective—alternative for him and his guests.

"Thank you, truly. I've seen so many neer-do-wells in my time, I felt I was surely going to be accosted any moment. I appreciate the kindness—and you said you knew the proprietor of this establishment? They're trustworthy? I have a delegation of twelve coming in from Keyport, so we'll need a number of rooms..."

narrative:
A sickly looking Valrath with a long scar along his neck sits down at your table at the Sleeping Lion, uninvited. His hands are calloused and you can see the hilt of a dagger up his sleeve.

"Hm, hello. I am looking for an associate of mine. Word is that they were seen in this bar. Perhaps you know them? They would be carrying a card. A black card. Hm?" You don't like where this is going.

"If you have seen my associate, I would be very thankful. Very thankful, hm? We have been looking for this associate for some time, and I will be finding them soon. My friendship can be lucrative. You know this, hm?"

If they're this close, it won't be long before the Sin-Ra Syndicate discovers the holder of the Black Card, and the penalty for betrayal is death.

The holder of the Black Card decides:

options.label: A
options.narrative: Kill the Sin-Ra Syndicate member.

outcomes.narrative:
You invite the Sin-Ra Syndicate member outside for a more clandestine discussion. As soon as you've stepped into the alley, you spring the attack, ending him quickly. You find a note with instructions laying out your worst fears:

"Traitor has been traced to the Sleeping Lion. Likely posing as a mercenary to avoid detection. Find and execute. The Sin-Ra leaves no survivors."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Reveal yourself to the Sin-Ra Syndicate member.

outcomes.narrative:
You look to the other members of your party, drawing the Black Card out and setting it on the table. For such a simple object, it feels so very heavy. There is a moment of calm before the Valrath lunges at you with his dagger.

The technique is familiar, though, and the ambush unsurprising. You deflect and smash his head against the tabletop. With a hiss he tries to grasp at you, but a kick under the table sends him backwards into a passing patron. Never the locale to turn down a bar fight, the Sleeping Lion erupts into chaos, and in the ensuing commotion, your Valrath attacker conveniently finds a dagger in his belly. There won't be anyone to report back to his masters in the Sin-Ra, but the cover is clumsy, and word will still travel. You'll need to go deeper underground.
effects: Increase the number of side scenarios you need to complete for your personal quest to 7 (note it on your character sheet).

narrative:
Most of the time, staying under the notice of the city's populace is the best course of action, but a little bit of information can go a long way to putting your mind at ease. You decide to take the risk of visiting a Sin-Ra gathering to gather intelligence. Sleeper cells are disconnected, so it's unlikely anyone would recognize another member on sight, and your Black Card should be all the proof necessary for admittance.

You knock at the door of a disused butcher shop in the Boiler's District. A suspicious eye appears at the peephole, and you flash your Black Card. Satisfied, the old iron door swings open to let you into a room filled with a variety of individuals from all walks of life, each agents of the Sin-Ra awaiting activation.

Conversation is easy, and it seems everyone's guard is down. Eventually, the topic shifts to rumors. "I heard a cell was murdered, their Black Card stolen," one loose-tongued woman says. "Sounds like a bounty will be set soon."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Keep your cover and shift the topic to other matters.

outcomes.narrative: You deftly steer the conversation to other topics, including any aspects of matters outside the city. Some loose lips give a great lead, and you slip back out with the Sin-Ra none the wiser.
effects: Unlock a random side scenario.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Attempt to throw them off your trail.

outcomes.narrative: You share that you heard the imposter was a red-headed brawler with a mohawk, and everyone agrees to keep an eye out for them. That should keep them nicely off your trail.

You try to explain that you heard the imposter was traveling with a group of mercenaries, mercenaries that look very unlike the ones you're here with tonight. The explanation results in some raised eyebrows, and you make your way out of the meeting shortly thereafter.

narrative:
It's midnight. A knock on your door rouses you from sleep.

You open it to find a familiar face you'd assumed long dead: your old friend, who is working to take down the Sin-Ra Syndicate. They touch a finger to their lips, letting out a slight, "Shh." You invite them inside and shut the door behind them.

They pull down a black hood and give a half-smile at the sight of you. Rather than relish the moment, though, they return to the task at hand. "It's time—we have to strike tonight. The Grand Vizier of the Sin-Ra Syndicate is coming to Gloomhaven this very evening. We won't have another chance. Will you help me cut off the snake's head?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help your friend.

outcomes.narrative: "The Sin-Ra works as a series of sleeper cells, each isolated from the others. It's how this Black Card let me access so many places—each unit is blind to the workings of the others. But even a network as dispersed as this requires leadership... and that is the Grand Vizier. This very night, he will arrive from White Oak, and I will end his life. It is our last chance."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Agree, then betray your friend to the Sin-Ra.

outcomes.narrative:
You agree to help your old friend, setting a time to meet later that night. You let them get well out of sight, then take the opportunity to knock on the door of the secret hideout and alert them. A few words is all it takes to give them warning of the impending attack.

The next morning, a beggar woman shows up at your door. She wordlessly licks her lips and sets a heavy bag of coin in your palm. You can't help but notice the pouch is stained with blood.

narrative:
"Yes, well then. There is the small matter of the tontine." An actuary sits across the table from you, shuffling through paperwork and looking truly out of place in the Sleeping Lion's back booth. "Your... ahem, your 'friend' in the Sin-Ra insisted that you be listed as the beneficiary. And as best as I can determine, they were the final surviving member, having outlasted all other participants in their little... club." He raises an eyebrow.

"You are familiar with tontines, yes? All participants pay in towards a common annuity, and the final proceeds are awarded to the surviving member. It is in my best interests to not question how the final result is made, merely to report its veracity."

He folds his hands. "The tontine proceeds are 50 gold, one for each ahem... exhausted member." He sets a rather large leather sack on the table.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Take the money.

outcomes.narrative: You thank the actuary for bringing you such good fortune. It's not often that losing a friend is so lucrative. "Be well, and please keep my card. I also offer exemplary mortician services." He tips his hat and leaves you to count your prize.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse the money.

outcomes.narrative: He packs his paperwork into a leather briefcase. "Yes, well, I understand the subject matter may be distasteful. You are not the first next-of-kin to refuse, of course. In such instances, I will see to it that the funds are put towards the common good." He stands, tipping his hat. "Good day to you, and my apologies for the intrusion."

options.label: C
options.narrative: Ask to establish a tontine between your current party.

outcomes.narrative: "You want to set up a tontine between just the people at this table? I would be honored to assist. Here are the funds you've earned, and I'll draw up the new paperwork."
effects: Collectively choose an amount of gold. Each character that wants to participate in the tontine pays that amount. Mark your participation and total amount paid on your character sheet. When all other participating characters have retired, the last remaining participating character receives the combined total of gold paid by all participating characters.

narrative:
You decide to unwind at the Sleeping Lion, but just as you start to relax, a bear of a man crashes into your table, scattering your drinks across the floor.

Towering over him is a massive Inox. "What did you say about my horns?" the Inox shouts.

The man stands up and brushes shards of glass from his tunic. "I just said I mistook you for a Valrath... barely even noticed the third one. Puny, isn't it?"

The Inox roars and charges headlong into the man, crashing through more tables in the process. At this, the entire tavern erupts into violence. After all, when someone is deep into drink, the last thing you want to do is knock that drink over.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Join the fray!

outcomes.narrative: You break a chair over a man's back, kick him in the teeth, and then you really get into it. It's a bar brawl that could only be described as "epic".
You jump into the melee, breaking heads and chairs in equal measure. You've seen worse brawls, but the proprietor still isn't happy when the dust settles.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Take the opportunity to lighten some purses.

outcomes.narrative: You selectively acquire a handful of coins from some unsuspecting or unconscious people. Even after tipping the proprietor, it was a fruitful night.
You try to snatch a coin purse off a drunk merchant, but he grabs your arm.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Do your best to stop the fighting in this respectable establishment.

outcomes.narrative: You start to calm the patrons, but one clocks you in the jaw. Oh well, you gave peace a chance.
You manage to calm down the Inox and buy off the rest of the room with some extra drinks. The proprietor breathes a sigh of relief.

narrative:
"Lean in, let me show you how Orchids store memories. You tell me if it's worth a drink." An Orchid drags his knuckles across the tabletop in the Sleeping Lion, knocking the grime off a prominent crystal jutting out of the back of his hand. With a calm twist, he snaps it off, rubbing it back and forth between his fingertips. He draws it towards his mouth, exhaling a low, baritone note as he concentrates on the crystal. If the room wasn't dark, you wouldn't notice it, but at the edges of your vision you see an erratic motion of light swirling its way into the crystal like water circling the drain. His eyes snap open, the endowment complete. He drops the crystal on the table between you with a surprising clatter.

"Memories start ragged, like that. Ruminate on them long enough, and you'll polish your memory to perfect clarity." He lays a strand of small spherical pebbles on the table, strung together on a loop of string. "It's good for reflecting. Orchids call them a 'cobble,' a set of worry-beads made from their own memories of triumphs and failures."

He sees your fascination. "Tell you what. You buy the next round, and you can each have one."

options.narrative:
Each character may choose individually:

Option A: Ask for a memory of perseverance.

Option B: Ask for a memory of serenity.

outcomes.narrative: He snaps the thin string on his cobble, and the memory crystals roll across the table. He scoops them up gently, sorting them into each of your hands.
"Hope they're worth as much to you as the next round is to me."

narrative:
The stage in the town square is being prepared for tomorrow's event: an archery contest. The winner will need to fire an arrow through the gaps in twelve lined-up axe heads, with lesser prizes for those unable to make the impossible shot. In the decade the competition has gone on, not a single person has ever managed the feat—but the crowds show up anyway, eager to watch the attempts and enjoy the offerings of the vendors who support the festival. You're looking forward to trying your skill—and your luck—tomorrow.

You walk by after dark as the organizers install the last of the axe heads, ensuring with a long slender pole that there's a true path through. When they're finally satisfied, they throw a canvas sheet over the setup, packing in for the night. Other than your presence, the town square is now quiet for the evening.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Take a test shot in preparation for tomorrow's competition.

outcomes.narrative: You pull back the canvas sheet and notch an arrow—you draw the bow, hold your breath steady, and let loose. The arrow sails through four axes before ricocheting to the ground. Not bad, and the practice gives you a good idea of what to expect tomorrow.
effects: Read %game.section:36.3% and you succeed on one axe head you'd otherwise fail.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Go home to get a good night's rest for the competition.

outcomes.narrative: You hurry to bed and get a good night's sleep, dreaming of a clean shot through the axe heads. You wake up refreshed and ready to win this competition.
effects: Read %game.section:36.3% and gain advantage on your first draw.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Sabotage the axe setup slightly to ensure no one will win.

outcomes.narrative: Given the precision with which these axes have been installed in the stage, it's a small matter to nudge a few out of position. No one will be able to land a clean shot tomorrow.
effects: Read %game.section:89.3%.

narrative:
Harrowers are a rare sight, both outside of Gloomhaven and within. Which explains why you are a bit surprised to see three Harrowers in ornate robes step cautiously off a barge onto the dock. The dockworkers look wary, bordering on concerned.

"We have come from across the sea for the spices we require," one chitters at you. "Can you direct us to the appropriate merchant? We will pay for your escort."

A bit caught off guard, you ask about the specific kind of spice. It extends an arm, a beetle dancing across the cuff of its robe. The movement... is it trying to describe the spice through motion? After a moment, the Harrower sees it is failing to communicate and makes a series of frustrated hisses.

"It is very important, and difficult to describe. We will know when it is present."

You could bring them to the Sinking Market across town, which would have common spices at good prices. Or you could bring them to the New Market for high-end luxury, foreign, and exotic goods.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Escort the Harrowers to the Sinking Market.

outcomes.narrative: If they've come all this way, it's likely for something uncommon to them but common to you—to the Sinking Market it is. After wandering the stalls for nearly an hour, they spot it: powdered axenuts! They give you a tip for the trouble, and you're happy to move on.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Escort the Harrowers to the New Market.

outcomes.narrative: If there's a place that would have the unique fare they're looking for, it's the exotic offerings of the New Market. Unfortunately, after great effort and a lot of dirty looks, you can't locate the spice they're looking for, and the sight of the Harrowers is driving off legitimate business. Everyone is happy when you direct them to the Sinking Market, and the Harrowers tip you for the trouble.

options.label: C
options.narrative: (Cannot be selected)

outcomes.narrative: If they've come all this way, it's likely for something uncommon to them but common to you—to the Sinking Market it is. You share a portion of your bugs and commune consciousnesses. With a direct line into their mind, you quickly determine the spice they're looking for is a powdered form of axenuts: simple to find, and a healthy tip for you.

narrative:
Some days you're swinging an axe against great evil, and some days you're extracting a bug infestation from a humble home in the Boiler's District. Today is unfortunately the latter.

The smoke bomb wasn't cheap, but with the insects stunned, it makes for easy cleanup. You hold your breath and work in shifts, entering the house and sweeping out the insects. When the job is done, you wind up with a decent pile of them loaded into a wooden crate. The homeowner thanks you for your time and happily pays your fee.

The bugs are starting to stir from their gas-nap, but it'll probably be another hour before they're fully awake. The question is, what to do with a box full of bugs?

options.label: A
options.narrative: Release them.

outcomes.narrative: You open the crate and release it just outside the home. You can't help but notice several of the bugs crawling right back inside. No harm in repeat business.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Try to convince a bartender it's a sleeping Harrower and stiff it with the tab.

outcomes.narrative: You walk into the Brown Door, a seedy dive bar in the Old Docks. Your "Harrower" friend generously orders several rounds for everyone present—it's a phenomenal evening. The last time you see the crate full of bugs, it's being hit on by a very tipsy woman.
After a few minutes of unconvincing excuses, you're forced to pay your tab and are thrown out. You leave the crate in the street and wander on your way.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Eat them.

outcomes.narrative: You select the best of the crate's offerings for consumption. Juicy, fat insects are the perfect way to bulk up. Delicious!
The crunch of exoskeleton is deeply unsettling. It's made worse as you suddenly remember the dusty, dirty state of the home you just drove these out of. Disgusting.

narrative:
As you return to town after your latest adventure, First Shield Harmon approaches and gestures you to the side of the road.

"I'm embarrassed to admit this," they begin in a low voice, "but we could really use some help. With all the goings-on recently and very little support from the capital, the city guard is lacking in both equipment and training for the new recruits."

In an effort to explain, they go into altogether too much detail about deficiencies in staffing that have led to some particularly weak defenses.

Harmon looks you over. "Everyone knows you're experienced warriors. Anything you could do to help the situation would be greatly appreciated."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help the city guard.

outcomes.narrative: You spend the afternoon reviewing the city's defense plans, ultimately putting together a new training regimen. The guards go home that night exhausted from the additional drills, but the leadership is very pleased with your contribution.
You spend the day training the new recruits. By the time the sun goes down, their skills are much improved, and they're grateful to you for the help.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Decline to help and instead sell this information to the Merchants.

outcomes.narrative: The Merchant's Guild is eager to hear about the problem spots of the city guard. "Politically, this is valuable. There is also the matter of evading some of the more cumbersome taxes... Thank you for bringing this to us."

options.label: C
options.narrative: Decline to help and instead sell this information to the Sect.

outcomes.narrative: You secretly contact a known member of the Sect and provide the information. He listens intently, finally turning over a handful of coins in thanks. "We will use this well, siblings."

narrative:
Nearly two thousand years ago, humans crawled out of the caves near what is now White Oak and found the Great Oak, a powerful tree that has protected the peoples of the world ever since. A bough of that original tree has been brought to Gloomhaven for a one-of-a-kind reason.

A man barks at the crowd in a White Oak accent. "Behind me is the Void: the swirling mass of black dust that consumes all who dare enter it." To demonstrate the Void's effects, he tosses a metal ball past the orange safety line. It disintegrates on contact, vaporized to sparkles of light.

"Today, we intend to use this sacred branch, one of the earliest objects on this continent we can definitively date, to perform a test of arcane comparative dating, and in so doing, accurately and definitively measure the origin year of this maelstrom!"

A man beside you leans in and offers a wager: "Fifteen gold says the Great Oak's older than the Void."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Refuse the bet: the original Great Oak must be older than the Void.

outcomes.narrative:
The lead scientist steps up as close to the Void as good sense dictates, visibly nervous. Two Orchids step beside him and link hands, emitting a high-pitched tone that channels the arcane energies. After a few moments, they seem to settle on an appropriate frequency, at which time a Savvas joins their midst, carrying the sacred branch. With the ritualistic setup complete, a swirl of white light emerges from the Savvas' chest, encircling the group. The Orchids' harmony reaches an ear-piercing crescendo, and the bough of the Sacred Oak tree lifts of its own accord out of the Savvas' hands into the air. It is suspended for just a moment before it fires with impossible speed into the swirling blackness of the Void, disintegrating on contact as all things do.

"We have the results! To my impossible surprise, the Void and the Great Oak are exactly the same age!" The crowd gasps. "More research will be required!"

The man beside you shrugs. "Meh, just happy I don't owe you 15 gold."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Take the bet: the Great Oak can't be that old.

outcomes.narrative:
The lead scientist steps up as close to the Void as good sense dictates, visibly nervous. Two Orchids step beside him and link hands, emitting a high-pitched tone that channels the arcane energies. After a few moments, they seem to settle on an appropriate frequency, at which time a Savvas joins their midst, carrying the sacred branch. With the ritualistic setup complete, a swirl of white light emerges from the Savvas' chest, encircling the group. The Orchids' harmony reaches an ear-piercing crescendo, and the bough of the Sacred Oak tree lifts of its own accord out of the Savvas' hands into the air. It is suspended for just a moment before it fires with impossible speed into the swirling blackness of the Void, disintegrating on contact as all things do.

"We have the results! To my impossible surprise, the Void and the Great Oak are exactly the same age!" The crowd gasps. "More research will be required!"

The man beside you shrugs. "Well, I suppose I lost, since it isn't technically older. I thought the Oak was the oldest thing there is. Fine, take your money."

narrative:
You're checking the bounty board in the military barracks for any new prospects when a group of new recruits filter past you, heading into a classroom. Curious, you peek inside and snatch an agenda off the table—it looks like a series of lectures on combat scheduled throughout the day.

Spymaster Argeise sees you thumbing through the paperwork and approaches you. "Mercenaries, eh? If you want, you can stay for the seminar. Might learn a thing or two." She leans in, "unless you think you're too good for that. Maybe you think you could teach this class yourself?"

You look at the other lecturers at the front of the room—they look like seasoned veterans, likely masters of their craft.

"Well?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Stay for the lectures as a student.

outcomes.narrative: The class runs until well past dark. While you're left sore from the spartan wooden seating, your mind is racing with the techniques, methods, and tactics the lecturers presented throughout the day. You make mental note of as much as you can, eager to practice your learnings on your next adventure.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Accept Argeise's challenge and give a lesson of your own.

outcomes.narrative:
You deliver a rousing explanation of combat mechanics peppered with real-world examples the other lecturers could only hope to experience. The audience is engrossed, and by the time you cede the floor, you feel a bit sorry for the presenter that has to follow you. Even when the audience erupts in applause, Argeise merely rolls her eyes, refusing to acknowledge your presentation skills.

"Don't let it go to your head, these soldiers are so green, they'd find the pommel of a sword fascinating. Anyway, here's payment for your presentation."

You attempt to speak to the class about your recent adventures, but they can tell you're about as experienced as they are. After a few minutes of fumbling, you wrap up your presentation and quickly make an exit.

narrative:
Hail, your Aesther friend, called you to her home in the Crooked Bone for an unexpected lecture. She scrawls a semi-circle of chalk on the dusty floor as she enters the second hour explaining the interconnectedness of the universe to you.

"...which means there are fifty-five known planes of this type. And each one has its own nexus in each of the other worlds. Get it?" You do not, and much of the vocabulary is going over your head.

"So this?" She holds up what looks like a standard pair of boots. "This is a nexus. It's a physical link to another plane in our world. Took ages to find one. They could be anything. A ring, a green gem, a rock... anything. Anyway, this one's boots."

She sets them in the middle of the chalk design she's stenciled, finally getting to the decision she summoned you for. "If we destroy it, we close the doorway to another plane. Not a big deal for an Aesther to go around, but sure would stop most unwelcome visitors in their tracks."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Reducing opportunities for interplanar interlopers makes everyone safer: destroy the boots.

outcomes.narrative:
You join hands with Hail and follow her lead. To your surprise, the destruction of the nexus takes little more than linking hands, some scrawled chalk outlines, chanting incantations in a tongue you don't understand, and watching a pair of boots disintegrate into a sparkle of dust.

"Whew, I don't think we're going to miss access to a random plane of wind!" She claps her hands, turning to other tasks. You can't help but feel a sense of dread—who benefits from making it harder for visitors to come to your plane?
effects: Aesther starts the next scenario with %game.condition.curse%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Offer to keep the boots and personally guard the nexus instead.

outcomes.narrative:
"Oh, you're no fun. Do you have any idea how long it took me to find these? So many mercenaries. Like, a lot of mercenaries. I even paid some of them in advance!" She's losing you, but continues anyway.

"If someone else found our plane's nexus, they'd smash it in a heartbeat, let me tell you. Assuming they understand dimensional fragility and can channel a fulguration matrix. And good luck inventing those for another couple millennia, right?" She laughs, then sees your blank stares. With a roll of her eyes she gives up. "Sure, fine. Take 'em. See if I care."

narrative:
The dock foreman hired you as protection while he breaks bad news to the gathered crowd of twenty dockworkers. "I'm just gonna say it: I know I'm two weeks behind, but I don't have your money. Margins were tight, then we got stiffed on a job, and... there just isn't anything to pay you with!"

Seeing the angry looks on their faces, you wonder whether the fifteen gold you received up front is worth it. That's when you spot someone you recognize in the crowd: your old friend the Bruiser. They must be earning some side money working the incoming ships. A voice shouts from the back: "What about those mercenaries? You had the money to pay them with the money you owe us?!"

The foreman stammers out a reply: "There's no money, just some for necessary expenses-"

"Protecting your hide from all of us is necessary, huh? I consider my own family pretty necessary!" The dockworkers push forward to take their money in coin or blood. This is not going well.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Stand your ground and fight.

outcomes.narrative: You stand your ground, and a few cracked jaws later, they've fallen back, still full of fire, but not willing to take a beating just to shout up-close. You get the foreman to safety, but not before locking eyes with the Bruiser, who could not look more furious at you.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

outcomes.narrative: You try to hold off the swarming crowd, but it's to no avail. What hurts more than the physical pain, though, is you're almost certain you saw your old friend the Bruiser's fist coming your way. The blows come quickly, and when they've had their fill, you're left with a ringing in your ears. Your employer is bloody, but thankfully alive. You drag him to safety and vow not to cross the dockworkers again.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Offer the dockworkers your earnings.
