outcomes.narrative: "See? Even your bodyguards know wrong when they see it!" The dock foreman looks ashamed as you pass out the few coins you earned, but it's not enough. You reach into your own pocket to try to make the workers whole. The Bruiser approaches you with a sad smile. "Thank you. It's not much, but it's the world to these people."

narrative:
Anticipating an enjoyable night of drinks at the Sleeping Lion, you enter the tavern to see a familiar Savvas sitting at your usual table. The Cragheart stands and extends both its arms.

"Ah, friends! So good to see you," it says. "Sit, have a drink with me!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Have a drink with the Cragheart.

outcomes.narrative: One drink turns into five, and five turns into even more. It is a great night of revelry at the Sleeping Lion. You see sadness in the Cragheart's eyes when you finally stand up to leave. It tells you it's been hard to find people to relate to since leaving the party and it thanks you for your continued friendship.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Encourage the Cragheart to move on with its life.

outcomes.narrative: Not fitting in with its own kind or with a city of mostly humans, the Cragheart thought it could depend on a misfit group of mercenaries for friendship. It understands that its adventuring life is now in the past, though, and that it should go find a new place to belong. It sadly admits that it has no idea where that would be, but the Cragheart gets up and leaves the tavern nonetheless.

narrative:
Food has just arrived at your table when a familiar face walks into the Sleeping Lion. It's none other than your old friend the Cragheart, albeit with a handsome-looking cape and boots that show hardworking wear.

Your old friend doesn't notice you at your usual table, and it takes some effort to get its attention. It squints its eyes at you, processing your presence for a moment before the spark of recognition hits.

"Friends! I didn't see you there. It has been too long!" The Cragheart greets each of you with a confident smile. Over the next few hours, you share stories of your own adventures, winding down the evening as you used to. You learn that the Cragheart has traveled extensively in its retirement—even further than your travels together. Eventually, though, the sun starts streaming through the tavern's curtains. There's only time for a few final words.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Thank the Cragheart for its time in your party.

outcomes.narrative:
You take your last few minutes together to thank the Cragheart for its contributions to your mercenary party, and remind it that it always has a home with you if it needs it. It smiles a smile that makes clear it's appreciative, but that chapter is closed.

"Oh, that reminds me. I did find something that made me think of you. Perhaps it's of some use?"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask the Cragheart to regale you with one more story from its time abroad.

outcomes.narrative: "There is actually something I thought could be of use to you: I met a very old, very odd woman in an forest up north. She wouldn't speak, but she had a way about her. Necklace made of bark, if I recall. If you ever encounter her, treat her with respect—if I were you, I'd just lay down my weapons, to be frank. I think that would work out well for you." There's a smile, but it doesn't elaborate.

narrative:
You're just settling into bed when the door to your room is blown clear off the hinges. You brush the splinters off your clothes and watch in horror as a rift opens where your doorway should be, gushing waves of brackish water into your room. Amidst the torrent, out flies a scepter with enough force to embed itself into the opposite wall. Wait, is that—

Blood, rubble, and terrifying eye stalks flash into view through the fissure. Then a familiar hand springs out: it's the Soultether's! It reaches frantically for any kind of purchase, but before they can pull themselves through to the safety of the room, a tremendous claw slices through their torso. The Soultether hollers out in pain, then locks eyes with you. "DESTROY THE SCEPTER!" they scream as the rift snaps back shut. The Soultether's severed hand remains on your side of the portal.

You feel their connection to you shatter. The Soultether is dead.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Respect the Soultether's dying wish and destroy their scepter.

outcomes.narrative: It takes all of you in unison to exert enough force to snap the arcane scepter, but when you do, the energy released throws you to your knees. You don't know why your old friend had to die to protect it, but you will honor their wishes. Somehow, you hope they see your deed and find peace.
effects: Lock scenario 94

options.label: B
options.narrative: Something this powerful should be wielded for good, no matter the cost. Keep the scepter intact.

outcomes.narrative: Even when they were still alive, you didn't always see eye-to-eye with the Soultether. You know that you have the strength to protect this staff, and you can put it to better use than being another discarded thing tossed aside. You will use it in their honor.
effects: Lock scenario 94

narrative:
It's been some time since you last saw your friend the Mindthief, and you take a trip down to the Old Docks to the forwarding address they left behind. A knock on the door reveals an unconcerned-looking Vermling that introduces himself as Two-Tailed Taz.

"Oh, that was your friend? Passed away. Poof. Gone." The Vermling makes a snapping noise with his jaw to emphasize the point. Still somewhat shocked, you press for details.

"Don't drink the water, not since Roland. Don't eat the rats, either. Same reason. Last of their litter. Very old. Old. Old! Dead now." Lost in thought, the Vermling rubs his teeth together, producing a sharp squeaking sound. Suddenly, he darts back inside the home and drags out a ratty-looking garment you recognize. "Oh, they left this for you. Right, right. All they had, sorry it wasn't more." With the message relayed, he nods to himself.

You look at the flea-bitten shawl your friend used to wear. It feels small in your hands.

Gain Flea-Bitten Shawl (Item 137)

options.label: A
options.narrative: Say a few words for your fallen friend.

outcomes.narrative: You try to reminisce with the Vermling about the Mindthief, but he's having none of it. "Very sad. Droopy bones. Face like ooze, very sad." He pulls at his eye while frowning to demonstrate. "So dead." After a few minutes, he excuses himself to check on some Black Imp stew he has cooking and forgets to return. You take the shawl and head to the Sleeping Lion to find other ways past your pain.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Doubt the Vermling's story.

outcomes.narrative: You growl at the Vermling, pressing the issue. "Fine, fine! They also left you some small money. No big deal, I would give. I give!"
You start to question the Vermling's retelling, but he loses interest in your interrogation. "I see why they retired. Very see. You boring." He shuts the door.

narrative:
"You look surprised to see me." Your old friend the Mindthief starts walking beside you through the Sinking Market. "Not dead yet, don't worry. And if you hear otherwise from Two-Tailed Taz, know he's a liar."

Your old friend seems right at home walking and talking with you, and for a moment, it feels like they never left.

"There are good Vermlings and bad Vermlings. Some bad Vermlings are killing villagers in the Hook Coast." The Vermling stops, looking you squarely in the eye. "Bad Vermlings are bad for all Vermlings. My adventuring days are over, but someone needs to help the villagers build defenses and learn to take care of themselves."

It's quickly becoming clear the Mindthief thinks that someone is you.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to help the villagers of the Hook Coast.

outcomes.narrative: "The Vermlings have had success, so they'll return for more. Get there as soon as you can." Your old friend takes a long breath, then smiles. "It was good seeing you—stay safe."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Friend or not, demand payment for the trouble.

outcomes.narrative:
You start to ask for payment, then remember that you don't actually need payment to help your old friend. If it's important to the Mindthief, it's important to you, and you would kindly help them whenever they ask. The Mindthief gives a knowing smile and you can't help but feel like you've forgotten something. No matter.

"The Vermlings have had success, so they'll return for more. Get there as soon as you can. No need to report back, I know you'll take care of it."

narrative:
Slumped outside the Sleeping Lion, you find your old friend the Nightshroud. Surprised to see them—for several reasons—you ask what's the matter.

"Normally, I am not-here, but here. Lately, I've been not-here, and not-here." The words spill out, not entirely sensical. "When my mind and my body are both present, I understand things. When they are out of sync, it is more difficult. To think."

The Nightshroud stands, a bit uneasy on their own legs. With a concerned look down to their hands they vanish, reappearing behind you. They continue, having not noticed the change.

"Am I thread? I fear I am unwound."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Encourage the Nightshroud to anchor itself to this plane.

outcomes.narrative:
"You are true friends. You are the anchor. I will not journey with you, but I will excise evil from this place in the shadows where you cannot."

The Nightshroud draws themselves to full height. You notice that, compared to a moment ago, they are a more healthy-looking opaque. Without additional ceremony, the Nightshroud vanishes in a twist of smoke.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Encourage the Nightshroud to let itself drift to other planes.

outcomes.narrative:
"I had purpose here. The draw was a life raft... but my purpose has concluded. I will not cling to that which has ended. A parting gift, then."

The Nightshroud touches your forehead, and you feel your mind tear for an instant. The dull thud lingers, but you feel something where there was nothing before. Without additional ceremony, the Nightshroud vanishes in a twist of smoke.

narrative:
"Stay back, it's likely to jump to others!" A man clutches at his stomach, boils spreading over his body. He takes a few faltering steps before dropping to the ground, dead. The town guard is holding back a growing crowd, fearful themselves to approach.

A citizen whispers something in the ear of a guard, pointing in your direction. He steps up to you with a concerned look. "I hear you used to travel with a Harrower. One who would kill like this. That true?"

You stammer a reply, but he's heard enough. "I hear your friend was the last to talk to that man. None of us are going near that—you're going to clean this up yourselves. Standard wage for the body removal, but this is on you."

Another lingering gift from the Plagueherald.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Protect yourself as best you can and remove the body.

outcomes.narrative:
You can't imagine any graveyard would accept it, so you make your way to the Void: the silent field of black sand in the middle of Gloomhaven that functions as a garbage dump for anyone that wants to dispose of something permanently. You toss the corpse in and watch it disintegrate.

You wish this was the first time you've encountered the Plagueherald's mess. Brushing off the fragments of black dust that landed on your clothes, you make your way over to the guard to collect the disposal payment.

You can't imagine any graveyard would accept it, so you make your way to the Void: the silent field of black sand in the middle of Gloomhaven that functions as a garbage dump for anyone that wants to dispose of something permanently. You toss the corpse in and watch it disintegrate.

You collect the payment for the corpse removal from the guard and head back to your room, perspiration seeping into your clothes as your skin bubbles. Several days later you still feel sick and curse the Plagueherald for their involvement.

options.label: B
options.narrative: This isn't your mess—refuse to help the guards.

outcomes.narrative: Having witnessed the effects, you're not about to mess with whatever horrific disease the Plagueherald inflicted on that man. The guards curse you for leaving them to deal with it themselves.

narrative:
The rumors are true: a pox is spreading through Gloomhaven, affecting anyone foolish to wander the streets after dark.

You're stepping out of the Sleeping Lion when you see it: a Harrower in a ragged cloak holding a man down in an alley as its swarm spreads out and consumes him. The man's screams are muffled as the insects skitter down his throat, depositing their sticky-sweet infection across his insides.

Killing monsters and demons is one thing, but the Plagueherald shouldn't be preying on people in the city. You approach it, intent on stopping its attack.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Calmly explain the situation to the Plagueherald, imploring it to move on.

outcomes.narrative: With the man dead at its feet, the Plagueherald makes a chittering sound that sounds almost like laughing. "You cannot see it, but this city needs to be cleansed. You will see, and you will thank me." At this, the Plagueherald bursts out into a massive swarm of insects and flies up into the sky. The deaths continue, and new rumors start about how you are associated with the killer.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Enough is enough—you'll need to exterminate your old friend.

outcomes.narrative:
The Plagueherald recoils at your attack, falling to the ground in a puddle of insects. "But... the cleansing... the city isn't ready..." You can't help but feel sorry at the sight of how far your friend has gone.

It chitters in disappointment, "...You will be responsible when the Harbinger comes..." The mass of bugs suddenly lurches spasmodically in on itself, finally relaxing. You kick the remainder apart with the toe of your boot, but there's nothing but curled up insect husks.

narrative:
You catch sight of your old mercenary companion, the Quartermaster, pulling a wagon through town. Piled high are weapons, armor, and all manner of trinkets, all held down with series of expertly-tied ropes. They're delighted to see you.

"Hello friends! Just finished acquiring these in the Sinking Market. Lots of good deals on second-hand goods today. With a bit of repair and polish, I'll be able to sell them good as new. Probably priced a bit higher than new, actually. Not much is out there... People are getting concerned with the stability of the city, thanks to all the politics. Hoarding." They wipe the sweat from their brow, and are just about to push on when they turn back to you.

"Say, you wouldn't have anything you're not using anymore, would you? I'd be happy to buy it from you, full price."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sell the Quartermaster some of your equipment at face value.

outcomes.narrative: "I know the condition you keep your equipment in, but still—a shortage is a shortage. What've you got?"
effects: You may immediately sell any number of items for their full price.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask to purchase some of the used equipment before it gets resold.

outcomes.narrative: You pick through the Quartermaster's cart, trying on various pieces of armor and testing the heft of the weapons. Perhaps some of this is suitable for use in the field.
effects: Each character may purchase one item from the available supply at half price.

narrative:
Your old friend the Sawbones sits down at your usual table at the Sleeping Lion and immediately launches into recounting recent adventures.

"I miss working with you all, of course. I felt like I always had steady work and steady income, which was nice. I had a bit of a rough patch a few weeks ago, but it was fine: my friend Bonecruncher lent me some money."

Oh no. Bonecruncher, the notorious loan shark? The Sawbones sees the look on your faces and meets it with an eye roll. "Don't worry about it, it's not some big racket like everyone makes it out to be. I don't even have to pay it all back at once—just a little bit of interest every now and then. He explained everything, I'll have it paid back in no time at all."

Before you can object, the Sawbones reaches into his satchel. "Besides, I got you all some nice gifts, since I've got more room in my finances now!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Accept a generous gift from your old friend.

outcomes.narrative:
It's a gift you couldn't have picked better yourself. You're closing out the night when you're approached by a hulking Savvas that introduces itself as an employee of Bonecruncher's.

"Sharing, eh? I'll let Bonecruncher know you're an additional guarantor of your friend's debt." The mountain of rock smiles. "I'm sure it won't come to that, though."
effects: Each character may gain one item from the available supply that costs 25 gold or less.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pay off the Sawbones' debt with Bonecruncher immediately.

outcomes.narrative: Bonecruncher chuckles and happily accepts payment. Still, the Sawbones doesn't seem to appreciate the dire fate you avoided for them. "I could've covered it, probably."

effects.condition: If event C-44 is in the city deck

outcomes.narrative: When you hear just how much the Sawbones owes, your eyes widen. You attempt to negotiate with Bonecruncher, who just chuckles. "I'll tell you what: since you seem to care about this friend of yours, in the event the doc isn't able to pay the interest, I'll come find you instead of breaking their legs off. Seems like a good deal for your friend."

narrative:
Your old friend the Sawbones slides into your usual table at the Sleeping Lion, exhausted from a long day helping heal the unfortunate at the Temple of the Great Oak.

"I got to use the old saw today, so that was nice." The Sawbones trails off, clearly thinking about better times. Finally, they snap back to it, asking you the question they've been considering for some time.

"What would you think if I... stopped being a healer. I've accomplished my dreams, but now I just feel... stuck, I guess." The Sawbones refuses to make eye contact, staring down at the bar top. "I know I'm helping at the Temple, and they really need the skills I have. But I just can't help wanting something more."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Remind the Sawbones how important their work is.

outcomes.narrative:
You know how many people have been helped by the Sawbones, and it doesn't take much to brighten their spirits.

"You're right, I know I'm doing the right thing. And it's not the end of the road, right? I can contribute to Gloomhaven and still choose a new path someday in the future."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Encourage the Sawbones to pursue a new dream.

outcomes.narrative:
You can see it in your old friend's face: they'll never be truly happy unless they scratch that wanderlust. If anything, it looks like they're asking for permission to do what they refuse to admit to themselves.

"You really think it'll be okay? I've given so much to this city, I just feel like it's time I did something for me, for a change." You tell them you'll support them no matter what, and the Sawbones looks like a weight has been lifted off them. "You're right! I deserve to be happy!"

narrative:
It's performance night at the Brown Door, a seedy bar across town. You're in attendance to root on your old friend the Soothsinger, who is competing in this evening's battle of the bands. A drummer makes a lot of noise, singers croon at the crowd, and melodies grace the stage. Each are met with various levels of enthusiasm from the audience, and it's quickly apparent who the top contenders are.

Waiting to go on stage next is Basseloff, a pretentious Quatryl bard who styles himself "the greatest in the world." You're standing nearby as he tunes his lute with meticulous precision, plucking each string and warbling to the frequency. It is obnoxious, and you can't help but feel sorry for the singer onstage who must be able to hear it.

As the prior act is drawing to a close, a group of fans see Basseloff and swarm, much to his apparent delight. In the chaos, Basseloff sets down his lute, just within arms-reach of you.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Quickly untune the lute.

outcomes.narrative: You quickly scramble the lute's pegs before anyone notices. Basseloff takes to the stage, and the change causes enough of a stumble to impact his scores with the judges.

You attempt to grab the lute, but a groupie quickly points you out. Before long, the crowd has turned against you, and you catch the eye of the Soothsinger as you're being carted off—they look exceptionally disappointed you didn't believe they could win without your "help".

options.label: B
options.narrative: The Soothsinger is good enough to win the contest without foul play.

outcomes.narrative:
You know the Soothsinger's ability and would put them up against any challenger. Basseloff gave a fine performance, but the real entertainment begins when the Soothsinger takes the stage.

They're a commanding presence and launch directly into a power ballad. Suddenly, they change tempo into a bewildering instrumental, followed by intensifying amplitude and a grand finale that is a truly captivating performance. Your friend walks off triumphant from the contest. The judges cheer, screaming, "Truly, Gloomhaven has proven it is a hub of great music!"

narrative:
In the very early morning, you are awakened by a knock at your door. Standing behind it is a giant, dirty Inox wearing a leather apron.

"Oh, uh... ahem," he coughs. "Sorry, I was looking for an Orchid friend of mine. They used to help me on occasion with my forge. I thought this was the right room. Sorry, it's just their control over fire was astounding, and I paid them well for assistance in completing some of my specialty work. Just can't get the fires stoked the same way without a bit of that, er..." he waves his hands in a fashion similar to what your old friend the Spellweaver would do, "...that."

He scratches his head. "Guess that's not an option any more. You wouldn't happen to know where I could find someone that could help me in their absence, would you?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Offer to help the blacksmith yourself.

outcomes.narrative: Despite the early hour, you head down to the Inox's forge and get an incredibly strong fire going for him so he can complete his order. He seems very pleased at your proficiency.

The Inox is completely dumbfounded when you walk all the way down to his forge, then proceed to exhibit zero aptitude at manipulating or controlling elemental energies. "Thanks for, uh... nothing, I guess."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Offer to summon a demon to stoke the flames.

outcomes.narrative: You inscribe a circle in ash at the base of the forge, and with a commanding boom, a Flame Demon appears before you. The Flame Demon obliges by producing gouts of fire as needed to support the Inox's work throughout the morning. When the task is complete, you thank the demon for its service, dismissing it back to the ether.

You attempt to summon a demon, but something has gone terribly awry. The Inox looks on in horror as his workshop is ravaged by the elements—it's clear the demons aren't interested in helping your cause. You apologize and sheepishly excuse yourself, leaving the Inox to clean up the mess.

narrative:
You've arrived at a cordoned-off area in the Temple of the Great Oak, beside the tree itself. In shining, polished armor before you is your old companion the Sunkeeper. "Thank you for coming. There is a tear in the Oak, and I fear it is beyond me to repair on my own."

Shielded from public view by a black curtain, a waist-high gash runs up the tree, revealing past the bark. Inside, the wood looks warm, vulnerable but comforting. You step closer and almost feel you sense a slow heartbeat—

The Sunkeeper puts a hand on your shoulder. "Be not enticed, we have work at hand. Normally, this is a secret task for several Sunkeepers working in concert, but all save myself are away on pressing business. The injury must be mended—either through care, or through cauterization. Which would be most comfortable to your skills?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Use magic to attempt to repair the Great Oak's injury.

outcomes.narrative: The Sunkeeper begins reciting long, elegant words you have not heard them use before in an unfamiliar tongue. You apply yourself to weaving energies, stitching the threads of bark like a costume over the tree. "Thank you, friends. Enjoy its blessings—and remember, speak of this to no one."

The Sunkeeper enters a trancelike state, speaking words of unknown origin. You see sunlight exit their hands, drifting over the surface of the bark and weaving it back together. You try to provide support through sheer force of will, but before the gash seals, the Sunkeeper falls to the ground, exhausted. "We'll leave it sealed off for now, and I'll return when I've recuperated. Thank you."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Cauterize the damaged portion of the tree.

outcomes.narrative: You wait until midday when the sun is highest to give the tree the most energy. Rumor has it that boughs of the Great Oak refuse to burn, but it seems that the Oak supports your decision today and the kindling you pack into the wound rapidly catches light. You stoke the fire for a few hours, and when you clear off the charcoal, you find the gash has been successfully sealed off.

narrative:
They're two hours late, and you're starting to get bored. You're being paid a healthy sum to facilitate the sale of whatever is in these mystery crates. Your curiosity is starting to outweigh your patience.

Just then, you hear a voice outside the warehouse. "You go in first, I'll direct the reinforcements when they arrive. Ready? Go." A split-second later, the door is blown off its hinges with the swing of a massive warhammer. When the dust settles, you see your old friend the Sunkeeper, who looks as surprised as you are.

"Wait—you're the ones selling stolen oak?" The Sunkeeper pries open one of the crates to show you: stacked in neat piles inside are boughs of the Great Oak. The contraband supposedly has protective powers, but the Keepers make sure it never falls into the wrong hands. This must've been sawn off illegally for sale on the black market.

"What were you thinking? The town guard will be here any minute with reinforcements!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Stick around and explain you were just being paid to sell the crates.

outcomes.narrative: You're a known quantity as mercenaries, and the guard lets you off with a warning. The Sunkeeper gives a frustrated look. "I've been tracking these crates for weeks, and this has been a huge waste of my time."

The guards arrive and are disappointed to just see you sheepishly sitting on a stack of crates. Your old friend does their best to explain the situation, and after a long back-and-forth, the Sunkeeper walks over to you. "They can't ignore this, but they're willing to let you plead your case to the arbiters. Best I could do."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask the Sunkeeper to let you go before the town guard arrives.

outcomes.narrative: "Are you insane? Do you realize how much trouble you're in right now? I..." The Sunkeeper, frustrated, sets down their warhammer. "Go." You're gone before the guards arrive.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Ask the Sunkeeper to let you go, with the crates.

outcomes.narrative: "Are you insane? Do you realize how much trouble you're in right now?" The Sunkeeper, frustrated, holds you in the warehouse until backup arrives. It takes hours, but the guards finish processing the evidence and finally release you with a court date. The Sunkeeper shakes their head as you're lead outside.

narrative:
You return to your room to find your old friend the Tinkerer on their hands and knees, grabbing at something under the floorboards. A leather backpack beside them is overflowing with polished brass mechanical limbs. "Drat, I could've sworn... There you are—oh, hello!" They look surprised to see you in your own quarters. "Oh, right. I realized I left some equipment here from back when we were adventuring together. I've been working on some top secret inventions. I needed this—" your old friend holds up a wooden handle with metal sockets on it.

"Spider-piston extender. Huge pain working on spider bots without one... Not, uh, not that I'm making spider bots." They look like they've already said too much.

"Anyway, I should probably let you get back to... Uhm. Unless you'd be willing to do some field testing on one of my creations?" They look incredibly hopeful.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to test a heal-spraying spider bot.

outcomes.narrative: "This can detect and hose down injured party members with suture spray. You're going to want to test-activate it a few times before trying it in the field. Last time, it wasted all of its healing acid spraying down a rock it thought was a Savvas. Melted it to slag. I'm almost certain I worked that kink out, though."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Agree to test an aggressive, poison-spewing spider bot.

outcomes.narrative: "Perfect, it should be calibrated to fire around you now. The abdomen will shoot out tiny darts on command. Originally I designed it to have eight tiny flamethrowers. Hah, well... it turns out friendly fire isn't."

narrative:
Your old friend the Tinkerer barges into your room holding a confusing metal box. "You're here! A Quatryl asked me to build a time-dilation machine. Should work perfectly. But if it doesn't, we need to hit the red button, green button twice, blue, then red three more times. Everyone ready? Great!"

Without waiting, the Tinkerer throws a lever. Time slows to the point of irritation—even attempting to refocus your vision is boredom-inducing. And then you see the sparks, and fire... you need to hit the sequence of buttons together and shut it down.

Characters must put down all of their cards in increasing order in the center of the table on an open stack, one after another. You may not play a card of an initiative lower than the top card of the pile. There are no turns, and characters may play cards as they see fit. narrative:
A collection of travelers surround a campfire up ahead and beckons you to join them. They are sharing stories as the sunsets for the evening and seem friendly enough.

A Valrath passes a flagon of sweet meekseed wine around the circle as he tells of his adventures along the southern coast. It's an incredible mix of adventure, fun, and bad fortune with impossible odds, and it certainly makes for a good campfire story. The story winds down and the assembled group looks to you to contribute a tale.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Tell a scary story.

outcomes.narrative: You spin a tale of true terror. The fire flares up at the just the right times, then descends to near blackness when the mood requires. The travelers have trouble sleeping, and the following morning ask you to escort them to their destination for a fee-on the condition you don't tell any more stories.
You attempt to tell a scary tale, but after some snickers, it's clear you didn't frighten anyone at all.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Make up an adventure and claim it's true.

outcomes.narrative: You spin a tale of fantastic adventure, recapping the travels of a group similar to your own. You sprinkle in true facts from the region and smart anecdotes that paint the tale with an air of realism so strong it surely must be true. The mouths hanging open at the shocking conclusion are better than any applause. They ask that you join them for as long as you're heading the same direction to share more of your epic tales, and they're happy to pay for the company.

You attempt to tell a grand tale of adventure, but it winds up a jumbled mess of improbable situations and long-winded explanations. They're polite in their response, and you part ways the next morning.

narrative:
The scraping snap of claws warns you of what's coming before you see it: there's a Lurker up ahead. You have no desire to tangle with the massive crab creatures, and with any luck, it hasn't heard you yet.

When you finally lay eyes on it, you see what's causing the ruckus: a full-sized Lurker has gotten itself caught in a bear trap by the river bank. It is frantically snapping its claws at the metal but can't get a decent angle to detach the jaws. Judging by how slowly it's moving, it's been struggling for some time.

When it spots you, it rears up, brandishing its claws in your direction. With one leg trapped, though, this one looks far from the fearsome tyrants they normally are on the battlefield-instead, this one looks like easy prey.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Take down the Lurker before it frees itself.

outcomes.narrative: A Lurker is still a formidable adversary, even with one leg immobilized. But you come at it from multiple sides and after a few good blows it falls, defeated.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Assist the Lurker in removing the trap.

outcomes.narrative:
The Lurker doesn't seem to fully understand you're assisting and struggles throughout the process, lashing out wherever it can. It takes some coordinated effort, but you manage to distract the beast long enough to pry the trap from its leg.

The Lurker, confused, gives a final twist of its head before galloping into the stream. You'll interpret that as a "thank you," which will perhaps ease the lacerations it left you with.

You attempt to pacify the beast long enough to get closer to the trap, but the Lurker is having none of it. Finally, you commit to being beaten around the head with its terrifying claws while you pry the metal jaws free. It takes a final swipe at you before diving into the shallow river.

narrative:
"Don't come any closer! On penalty of death! Your death! From unluckiness!" Standing up the road is a stout Quatryl with various cushions and pillows strapped to his body. The configuration seems to make it difficult for him to breathe. "I'm warning you! I am dangerously unlucky! Approach at your own risk!" As if to emphasize the point, he promptly falls over, smashing his nose into the ground.

A trickle of blood runs down his face. "Oh no, it's… yeah, that's blood." At the sight of it he gives a half-stumble, then promptly passes out in the road.

You prop him up to be comfortable, then splash cool water across his face. He wakes up with a start. "No! You're too near me! You'll get the curse! I'm the unluckiest Quatryl that ever lived, you need to stay back!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Assure him you're here to help however you can.

outcomes.narrative: "Hey, that actually feels… better. I might be uncursed!" He gives a celebratory jump, but stubs his toe on a rock in the process. "Maybe still a little unlucky."

outcomes.narrative: You deal a final, merciful blow, and the Quatryl falls peacefully. You can't help but feel that some of whatever afflicted him has washed off on you, though…

narrative:
By the side of the road, you find a carriage parked, its owner wiping sweat from his brow. An old Vermling gives a toothless grin in your direction, waving you over to the makeshift shop he's set up.

"Gloomhaven Council Law 119.5, important one, you heard of it? Sets the patrol boundary for the town guard just over that ridge there. This patch of road is outside their jurisdiction. Lets me keep the prices low, eh? Lots to see, priced to move. Wheels to move, too," He kicks the side of his carriage, "just in case that law ever changes. Heh heh." He chuckles to himself as he lays thick carpets by the side of the road, spreading out his wares—several unusual artifacts catch your eye.

"I'm just doing my part to make sure these hard-to-find items stay in circulation, eh? No touching! Browse with your eyes, not your hands."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Browse the available wares.

outcomes.narrative: "Last thing I need is word to get around. You look like someone with a closed jaw. Heh."

A curious-looking gear with rusted edges. Read %game.section:76.6%.

options.narrative: Assure him you're not concerned with where his items come from.

outcomes.narrative: You engage the traveling merchant on how well-connected you are, but in the course of the conversation, something clicks, and he narrows his eyes. "Store's closed. Sold out. Go away."
"Glad to hear it."

narrative:
You're a few steps outside of Gloomhaven's walls when a man with a pair of horses and a wagon stops you. He flashes a broad, inviting smile.

"Care for a ride to your destination? Anywhere you want to go, just five gold."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Take the man up on his offer.

outcomes.narrative: The wagon ride isn't luxurious, but it sure beats having to walk yourself. You arrive at your destination well-rested and ready for whatever circumstances are thrown at you.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Take your chances on the road.

outcomes.narrative: You wave the man off. You've arrived under your own power every time before, and today won't be any different. What's the worst that could happen?

narrative:
You stop to allow a procession of Inox to pass. They're dressed in ceremonial garb and led by a trio of Savvas chanting a solemn dirge and thumping their chests in time to the group's footfalls. At the center of the group, you spot a young Inox woman sobbing behind a white veil, her hands bound with silk rope. No one appears willing to comfort her.

The display is unusual enough that you peel off an Inox at the back of the congregation to ask what's going on.

"We're heading to the Rupture." He gestures to black smoke rising from a far-off peak. "The beast awakens and demands a sacrifice. We must sate its anger! The mountain is aflame!"

The woman falls to her knees, wailing in terror. The Savvas stop their chanting to order the group into action, and two men in flowing robes pick her off the ground. When she refuses to walk, they drag her as best they can, still sobbing.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Let the procession pass.

outcomes.narrative: They head towards the smoking mountain, and a few days later at sunset, you feel an uneasy stillness, as though the mountain has finally come to rest. Odd.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Offer yourself as a sacrifice in her stead.

outcomes.narrative: You demand to take the young woman's place. The Savvas deliberate with each other for a moment, then acquiesce. "Retrieve the sacred artifacts and cast the greater into the liquid flame so the mountain will rest. Fail, and you have doomed our village and this land."

options.label: C
options.narrative: Kill the convoy and free the woman.

outcomes.narrative:
The woman's captors are no match for trained mercenaries, but she is less than appreciative.

"You've doomed us! Now the mountain will flow with liquid flame and destroy my village!" She falls to her knees, sobbing. In an attempt to pacify her, you agree to complete the ritual in her party's stead.

"Really? You'll need to push past the guardians to retrieve the sacred artifacts. Take the greater of the two and cast it into the mountain's fires. Oh, and I'm told a sacrifice of innocent blood will help appease the beast." You nod, but make no promises about that last part.

narrative: A set of abandoned fishing poles rests beside a feeder stream. The poles look like they were hastily discarded in the tall grass, and a bucket of worms writhe in a wicker basket beside them. With your stomach rumbling, you grab a pole and make use of your good fortune.

It puts up a fight, but you reel in an iridescent gimmelfish.

The nibble at the end of your line suggests a tasty lunch is about to be served, but you didn't realize who was on the menu. When the rows of scalpel-like teeth burst from the edge of the stream, the idyllic fishing spot turns to a traumatic race for cover. Tentacles whip sludge-filled barbs at anything within terrifying range. The eye-stalk breaches the water last: a crimson orb hunting you down among the tall grass.

You regain your wits and defend yourself, finally taking down the deep terror, but it will be weeks before you wake up in anything but a cold sweat.

narrative:
That's strange. There's something in the road here… ah, it's a corpse. A freshly-gnawed corpse. But it's beside a sturdy-looking mace that would look great on your hip—

Pfft-TUFF!

A sharp barb lodges itself into your leg, and the idyllic hillside takes a turn for drowsy. You try to keep your bearings as a group of Vermlings rappel down from the trees and launch their attack, blow darts and spears in tow.

As you fight the sedative effects of the poison and struggle to stay awake, you recall that Vermlings have been known to eat the dead. It is not a comforting thought as your eyelids get heavy.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Defend yourself through the sleepiness.

outcomes.narrative: You fight through the unbearable urge to sleep. You make a hasty retreat—but you make note of the location to return someday better prepared.

The only thing keeping you awake is the punctures of spearpoints as you attempt to retreat. You manage to make it to safety and note the location for the future. Whether it's the blood loss or the poison you're not sure, but you are due for a nap.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Grab the heavy mace and try to make a run for it.

outcomes.narrative: With heavy eyelids, you grab the handle of the mace and start running, dodging projectiles as you go. You mark the location to return someday.
You grab the handle of the mace, but it's heavier than it looks. With the extra weight, a poorly-timed nap is in your future.

narrative:
Not far outside Gloomhaven, you look up to see a large bird flying overhead. Something is odd, though. Its movements are jerky, and there is smoke billowing out of it. Then you see it plunge into a sudden nose-dive and crash to the ground off in the east.

You rush to the scene and find a limping, soot-covered Quatryl kicking a giant winged contraption made of leather and metal.

"Curse this wretched thing!" He yells in frustration. "I thought I'd worked it out, and then I suddenly lost pressure in the piston chamber!"

He looks over at you. "You there! Wonderful timing! Help me get this thing back into the air. There is no time to waste—the world needs my invention!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Examine the machinery yourself to determine the cause of the malfunction.

outcomes.narrative: A cursory look is all it takes to confirm your suspicion: the piston chamber is losing pressure due to icing at higher altitudes. It's a small matter to better insulate the valve and the system is again flight-worthy. You stand clear and watch in awe as the thing begins flapping wildly and lifts off the ground.

It's pretty clear what the problem is: there isn't a feather anywhere on the thing. The leather is from ground-based animals and wood also grows out of the ground. The Quatryl sighs as you explain it to him. "…right. Okay, I'll just finish this one on my own. Thanks."

A short time later you see the machine scream past above you. Unfortunately, the flight is short-lived, and the second crash is not nearly as forgiving. You find the Quatryl dead on impact, and there's nothing more to do except harvest the machine for valuable parts. You did try to warn him.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Follow the inventor's directions and perform the repairs.

outcomes.narrative: You set the wings and bang out a few dents while the Quatryl repairs his pressure problem. In under an hour the Quatryl declares the contraption airworthy and jumps in the cockpit. Unfortunately, the flight is short-lived, and the second crash is not nearly as forgiving. You find the Quatryl dead on impact, and there's nothing more to do except harvest the machine for valuable parts.
