narrative:
You are feeling a tad hungry as you walk down the road. You are considering stopping for a meal when you come across a thicket of bushes covered in red berries.

The berries look delicious, but you hesitate. They could be poisonous.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Eat the berries.

outcomes.narrative: You shrug and grab a handful of berries to stuff in your mouth. They are incredibly sweet and just the right amount of tart. You couldn't feel better about your decision. That is, until you start vomiting. Your stomach is incredibly unhappy with you, and the situation doesn't improve much by the time you arrive at your destination.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pass by the berries and just eat your normal rations.

outcomes.narrative: Not wanting to regret making a stupid decision, you refrain from eating the berries and continue on down the road.

narrative:
As you walk down a dirt path, you see a hard-looking mercenary sitting in a patch of grass. He nods as you pass.

"Hey, friends," he says. There is something off about his tone, though.

"I don't suppose one of you might be willing to part with a stamina potion, would you? I'm headed toward Gloomhaven, but I've just come from such a long way, and I'm not feeling too good about the stretch I have left."

With the clank of his sword sheath against his armor and a loud groan, the man stands up. "I'll pay you well for it."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sell the man a stamina potion.

outcomes.narrative: After some oddly tense negotiations, you are able to agree upon a price. With one hand firmly on his sword hilt, the man grabs a coin pouch with the other hand and extends it toward you. You exchange goods and continue on your journey without further incident.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Politely decline and move quickly on your way.

outcomes.narrative:
There was something off-putting about that man. You are more than happy to move along and put some distance between you.

It feels good to snub that mercenary. Is that how they feel when they look at you? Empowering, really.
There was something off-putting about that man. You are more than happy to move along and put some distance between you.

narrative:
After a heavy rain, the roads are dark streaks of slushy dirt. A group of exhausted attendants are pitifully attempting to free a wagon caught in knee-deep mud. The side of the wagon is emblazoned with "The Great Dallum—the Seer Who Knows."

With a moment of help you manage to clear it out of the rut. As soon as it's free, the side door opens and out steps a man with a charisma unlike any you've seen. Long, sandy-brown hair cascades down his shoulders, and his watery blue eyes gently meet your gaze. With a warm smile, he addresses you by name, then gives a friendly chuckle at your surprise.

"Thank you for your help—I know not how long we would have been trapped here were it not for you." He clasps your hands in his own, and you feel the earnest callouses of a man who is no stranger to hard work. "I can see eddies flowing through us, and I use my gifts to help others. We were on our way to Gloomhaven when the rains caught us. Before we continue, can I thank you by lending my sight to your needs?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Ask that he looks into the future of Gloomhaven.

outcomes.narrative: He speaks slowly and softly: "Gloomhaven is a troubled city... I hope to speak with the leadership there. I only hope that my warnings will not fall on deaf ears." He gives a somber look. "Sometimes all that's required is a friendly introduction..."

effects.narrative: You agree to put in a good word for him with your contacts when you return to town. "This comes as no surprise... this world delights in providing what we need precisely when necessary."
"No matter, sometimes the smallest seed is all that's needed to blossom into great change."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask that he looks into the future of your party.

outcomes.narrative:
He speaks slowly and softly: "Your journey is nearly at an end, but there are others like you that will take up your standard. Your upcoming retirement will be arguably as good as you dream, but I fear adversity looms in the change."

You turn to leave, but he calls you back. "Oh, one more thing: be wary in your upcoming travels. I foresee that a minor injury will prevent a more serious incident. Good luck."

narrative:
It's late afternoon when your progress is stopped by a thicket of brambles that have overtaken the road. It's hard work clearing the path, and during a break, you spot a small outpost with a good vantage point to the horizon. It's a little ways off the road, and even from a distance you can see it is being strangled by the same brambles that have made your journey frustrating so far.

There are a few hours before nightfall: diverting and clearing a path to the outpost would be hard labor for the rest of the afternoon, but having a safe place to rest would be welcome. If you do a good job, you may even be able to use it in the future. Is it worth the effort today?

options.label: A
options.narrative: Spend the rest of the day clearing brambles to get to the outpost.

outcomes.narrative:
The sticky brambles scratch and tear whatever gets within reach, and in short order, you're covered in pinpricks. When you do finally make it up to the outpost, you're dead tired. You hope that a future trip is made easier by your efforts, but you can't help but grumble at how much work it was for so little reward.

You're back on your way shortly before sunrise, sore muscles and all.
effects: Each %game.trait:armored% character ignores the suffer 1 damage and %game.condition.wound%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Clear only what's needed to continue to your destination.

outcomes.narrative: Bushwhacking the sticky brambles is frustrating work. While it may just be your imagination, you can nearly feel the bushes regrowing behind you. Several hours of work later, you emerge on the other side of the thicket and resume your journey.

narrative:
The distant sound of popping washes over the landscape, increasing in intensity as you approach. Before you is a field of trees bearing amberhollow, a brittle, hollow fruit that is entirely comprised of its shell with nothing but a bit of sweet liquid and an intense vacuum at its center. They're a novel treat enjoyed for the explosive cracking sound they make when opened. The larger the fruit, the larger the vacuum and the harder they are to transport, leaving a very short (and sometimes dangerous) window for picking.

This orchard of amberhollow trees is certainly ripe, and all signs would point to it being an excellent harvest. Unfortunately, a pair of flame demons are wreaking havoc up and down the rows, lighting the heavy branches aflame, and the fire has spread to the only building on the property. The whole crop will be nothing but ash in minutes, and the burned corpse of the farmer at your feet probably won't be enjoying the fruits of his labor, either.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Confront the flame demons.

outcomes.narrative: You brazenly confront the flame demons, ordering them to stand down. They recognize you and tone down the heat, but most of the crop is already lost. They eventually depart, leaving you to sort through the remains of the farmer's home and crops.
The demons don't take kindly to your tone. There isn't anything left of the farmer's home by the time the fight is over, but you do find a few fruits still intact.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Gather some fruits from the trees and make a quick exit.

outcomes.narrative: It doesn't look like there's any reason to get involved defending a dead man. You pick a few of the ripest looking fruits from the trees and depart before the rest of the orchard burns down.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Push past the demons and raid the farmer's former home before it burns up.

outcomes.narrative: Pursued by the flame demons, you hastily make your way into the burning building, gathering whatever valuables you can find. Soot and ash rain down on you as the thatched roof ignites. It takes everything you have to beat back the demons in the chaos and make it out with your lives.

narrative:
You're trudging along by the confidence of moonlight when an unfortunate misstep sends you tumbling down into a ditch. To your horror, your fall is stopped by slamming into an old Orchid meditating out of sight from the road. An Orchid sustains itself merely from contact with the ground and exposure to the sun, so it's not uncommon for one to detach from society for days or even months at a time. With a yawn she rouses herself, taking stock of the night air.

"Ho there! Been napping for a spell, what year is it?" The year? You tell her it's 1958 LO. "That'll make it just shy of two hundred years between measurements, then. And on a full moon, too! Excellent timing." She drags a heavy blanket off an apparatus next to her which reveals the largest telescope you've ever seen.

"Drat! The optic's cracked. Must've had a snap frost some year. Suppose I'll have to journey to the nearest town for parts. Can you point me towards Wayward? I assume the Sharp 'n' Sturdy still stands, even after all these years."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Attempt to repair the optics yourself.

outcomes.narrative:
You dismantle your possession and, with a bit of effort, are able to repair the damaged telescope. "See there? That twinkling teal crystal budding right out of the soil on the moon?" She makes some excited marks in her journal. "It's growing. I've been observing it every few centuries. But the real interesting part? When the moon rotates clear around to the other side, there's another one, straight across from each other if you drew a line through the core."

She stretches her back with a crack that sounds decades in the making. "Two crystals, opposite sides of a moon that'll never get the chance to see each other. Who put them there? I have my theories. Maybe it's nothing. Or maybe it'll be very important someday."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain that Gloomhaven is much closer than Wayward.

outcomes.narrative: "Gloomhaven? Miserable name for a city, just dreadful. Things really have changed while I was asleep!" You draw her a crude map of the region and showcase where Gloomhaven sits at the mouth of the Still River. She raises an eyebrow, but doesn't explain why. "Well, thank you for the help."

narrative:
A human boy is pacing back and forth in front of the mouth of a cave. When he sees you, the teen starts in your direction, then thinks better of it, turning back to his pacing. You approach and ask him what's the matter. He wrings his hands as he explains.

"It's… I lost a bet with some older kids. I'm supposed to go into this cave to prove I'm not a coward. It's just… those friends were supposed to meet me here to watch." He starts speaking at his shoes, unwilling to make eye contact with you. "I… I think they got here first and they're waiting in there to scare me. But if I don't go in, then they'll know I really am a coward. I don't know what to do."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Convince him to face his fear and go into the cave.

outcomes.narrative: After a rousing pep talk, the young man gives a somber nod and heads into the mouth of the cave. You wait a few minutes for his return, but with the sun setting soon, you head off towards your destination.

You give an explanation of how his cowardice will haunt him for the rest of his life, but it doesn't overcome his fear of entering the dark cave. After more than an hour of attempts, you leave him to build up the courage himself.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain he has nothing to prove.

outcomes.narrative: You explain to the boy that those "friends" were bullies, and that he's better off without them. He eventually nods his understanding and starts the walk back to Gloomhaven, alone. It feels like you inspired something in the boy.

You take pity on the boy's circumstances and escort him in, ready to get the jump on these "friends" that are so willing to bully him. The cave is surprisingly deep—and then the growling starts. Two full-grown cave bears are finishing up a meal, but they have room for dessert. It's a bloody fight, but you emerge victorious.

The boy, although unharmed, looks pretty shaken up.

narrative:
A few minutes outside of Gloomhaven, a well-fed raven is pacing in the middle of the road. It cocks its head as you approach, seemingly unafraid and used to interacting with people. When you get close enough, it hops forward, presenting its left leg. A small scrap of parchment is tied to it with a black ribbon.

The note is sealed with black wax and the insignia of a serpent wrapped around a dagger. You unfurl the note and read:

"It has been nearly a month since your last check-in. Advise immediately whether you have installed the puppet stewards as agreed."

The raven presents its other leg, waiting for a reply to be tied on.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Report that the preparations are on track.

outcomes.narrative: You pen a short missive confirming everything is on schedule and tie it onto the raven's other leg. It is seemingly waiting for something, and after a moment, you break off a piece of your trail ration. Satisfied, it takes to the air, and you quickly lose sight of it amongst the tree tops. Oh well.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Report that this went to the wrong individual.

outcomes.narrative: You write a short note explaining that this bird seems to have confused you with someone else. You sign at the bottom and tie it to the bird, giving it a few pats on the head. It looks confused, but eventually takes off. A few hours down the trail, you come across a black leather coin purse, seemingly left for you.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Report back with a surprise (requires "Escaping the Sin-Ra" Personal Quest).

outcomes.narrative:
As a former Sin-Ra operative, you know their methods when you see them. You write a return note and carefully—carefully place a single drop of concentrated poison in the folds. You tie it to the raven, and with a sharp whistle, you order it back into the air.

A few hours down the trail, you come across a dead man in the road, the note clutched in his hand. With one less operative in the world, you take what you can and move on.

narrative:
You're a long distance from Gloomhaven when an exhausted Valrath approaches on foot from the other direction, leading an equally spent hristek by its reins.

"Hello, travelers," the Valrath says. "I'm embarrassed to ask, but I was on a mission from the city, and I seem to have ridden too far, too fast. Both my mount and I are tired and out of supplies—would you allow us to rest with you this evening?"

You agree, and when you finally stop to make camp, the grateful traveler opens his saddlebag to share his remaining supplies. As he does, a wooden lockbox tumbles out onto the ground. He quickly scoops it up, but not before you catch sight of the symbol carved into its lid: a trident rising through a spiral.

"Silly me," he smiles as he stuffs the box back into his bag and produces a few paltry pieces of cured meat. "Now, friends, let's sit around the fire and eat, yes?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sneak over and open the lockbox while he's distracted with dinner.

outcomes.narrative:
You always keep a few pins around in case you need to open something you shouldn't. You easily pick the lock, finding only a notebook and a small mechanical bell—which begins clanging loudly.

"THIEVES!" cries the Valrath, ripping the box from your hands before riding away on his exhausted hristek. "I'll take my chances on my own."
Your clumsy efforts to pick the lock disturb the hristek, who honks angrily. You pretend you were merely petting the animal, and the traveler laughs. "Yes, she dislikes strangers, I'm afraid."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Let his secrets lie—ask him about his mission instead.

outcomes.narrative:
The traveler's business is his own, and besides, you're curious—what brings a lone rider into the dangerous wilds? "I'm a scout," the Valrath confides, "I work for a secret group that will bring salvation to Gloomhaven."

"If you're of like mind, simply look for the symbol of the trident, and together we'll save our city."

narrative:
Headed in the opposite direction, back towards Gloomhaven, are a pair of guards escorting four men clasped in manacles. As you pass them, one of the prisoners forces the gag out of his mouth, shouting at you for assistance: "Help us, please! We're political prisoners!"

One of the guards gives him a swift jab in the stomach and replaces the gag. "Sure, political prisoners. More like these four are treasonous scum. We're taking them back to the Ghost Fortress for processing." The guard yanks the chain-gang forward, snarling at the one who spoke up. "Enjoy the rest of your walk, it's the last gulps of fresh air you'll have before they seal you away for good."

The guards give a laugh, turning to you for your reaction. That's all it takes for the four men to make a run for it, stumbling up the embankment towards the cover of trees.

It takes a moment before the guards realize what's happening, and even then, all they manage is an impotent cry of, "Stop them!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Assist the guards in recapturing their charges.

outcomes.narrative: The prisoners are already worse for wear from the long walk, and it doesn't take much to subdue them. You make sure the manacles are in place before you bid the guards a good day. They nod their thanks and are sure to let you know they'll put in a good word with their superiors.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Let the prisoners escape.

outcomes.narrative: In a flash, the prisoners rush past you and into the cover of the trees. It's perfectly plausible that you just didn't react quickly enough, but that doesn't save you from the admonishment of the guards.

narrative:
Just outside the range where Gloomhaven could reasonably extend its influence, you find a clearing with a friendly-looking Quatryl in formal clothes beckoning you over. The Quatryl, bursting with excitement, gives a sweep of his arm to introduce you to the device beside him.

"Welcome to the Slot Sanctum, a traveling slot machine that can make your wildest dreams come true with a spin of the dial!" He gestures to the machine with flair. "Win fabulous prizes!" He calls your attention to the small table of stacked coins, exotic furs, and mystery boxes wrapped in red ribbon.

Giving it a spin couldn't hurt.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Play the slot machine legitimately.

outcomes.narrative: The operator shows you how to use the slot machine, and sets you up to pull the lever. He hands you a drink with chunks of ice floating in it. Tasty.
effects:
Make an 8-card slot machine deck composed of attack modifier deck cards from the ally modifier deck: two %game.attackmodifier.minus1%s, two %game.attackmodifier.plus1%s, two %game.attackmodifier.plus1%s, and any two other attack modifier cards of your choice. Each character may pull the slot machine lever as many times as they choose. For each pull, pay 5 gold and draw three cards from the slot machine deck. If two cards match, that character gains 4 gold. If all three cards match, instead gain 20 gold. If all three cards match three times in a row, also gain a random item design. Otherwise, gain nothing. Shuffle the slot machine deck after each pull.

The Quatryl looks delighted with your participation. "I'm also happy to discuss Slot Sanctum franchise opportunities!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Distract the Quatryl operator to gain an advantage.

outcomes.narrative: You ask for a tour of how the marvelous machine works, and the Quatryl is more than happy to showcase it.
effects: Add two additional attack modifier cards of your choice to the machine.

outcomes.narrative: The Quatryl notices your attempt to distract him and chides you for the attempt. "I regret to inform you that you'll need to leave the Slot Sanctum premises for violating protocol. Good day!"

narrative:
Every single time you leave the walls of Gloomhaven, you follow the road to the right at the copse of trees with the arrow-shaped rock, the beaten path, the one that has faithfully led you to adventure. It is a reliable road, and to be frank, you've never heard anyone who bothered taking the short footpath that leads into the grass to the left.

You asked around the Sleeping Lion one drunken night and you were laughed off: everyone knows to take the path to the right when leaving the city. It's just common knowledge. But when you pressed, no one could give an adequate reason why.

Perhaps today is the day. The day you will finally take control of your life and step outside the comforts of familiarity. Today is the day to go left at the fork.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Go left.

effects: Read %game.section:37.3%.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Go right.

outcomes.narrative: There are reasons for adventure, and those exist at your destination. No need to stray unnecessarily.

narrative:
An old man sits by the side of the road. "I suppose you're here to kill me, then?" You make clear you have no idea who he is, and he nods solemnly.

"I met an Aesther once. She told me she could see the infinite. So I asked her to tell me my future... dumbest mistake I ever made." He starts unbuttoning his coat. "She said she could tell me just two things: first, that a group looking just like you would kill me on this day, on this road. And second, that if I ever spoke to my son again, even a single word in a letter, he'd die the very next day."

"I left right then. Fifty years I didn't talk to the boy I loved. He passed just last year, natural causes. Lived a good life, but I couldn't tell him why his dad left. Couldn't tell him I loved him one last time." There's a catch in the old man's throat. "So either I lived a life of needless sorrow, or you're going to kill me today and prove that witch right." He folds coat neatly on the ground beside him, ready for his destiny.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Kill the old man to prove the prophecy true.

outcomes.narrative: You deal a swift, mortal wound. As he expires, a weak smile dresses his face, and he whispers, "she was telling the truth. I saved him... Thank you..."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Spare his life, and crush his heart.

outcomes.narrative:
"No, you must do it! You must! I spent fifty years away from my son! My boy! If you don't finish this, it was all for nothing!" He breaks down sobbing, begging you to meet his request.

You turn away from the troubled man and continue on your way. His choices were certainly unfortunate, but ultimately not your concern.

narrative: You've taken a "shortcut" through the sewers to get outside the city wall, but a wrong turn leaves you lost. The only way forward is through a wall of pipes. You pry one off, but a burst of water pressure knocks you to the ground and seals the door. The water is rapidly rising! There's no time to talk. In order to escape, you need to select the correct valve to turn off the flow, and you need to do it fast.

options.narrative: Set this card on the table. Players may no longer communicate in any way. Once you have selected which valve to close, raise your hand. When all players' hands are raised, each player simultaneously says their chosen valve's letter aloud. Then, flip this card.

outcomes.narrative: You each reach out simultaneously to grip the valve's handle, wrenching it in unison. It seals with a groan, and with the water stopped, you're able to pry open the hatch and make your way back to the surface.

There's no time to think, but it turns out there is a way to make the situation worse: the lever you selected increases the rapid flow of water into the room. You're soaked and exhausted by the time you're able to pry the rusted hatch open.

narrative:
A well-manicured patch of grass surrounds the imposing trunk of a massive amberhollow tree. Its fruits are delicious but fragile—the brittle shell implodes with a satisfying pop to reveal sweet liquid at the center. They last just a few days after picking.

A skeleton is resting peacefully under the shade of the tree's wide leaves. The left side of its face is caved in, although you can't tell if it was before or after death. Curiously, someone has dressed it in a pair of overalls as though it were a macabre scarecrow. A bucket sits in the skeleton's lap, a few gold coins at the bottom.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Pick some amberhollow for a snack.

outcomes.narrative: You're still climbing the trunk of the enormous tree when you feel the tug at your feet—the skeleton is clawing at you! It pulls you to the ground and while it's no match for you, it still fights with a terrifying intensity. You scatter the bones and continue to your destination.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pay for the privilege of picking some amberhollow.

outcomes.narrative: You drop five coins in the bucket and make your way up to the low branches of the tree where you find the most perfect specimen, packing it along with you. The skeleton pays you no mind.

options.label: C
options.narrative: Take the coins from the bucket.

outcomes.narrative: You reach in and pull out a handful of gold coins—you're not sure why someone left them here, but before you can pocket them, the skeleton in overalls leaps at you with a terrifying intensity. You beat it back and hurry to your destination, leaving the coins behind.

narrative:
A leisurely walk to your destination is interrupted when you stumble over a tree root sticking up from the forest floor. Upon closer inspection, you find that it is, in reality, a leg. A leg that is attached to a rather dead Savvas, half-buried under a bed of fallen leaves.

You exhume the body with a nearby stick—it's a finely dressed Savvas with the bronze insignia of the Merchant's Guild on its lapel. This looks to be a high-ranking guild member who met a very unfortunate end at the hands of a wild animal.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Gather the valuables and bury the body.

outcomes.narrative: You strip the finery off the Savvas corpse, taking special care to keep the lapel pin identifying it as a member of the Merchant's Guild. The sun is setting by the time you've finished burying the corpse in a better grave, but you should be able to sell the belongings for a high price when you return to town.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Carry the body with you on your adventure, then return it intact to the Merchant's Guild.

outcomes.narrative:
You wrap the body in a blanket and cinch it tight with rope, throwing it over your shoulder. It's as heavy as a corpse made of rock, but you think you can manage. How hard could it be?

For the next scenario, select one character to carry the body. That character adds three %game.attackmodifier.minus1% cards to their attack modifier deck for the scenario.

effects.condition: If you successfully complete the scenario
effects: Read %game.section:127.2%
Read %game.section:78.5%

narrative:
A discarded town guard tunic and belt on the side of the road catch your attention as you pass. You look around and see a guardsman squatting in the bushes a small distance away.

"Oh, hello!" he says. "Good timing, actually. You wouldn't mind grabbing me some leaves, would you? There's quite a mess over here."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Bring the man some leaves.

outcomes.narrative: You gather a handful of leaves and walk over to him. You lock eyes with the man throughout the encounter. It makes it significantly more awkward for everyone.

You gather a handful of leaves and walk over to him. If you weren't quite sure what was going on before, the smell definitely confirms it.

"Thanks a lot!" He says cheerily. "Sometimes nature calls, am I right?"

You cough in affirmation and quickly move on.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Grab his stuff and run off while he's indisposed.

outcomes.narrative:
You look from the squatting man down to his guard clothes. Surely he has something of value, but even if not—humiliating a guard can be its own reward. You quickly grab it and run off down the road.

"Hey!" The man yells at you. "What are you doing? That's city property!"

You don't look back.

narrative:
POP!

With a laugh, you watch the red-mohawked leader of the Four Crosses, a rival mercenary group, throw a ripe amberhollow fruit into the air, where his companion bats it with the blunt side of his sword. It results in a loud bang of sugary liquid and laughter from his coarse companions. They're systematically pillaging the contents of a wagon.

A farmer and his wife plead with them amidst the laughter. "Surely you needn't destroy them needlessly, they're fragile—have pity!"

The leader chuckles as he hops into the wagon and starts stomping the fruits underfoot. "Hey, you said we could have half your harvest if we protected you on the journey to White Oak. We'll use our half as we please!" The rest of the Four Crosses erupt in gruff chortles.

options.label: A
options.narrative: The Four Crosses give mercenaries a bad name. Stand up to them.

outcomes.narrative:
You drag their leader off the wagon and with a swift motion, unhitch the cart door to bury him in amberhollow. It takes just a swift kick and the fragile fruit ruptures in a loud detonation—the chain reaction leaves him drenched in sweet liquid. He looks like he's about to say something, then shifts his stance and walks off without a word, his stunned goons following quickly behind.

The farmer's wife stifles a laugh of her own, and they gift you a thank-you before leaving with the remainder of their harvest.
You try to stand up to the Four Crosses, but the conversation quickly turns to mimicry and mockery. You refuse to meet them on their level and head off to your destination.

options.label: B
options.narrative: It's the Four Crosses' fruit, per the deal. Side with the mercenaries.

outcomes.narrative: You remind the farmers that the Four Crosses are the rightful owners of half the wagon's bounty, leaving them to silently seethe. The mohawked brawler grunts. "You dumb idiots aren't so bad. Have one on us."

narrative:
You are feeling a tad hungry as you walk down the road. You are considering stopping for a meal when you come across a thicket of bushes covered in green berries.

The berries look delicious, but you hesitate. They could be poisonous.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Eat the berries.

outcomes.narrative:
You pluck a few green berries off the branches to stuff in your mouth. They are incredibly sweet and just the right amount of tart.

An Orchid farmer plods by on the road beside you leading a kivak carrying baskets of the green berries. "Enjoying the harvest?" He gives a stiff pat to the rocky skin on the side of the kivak, sending it off into the berries to find lunch. "Tin-berries only ripen once every three years. The red ones are darned poisonous until they turn that pretty green, but once they do... OOH-wee! Best roadside snack you can find outside of an amberhollow tree."

He plucks a few choice clusters and stows them in a pouch. "Enjoy it while you can, these bushes'll die off once they've been picked clean. It'll be ages before we see them again."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Pass by the berries and just eat your normal rations.

outcomes.narrative: Not wanting to regret making a stupid decision, you refrain from eating the berries and continue on down the road. A moment later you squeeze past an Orchid farmer walking a kivak down the narrow path. He tips his hat in passing. "Make sure you try the green tin-berries while you can!"

narrative:
"Lantern Beetles, that's what I call them, on account of I put them in these little lanterns. Handheld, lots of uses, really." You're chatting with an Orchid farmer as you pass by the buzzing boxes he's tending. "They've got a connection to the ether that surrounds us like no other creature I've ever seen—they can feel it, live off it like it's food right to their tummies. You feed them that, it changes things.

"I've been farming them for going right on forty years now. There's always buyers. People who want to rid their home of dark energy love the Brilliant Beetles. I know a few folks who keep an Ignition Beetle in their kitchens to spark the stove, almost like a pet." He lights a candle inside one of the boxes and the beetles flock to it, brushing their mandibles against it as though they were drinking the smoke.

"Most sales probably go to the Harrowers, though—it's like a fancy drug to them. I mean, just look at these beauties. Is it any surprise they'd want to have one as a part of them?"

options.narrative: Flip this card.

outcomes.narrative: The party may lose 15 collective gold to check one box below and gain the corresponding item.

outcomes.condition: All six boxes have been checked

narrative:
It's late afternoon when the road you're following cuts through a thicket of tangled brambles. You recall putting in significant effort to clear this path some time ago, and while the vegetation is doing its best to retake the trail, it's a simple matter to avoid the worst of the thorns.

The trail you blazed up to the abandoned outpost remains clear, and a good night's rest with a real roof over your head could do you some good. Given the decent condition of the road, though, you could make good time to your destination by continuing on your way.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Make camp in the abandoned outpost for the night.

outcomes.narrative:
You follow the trail up to the abandoned outpost you discovered and settle in for an easy evening. There's still wood stocked in the shed, and the view out the windows demonstrates the beauty of the landscape around Gloomhaven. You don't know who owns this place, but routine maintenance goes a long way to making the surroundings more hospitable.

Before settling into bed, you rummage through the gardens and find some fresh amberhollow ripening on a tree.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Take advantage of the open trail and continue on your way.

outcomes.narrative:
You head down the bushwhacked path towards your destination. The work that you'd done in the past pays off today, and keeping the surroundings hospitable has likely helped many travelers on their way to Gloomhaven.

The rest of your trip is uneventful and you arrive ready for whatever is thrown at you.

narrative:
Out of the sky comes a heavy downdraft of warm air, followed by the ground-rattling landing of an elder drake. He spits out a concerned-looking Inox, who drips from the experience of riding in the winged creature's mouth.

"Hello mercenaries! I have been searching for you for hours. This Inox," the drake pushes the terrified man forward. "This Inox broke into my home and tore a scale right off my tail. Dreadful manners." The Inox begins to sob. "But he told me he was something of a smith, so I gave him the opportunity to make a gift for you. Go on, show them. GO!" The drake bellows, and the Inox jumps into action, presenting you with an impressive piece of chest armor fashioned from the lost scale.

The Inox whispers as he hands it off, trembling, "Please. Please help me!"

The drake continues, "Good, well, that's settled, then. Thank you, offensive Inox. Time for me to eat you, then all will be forgiven."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Let the drake eat the Inox.

outcomes.narrative:
You stand by as the drake takes a single, devastating bite. The top half of the Inox is cleanly removed, and the drake makes small talk as he finishes the remainder. When the conversation naturally reaches a close, he takes off with a wave of his wing.

"Come see me any time!"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Intercede on the Inox's behalf.

outcomes.narrative:
"You wish me to... spare him?" You explain that with such a generous gift, the Inox has already proven his value. The drake ponders this for a few tense moments. "Very well. I will forgive your transgression, and you will never again set foot in the Copperneck Mountains. Mercenaries, enjoy the armor—it is truly one of its kind." With that, the drake takes flight and is gone.

The Inox falls to his knees, wiping tears out of his eyes. "Thank you! Thank you! How can I ever repay you?"

It turns out the Inox really is an excellent smith, and he spends the next few hours sharpening and polishing your equipment.

narrative:
"It is you! I have heard the rumors that you forged the Dawnblade!" Blocking your way forward on the road is a joyous old woman. "When its existence was finally felt, we knew destiny had spoken, and it was time to fashion its legendary complement: the Duskbrand."

She unwraps a parcel, revealing a dark blade. Smoke seems to play across its surface, but it has a refined elegance. She hands it to you, tears in her eyes.

"My husband cast himself into the forge to get the flames hot enough—his life energy was the missing spirit needed to craft the Duskbrand, the mirror-match to the mythic Dawnblade. Finally, our family's centuries-old legacy can rest. To think, you slew the dagger-bearers, you caught the Immortal Brummix, you bested the Elder Riverwatcher, you tamed the storm in the mists. You are the chosen!" She falls to her knees, prostrating herself in front of you.

Wait, uh... you didn't do any of those things. You just grabbed a sword forged by your barmate Xain.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Graciously accept the sword.

outcomes.narrative: You awkwardly thank her for the sword, but steer clear of confirming her belief that you are a chosen... well, anything. She stands after a too-long period, wiping tears from her joyous eyes. "You will do great things! Thank you for your sacrifices. My husband's spirit will rest knowing his essence enabled your calling." She apologies for taking up so much of your precious time, leaving you with a sword of exceptional craftsmanship.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain that she's mistaking you for someone else.

outcomes.narrative:
With all of the reverence due to someone whose husband cast himself into a forge on the mistaken belief that you were somehow chosen to wield a blade you basically nabbed as compensation for clearing an elemental factory, you explain that you are not actually whatever chosen person she believes you to be. She cuts you off with a wave of her hand.

"The chosen demonstrates such humility! May the blade destroy your enemies, for there are many, and your trials impossible to fathom. You will do great things!"

narrative:
"Can it be true? The chosen are before us!" A group of incredulous ascetic Vermlings catch up to you on the road out of Gloomhaven. "We were told that you possessed both the mythic Dawnblade and its mirror-equal, the legendary Duskbrand. Is it true?"

Another Vermling, the fur of his head shaved in an intricate pattern, speaks up: "Tell us! Do you carry light and darkness in your scabbard?"

A particularly scrawny Vermling squeaks with excitement. "Show us, please!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Show off the Dawnblade and Duskbrand, as requested (requires the party have both 117 and 118).

outcomes.narrative:
You draw the twin swords and hold them out for inspection. The Vermlings' eyes widen at the sight, huge smiles playing across their faces.

"It is true! We are so sorry for the sacrifices you have made to acquire them, and the sacrifices yet to come for you. Bless you, truly. We won't interrupt your quest any further!" With that, they rush off.

You really need to find out where Xain got those blueprints.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Explain that you have them elsewhere, for safekeeping.

outcomes.narrative:
The Vermlings appear understanding, and nod with a borderline conspiratorial tone. "Yes, yes—we wouldn't want such powerful artifacts to fall into the wrong hands. That's wise of you." The whole exchange is quite awkward, and you can't help but feel that they're judging you, although they make no overt suggestion that's true. They cinch up their robes and, after some light conversation, proceed down a different trail. The one at the rear mutters something and you feel a sense of dread permeate the air.

You really need to find out where Xain got those blueprints.

narrative:
You find a familiar-looking Orchid on the road an hour outside of Gloomhaven. "Oh hey, friends, it's you!" Xain, a regular at the Sleeping Lion who always seems to wind up in trouble, has a bindle full of assorted possessions thrown over his shoulder. "Oh, the bag? I'm temporarily relocating, change of scenery. Going to a tiny outpost in the frozen north." Xain sees your faces.

"I hear it's all kinds of nice. Very cosmopolitan, they've got everything. Snow. Even mail, sometimes. And I hear some Algox are... uh, friendly?" He's not terribly convincing. "Anyway, migrating also comes with the bonus of avoiding a friend of mine, who I happen to owe a little bit of money."

Xain looks uncomfortable with what he's shared. "Whelp, best be off, no time to waste before the pass closes. It'd uh... probably be for the best if my little relocation didn't make it back to Bonecruncher, so let's just keep that between us, huh?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Demand payment for your silence.

outcomes.narrative: You speak in vague terms about your personal relationship with Bonecruncher, leaving Xain turning paler by the minute. He nervously shifts his weight when you mention just how simple it'd be to tip off his creditor. "Alright, alright, fine! Listen, I'm skipping town in part because I don't have money. But here, fine, take it. It's all I've got. I'm sure I'll be able to get rich quick up in Frosthaven anyway—people'll be tripping over themselves to invest in my ideas."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Ask where he got the blueprint for the Dawnblade that was forged.

outcomes.narrative:
You explain that, ever since you forged the Dawnblade with Sunny's help, you've been accosted by confused emissaries. He raises an eyebrow, taking it all in.

"The blueprints? I just bought them off an old Vermling. He said he'd nabbed it off some dead mercenaries. Nothing to it..." Xain's face brightens, an idea forming. "...unless it's really valuable to you, in which case, I feel obliged to mention the finder's fee you owe me." You give him a look and he shrinks a bit.

"What? I've got a long trip ahead of me. Everyone's got to eat. Except Savvas. And Aesthers. And uh, Orchids like me, I guess. But still, you get it." You begrudgingly hand him a couple coins just to end the conversation.

narrative:
You slow your pace through the wilderness as you suddenly realize the animals have fallen silent, and the area around you has turned strange: the ground crumbles like sand beneath your boots, and the leaves of the nearby trees have faded to gray.

You notice a stale wind whistling from somewhere nearby, and you follow the sound to a clearing that stops your breath with awe.

It's like a charcoal sketch. Everything is a perfect pallid gray, all the color drained from the area as the entire clearing gradually turns to ash. The only color you see comes from the interplanar rift floating in midair, which dances with chromatic energy as the colors of the wilderness drain slowly into its maw.

By now, you've learned to recognize elemental magic. Somehow, the elemental energy from this plane is flowing through that rift into another realm, sucking dry the elemental essence of the trees, the earth—even the wind itself. In fact, you realize the colors have begun to fade from your own gear as well.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Sate the rift's appetite with elemental energy of your own.

outcomes.condition: Each character has at least one card in their card pool with an elemental infusion
outcomes.narrative: You summon your own power to hold the hungry rift at bay. Sure enough, your spells spin lazily around the portal's rim, slowly draining into its center. That should hold it for a while.
This place is lost already, and a random stretch of wilderness isn't worth your time. You wade through the gathering ash as you head back to the road.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Enter the rift to investigate.

outcomes.narrative: You leap through the rift and find yourself in the palace of the Prime Demon Ka'athrash on the Elemental Plane of Power. Floating before you in a chamber of pure white stone is the source of the trouble: an obsidian amulet in the shape of a bird's skull. The elemental streams flow endlessly into it, but it craves ever more. You can feel it pulling at your own energy too, offering a trade: your essence for its power. You take it with you... you're sure the Prime Demon won't miss it.

narrative:
Barreling down the road comes a red-trimmed wagon drawn by a pack of shambling skeletons. Two glum-looking Inox march behind it, keeping an eye out for any threats. As soon as you're within yelling distance, you hear the dramatic cry of "Halt!"

Out from the wagon steps the elegant Jekserah. "Mercenaries," she smiles a greeting. "What ideal timing. You two," she points at the Inox, "stop that! You don't need to water the skeletons! Just keep them leashed." On edge, Jekserah walks a bit down the road with you out of earshot of her twin Inox bodyguards.

"I have an army of skeletons, and somehow those two are the boneheads. And lately, I've found them quite... spineless. Questioning, almost threatening. Let alone the cost," she laughs with a flourish, as though this is relatable. "In any case, it's fortuitous to see you. Walk them off into the woods and make sure they don't come back... or better yet, just bring back the bodies." She sighs, looking at them from a distance. "They do have good bodies, after all."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to eliminate Jekserah's bodyguards.

outcomes.narrative:
"It's settled, then. You two!" She calls over her two hulking guards. "Guard these mercenaries with your lives. They're doing something very important today for the Merchant's Guild, and you'll see it through to your end." She starts heading back to her skeleton-drawn wagon, tail swishing behind her.

You lead them a short distance into the forest and spring the attack. The duo return blow after blow, but after a few frantic minutes, you're dragging their bodies back to Jekserah.

She passes over a red leather sack of gold. "I do appreciate your loyalty."

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse to get involved.

outcomes.narrative:
You're mercenaries, not hitmen. You turn down the Valrath, who doesn't take kindly to being told no.

"Well... I do appreciate your loyalty."

narrative:
The sun has just set, and the rosy patterns in the sky are giving you a few dwindling minutes of light before you need to set camp for the night. An inviting clearing just ahead sets your mind at ease, and the small stream nearby provides a calm, quiet burbling. It's really the perfect spot to settle in until morning... perhaps a little too perfect.

You see the shadow cast by a figure a fraction of a second too late. Salt, drawn in meticulous lines across the mossy ground, forms a perfect summoning sigil. With a wave of the caster's arm, the inscription alights, completing the planar request and binding you within the area.

"Mercenaries! You have crossed the demons! Such action is punishable by death!" A melodramatic voice rings out, followed by a cackle. "Let your final moments be borne of the chaos that consumes you!"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Explain that you've changed, and you mean the demons no harm.

outcomes.narrative:
The summoning sigil manifests a dozen terrifying demons. The caster calls to them in a guttural tongue, and, while you don't see the demons respond in any discernible way, he seems satisfied.

"They confirm your claims. You are free to go." The demons recede into the sigil, and the barrier drops. You still elect to choose a new place to camp.

"We have borne witness to your transgressions. Now you will suffer our wrath!" The fight drives you to the brink of exhaustion, mentally pleading for the pain to end. You finally drive your weapon into the last of the demons—the caster is conveniently nowhere to be found.

options.label: B
options.narrative: No use wasting words, it's time to cut these monsters down.

outcomes.narrative: The fight starts in an instant, but lasts several minutes of grueling, life-threatening combat. By the end, you've nearly exhausted the tricks up your sleeve. Thankfully, your final adversary is as weakened as you are, and with a bit of coordination, you manage to end it. The sigil burns away and the barrier drops, but the caster is conveniently nowhere to be found. Crossing the demons may be hazardous to your health.

narrative:
The mossy trail reveals clusters of bugs at regular intervals, spread out across the forest floor. They instinctively shy away as you approach, but among their numbers, you spot a few of the peculiar bugs that are so common within the Plagueherald.

A Harrower can unwind the humanoid figure it typically presents as, stretching over a wide area. Its consciousness is likewise diluted, though, and approaching one in that state can be startling or rude. It looks like there's far too many bugs to be a Harrower, though...

options.label: A
options.narrative: Call out to the bugs.

outcomes.narrative:
You address the sea of insects. Slowly, arduously, the army of tiny dots accumulate.

A black ocean of chitin swells at your command. With a thought, you order their assistance, and they flood over you and your companions, bestowing the gift of Xorn.
effects: Each character adds %game.condition.poison% to all of their attacks performed during the first round of the next scenario

outcomes.narrative: A wave of sticky black legs tear at you. You rush through to the other side, slapping at your body and hoping the pain subsides.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Quietly walk through the thicket without alarming the insects.

outcomes.narrative: You quietly make your way through the forest, crushing a minimal number underfoot.
To your horror, the army of tiny dots swells into mounds of undulating limbs. They extend their appendages at you as you rush through, trying to hold your mouth shut lest they climb inside.

narrative:
The road winds through a grove of trees, its saplings stretching skyward as the old growth gives much-needed comfort from the heavy sun. A lumberjack slams his axe deep into the bark of an elkwood tree, the sound ringing through the valley. A small log cabin is nearing completion, the roof partially erected. The Orchid takes a swig of water from a canteen as he watches you approach. He sums you up and rolls his eyes, chuckling.

"Mercenaries, right? I can't believe someone would pay to have you sorry saps do their bidding." He hefts his axe confidently. "You wouldn't last a day out here if you actually had to work for a living. Go on, scurry off to whatever implausible scenario commands your attention today." He drops his voice, imitating the way you'd speak to a baby. "I'm sure it's very important."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Insult the Orchid back.

outcomes.narrative: You expertly comment at length about how he's trying to compensate with his physique, but you both know it isn't even that impressive. The Orchid sits on a stump, staring at the ground quietly until you depart.
This Orchid is well-trained in being a jerk. He interrupts and peppers you with insults until you leave.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Challenge him to a logging competition

outcomes.narrative: You lay into the trees with force borne of anger, and before long, you've cut down a sloppy pile of wood. Comparing it to the Orchid's, it's clear he's more skilled, but you win. "Hmph, not bad, for city-folk."
After ten minutes of effort, you finally concede defeat to the lumberjack, panting and exhausted. "Not so easy, is it? Weak."

options.label: C
options.narrative: Murder the Orchid and burn down his cabin.

outcomes.narrative: His chuckling ceases with a slow gurgle, your weapon piercing through his torso. You take a small delight in setting the cabin ablaze. It may not have been kind, but it was certainly deserved. One less antagonist in the world.

narrative:
The shimmering, crystalline hand of an Orchid grabs at your ankle, rooting you in place. But this is no Orchid—it's "Crystal Rot," the discarded corpse of an Orchid given new life through nearby necrotic energy. The patchwork of dead grass and skeletal remains of forest fauna nearby suggest this one is still in the process of forming, feeding off the death in the area.

Given it's not yet a threat, you dig it up for a better look. Sure enough, the façade is that of an Orchid: crystals dance in fractal patterns across its skin. But in the gashes between flesh, you can see the thick black ichor that has taken up residence, recoiling from the sunlight.

Hollowed-out eyes shift and come to rest on you, expressionless. Its mouth lilts open, testing the jaw of its deceased Orchid puppet.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Kill the monster before it finishes forming itself.

outcomes.narrative: A few sharp blows are all it takes to shatter the crystals encasing the rot, exposing the interior to cleansing sunlight. It writhes and burns away what's left, leaving nothing but dense black soot and a foul odor. You pile what's left of the dead Orchid into a funeral pyre and make sure it's burned away before leaving. It takes most of the afternoon, but the effort will hopefully prevent some other travelers from an untimely fate.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Attempt to pacify the monster's anger.

outcomes.narrative: You take the refined memory crystal you received from an Orchid in the Sleeping Lion and press it deep into the black ichor swirling inside the dead Orchid's head. Within seconds, the half-formed Crystal Rot starts to violently convulse, frustrated at the peaceful images forced into its angry mind. You watch as the serene memory refracts outward, cauterizing the liquid darkness in piercing shards of light. Its neck droops, and the figure collapses to the ground, finally at peace. You burn the corpse per Orchid tradition, and a calm washes over the landscape.

You try to calm the feeding beast, but it seems riled by your presence—almost as if it can sense the lives you've taken hanging as an aura around you. It moves subtly, slowly, and then launches an attack with surprising force. You beat it to the ground and destroy the remains.

narrative:
There were certainly heavy rains last night, but you didn't realize the full extent until you came face-to-face with a river raging right through the middle of the road.

This river is no small matter, either—even a talented jump would barely clear the water. There is no practical way around, and judging by the drizzle that began falling minutes ago, it looks like even more rain is on the way.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Attempt to cross the river.

outcomes.narrative: You take steady steps though the raging river, walking along the bottom until you reach the other side unharmed.
You are water-logged and still shivering from the icy river when you reach your destination.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Attempt to build a bridge across.

outcomes.narrative: With the power of the elements on your side, crossing the river turns out to be incredibly easy. One frozen bridge later, you are on the other side.

It takes rocks, downed tree limbs, and all the twine from your satchel to make up the rickety bridge, but it holds long enough for you to make it safely across. You arrive at your destination tired but mostly dry.
You assemble the best impromptu bridge you've ever built. Judging by the midway plunge into the icy river, though, it will also be the last.
effects: Each character starts the next scenario adding two %game.attackmodifier.minus1% cards into their attack modifier deck.

narrative:
Your route takes you across a number of small streams, each of which are simple enough to ford. The one ahead of you presents a unique issue, though: whereas all of the tributaries you've crossed flow as you would expect, this larger one, paradoxically, is winding its way straight up the gentle hillside, totally unfettered by gravity.

It's worth the detour if only to appease your curiosity. You follow it up to find the stream is filling a serene pool with crisp, cool water. The edges of basin are meticulously chiseled rock, and peering in past the ripples... wait, is that a Lurker down there? No... it's a person! You can see them resting at the bottom of the pool, motionless in a state of repose.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Try to get the body out of the water.

outcomes.narrative: The pressure and inability to breathe would be unbearable if those were concerns for someone like you. At the bottom, you find what looks to be a meditating Savvas. You hitch your arms under and drag it to the surface.
effects: Read %game.section:6.3%

outcomes.narrative: The pressure and inability to breathe would be unbearable if those were concerns for someone like you. At the bottom, you find what looks to be a meditating Savvas. You hitch your arms under and drag it to the surface.
effects: Read %game.section:6.3%

outcomes.narrative: With nothing but a loop of rope from your pack and a nearby rock, you manage to fashion an improvised fishing rod. After a few attempts, you manage to catch the end of the rope under the figure at the bottom of the pool and haul in what looks to be a meditating Savvas.
effects: Read %game.section:6.3%

outcomes.narrative: Sure that it's too deep for you to swim down, you spend some time trying to fish out the figure with some rope (ineffective), and spear the figure out with a long stick (also ineffective). With the sun starting to set, you give up, vowing to return some other day.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Your curiosity is satisfied—it's time to move on.

outcomes.narrative: Sometimes figures hang out at the bottom of pools. Pools where the water flows the wrong direction. Big deal? There's enough oddities in this world that this one isn't worth your time.

narrative:
A splitting headache. Nausea.

You feel the crackling pulse of an energy rift looming behind you. You turn to face it, and sure enough, a ring of blue energy, large enough to step through, hangs impossibly in the air. You peer through and see a landscape not dissimilar to your own. Contemplating it could keep you busy for hours, but it feels familiar somehow, like a persistent dream.

No, not a dream—a challenge. Do you have the fortitude to step through into the unknown?

options.label: A
options.narrative: Enter the rift. (Each character starts the next scenario with Light 1. Flip this card.)

outcomes.narrative: Enter the rift.
effects: Flip a card (start over, and read event again)

options.label: B
options.narrative: Refuse the call.

outcomes.narrative: Refuse the call.

narrative:
The sound of wailing wakes you from an otherwise peaceful rest along the trail. You follow the sound to a pool of glowing water at the base of a willowburn tree. When you get to the water's edge, a ghostly, translucent woman appears, knee-deep in the swirling current, weeping into her hands. She doesn't acknowledge you, lost in her own thoughts.

You reach out to console her when someone slaps your hand away—an old man with a cane wards you back with a "Tisk tisk." The woman continues to sob.

He sits down on a log, speaking plainly and unconcerned if she overhears. "That's not a woman. Best not to touch it, she'll wrap you up in her darkness, and you'll fall to pieces. She's been in that pool for as long as I've been alive, weeping and pulling the unsuspecting close. I've stopped a good many, but she's nabbed her fair share."

He pulls out some fruit and continues between bites. "She'll be gone by morning. Shows up once a month or so. Good news is that when she's gone, the water will keep glowing for a few days, puts some pep in your step if you drink it."

options.label: A
options.narrative: Reach out to the woman.

outcomes.narrative: You recognize this illusion as an Aesther that has not yet managed to coalesce itself. Your own formation required fixation on a single, unifying ideal—she hasn't yet found her own anchor. You lend some of your focus, and a flicker of calm passes over her before she suddenly vanishes. You don't know if it's enough, but you hope you've shortened her trials.
You reach out to touch the glowing woman, but find yourself waking up with a pounding headache and covered in long claw marks an hour's walk from where you started. So much for helping.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Wait until morning and try the water.

outcomes.narrative:
You sit at the water's edge through the night and watch the woman flicker in and out of reality, reaching for levers that don't exist, frantically pawing at invisible walls, and finally breaking down crying. She repeats the pattern over and over, and you catch words here and there: "tower," "seeker," but if there is no logic to the order.

When the sun rises, the woman flickers a final time and vanishes. The old man gives it a solid ten seconds before he reaches into the pool and scoops up a cupful of glowing water, offering you some.

narrative:
Your travels between two distant hills take you past signage of an Inox clan claiming ownership of the valley. The warning permits peaceful passage, but claims dire punishment for any who would stay past dark. Unfortunately, it's already late in the day, and with no other option, you make camp and start a fire.

As you're about to enter your tent, echoes of voices waft over the hills, and the faint, low sound is chilling. It may be the wind, or it may be some inhuman force.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Quickly put out the fire and sneak out into the brush to get a look.

outcomes.narrative: Your stealth skills prove sufficient to remain unnoticed by a group of night demons. They pass by without incident.

You attempt to hide and stay quiet, but a snapped twig at an unfortunate moment startles the a group of night demons, who immediately fly into an attack. The scene turns bloody, and you're barely able to fight them off.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Wait by the fire for whatever comes.

outcomes.narrative: You can barely make them out against the pitch-black night, but in the firelight you see the silken, translucent forms of night demons approach. You wave them over to your campfire, but they seem content to stay at a respectful distance, watching the flames. When you next look up, they're gone.

You wait by the fireside for your visitors. The night takes on an uneasy, stomach-corrupting feeling, and after a too-long pause, the fire extinguishes itself in a snap of smoke. Before you can react, the night demons are upon you, tearing at you under the moonless night. You fend them off, but arrive at your destination the next day still licking your wounds.

narrative:
You encounter two Valraths with a small horse and cart on the side of the road. They seem uncomfortable at your approach, their hands instinctively going for their weapons.

You make a sign of peace and they relax a little.

"Perhaps it is good that you happen by, travelers," the younger one says. "Our horse is completely spent and we fare little better. We are in desperate need of some supplies to finish our journey."

The Valrath offers a sorry smile. "Do you think you could help us a bit?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Give the Valraths a portion of your supplies.

outcomes.narrative: You step forward, and with a bit of scrounging between your bags and the underbrush, you're able to put together a pretty decent sack of food and gear. The Valraths are grateful for the aid, and promise to sing your praises.
effects: Gain 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

outcomes.narrative: You'll need to replace the supplies next time you're in town, but you decide you can spare them. The Valraths breathe a sigh of relief, thanking you and promising to let people know what you did when they get into town.
effects: Gain 1 reputation with any one faction of your choice.

options.label: B
options.narrative: You spent good money on these supplies. Refuse to help.

outcomes.narrative: You apologize curtly and continue on your way. The Valraths seem disappointed and don't take the news well. You can hear them whispering things to each other as you walk away.
effects: Lose 1 reputation with your highest-reputation faction.

narrative:
You hear the labored moans of an animal slowly dying nearby. In the shade of a tall outcropping, you find a Quatryl farmer kneeling beside a kivak, a horned beast of burden, trying to console it as it passes. He sees you approach and wipes a tear away.

"This is my poor kivak. Best companion I could've ever had for darn near fifty years now. She stumbled and took a battering coming down this cliffside." He points at the deep gouge in the cliffside that traces where she fell. A pool of blood has started to form under the animal, and it's clear it's in pain. The farmer looks absolutely distraught, stroking the beast's head as he tries to comfort it.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Offer to put it out of its misery for the farmer.

outcomes.narrative: You give the farmer a moment to say goodbye, then lead him away and complete the deed. The farmer thanks you for your kindness, wiping away a tear.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Attempt to heal the beast.

outcomes.condition: Any character can perform a heal of value > 2 targeting an ally
outcomes.narrative:
You set to work on the kivak, patching the wounds. Slowly, slowly, the beast turns its head, then calms its breathing, finally coming to a shaky standing position. It licks at you, nuzzling its horn against your face. The farmer couldn't be happier at your assistance.

"Thank you! You have no idea what this means to me, thank you! I'll never let you stray again!"

You attempt to heal the beast, but it is too far gone from its fall. It flails as you try to comfort it, and in its demise, it lashes out at anyone nearby. You do what you can to give it a dignified end, soothing the pain as best you can. The farmer thanks you for your trouble, then asks to be left to mourn.

narrative:
You find a sobbing Quatryl sitting dejectedly by the side of the road. His attire is ostentatious—it would be extravagant even for the high-society galas of White Oak. He pulls a foppish hat off his head, blowing his nose dramatically into it as you approach. "Oh, sadness and woe! Hasten away, travelers, lest you learn the sorry tale of Basselhoff, the greatest bard in the world!

"Stifle your primal urge to secure my autograph, as I would be unable to command even a quill to fulfill your desire, so distraught is my current countenance! I have written a ballad so flawless even mine own consummate mind cannot comprehend the coda. Behold!"

"A life of woe befell my mate,

From hard-won wound to hard-lost gait,

A lass one day did end his strife..."

Basselhoff wilts, unable to finish. "I have... writer's block!" He curls into a ball at your feet, weeping. Offer him a final line to finish the song:

options.label: A
options.narrative: "A doctor who became his wife."

outcomes.narrative: "Yes, that's it! Matrimony is the perfect conclusion to a tale of tragedy. I can picture the knowing nods of the audience now!" He scurries back to Gloomhaven to perform the ballad immediately.

options.label: B
options.narrative: "A bandit with a hunting knife."

outcomes.narrative:
Basseloff runs his tongue along his teeth, thinking through the words. Finally, he gives a slow nod that turns more enthusiastic as it goes on.

"A tragedy must end in death, and your proposed—well, my inspired conclusion, really—drives home the random, senseless violence that can snuff the flame of life at any time. A fitting finish!" He rushes back to Gloomhaven to perform the song immediately.

options.label: C
options.narrative: "And then she died."

outcomes.narrative: Basseloff scrunches up his nose, processing your attempt at concluding his ballad. Slowly, curiously, an eyebrow raises, soon matched by the other—his face is the picture of surprise. "Yes! That's it! A break from troachic octameter is precisely what's needed to disarm my audience, to stun them into the muddled immobilization of the mind, this poisoned wound is the curse of my genius! You are made brilliant by virtue of my catalytic muse, and I thank you!" He hurries back to Gloomhaven to perform the masterpiece immediately.

narrative:
Pfhisss. Pf-Pff-Pffffhisss! Against the afternoon sun, you can barely make them out, but tiny, molten rocks are pelting the landscape around you. This meteorological anomaly increases in intensity—when trees begin to fall, you take cover under a rocky outcropping. A moment later, a merchant husband and wife take cover under the same outcropping, clothes singed and worse for wear.

"This is awful! Our whole camp is still out there!"

"Our kivak won't be able to survive, and I left him leashed to the tent! Is there any chance you could—"

"Oh, the tent! That was expensive! If you could help—"

"And dinner! We left our dinner on the campfire!"

"Actually, there's a couple other things, if you're already going out there—"

"—wait, where's our son?"

options.narrative: Choose which of the following requests you will retrieve for the couple, then flip this card. Each will require a separate trip: their child, their Kivak, their tent, their box of animal pelts, their trunk of personal effects, their dinner and accompanying serving set, and a lovely Orchid-woven rug they had spread under the campsite.

effects: Gain 5 collective gold for each item you retrieved.
Treat the negative effects below as if you retrieved 3 fewer items.

outcomes.narrative: "Thank you so much, truly. You could have been a bit quicker, of course, and that would certainly have an impact on the condition of these things," the merchant holds up the rug, which is pocked with numerous holes, "but we appreciate your help all the same."

narrative:
"Hello travelers!" You're a day's walk from Gloomhaven when you come upon a curious sight: a roadside stand stocked with nothing but acorns. The proprietor sees your confusion and she gives a polite smile.

"These are not just any acorns—they're the seeds of none other than Gloomhaven's Great Oak! Each is endowed with a bit of the grace that makes the Oak so powerful." She pulls out a tray of additional acorns that have a darkened, antique feel. "And if you want some exceptional potency, I can also offer acorns from White Oak's Great Oak—the original! There's nothing luckier you could carry with you."

Whether they work or not, this woman is clearly a true believer.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Purchase some Gloomhaven Great Oak acorns (requires 10 gold).

outcomes.narrative: You purchase a lucky acorn, tucking it into your pocket. There's probably nothing to it, but you can't help but feel that some force out there is looking out for you.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Purchase some White Oak Great Oak acorns (requires 15 gold).

outcomes.narrative: You purchase a lucky acorn, tucking it into your pocket. There's probably nothing to it, but you can't help but feel that some force out there is looking out for you.

options.label: C
options.narrative: You're not interested in carrying an acorn in your pocket.

outcomes.narrative: You pass by the stand without purchasing anything. She calls after you: "If you change your mind, be sure to stop back by!"

narrative:
Most travelers along the East Road keep to themselves, never certain whose day they might be disturbing. That common courtesy is left by the roadside for the numerous panhandlers and roving salespeople accosting anyone who might have some coin. You watch a Vermling tell off a party of well-dressed travelers within earshot ahead of you.

"You think fancy talk and fancy learning means you can walk over others, eh? Mother always said there's worse than being stupid." Kicking their wagon as they hustle on, the scraggly Vermling approaches you with her sack. "How about you? A potion for the big, strong adventurers!" she says as she waves you down. "Helps in battle, best quality."

You are about to push forward when she pulls the potion out of her sack. It glows silver in the daylight—an impressive, large flask of master craftsmanship. She pulls the wooden stopper and takes a small sip. The enchanted container sets immediately to work regenerating the removed liquid.

"Mother always said, 'Seeing is buying.' You want it?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to pay 15 gold for the potion.

outcomes.narrative: You hand over the coins, and she passes you the potion. "Mother always said the products pick the people. You're good people."
"Mother always said money makes friends. Let's be friends someday, eh?"

options.label: B
options.narrative: Haggle with the Vermling for the potion at a good price.

outcomes.narrative: "Fancy talk, fancy people! Mother always said the best off are always looking for the most off."
effects: Increase the amount lost by 5 gold.

outcomes.narrative: The Vermling will not accept the tiny sum you offer.

narrative:
"Hard times, hard times, that's all. Sometimes things're going up, sometimes things're going sideways. I'm in something of a lateral move at the moment, myself." The old man dusts himself off and looks up with a wink. "But you can never be poor if you've got secrets, right? Secrets always have value.

"Tell you what: you look like trustworthy folks. I'll tell you about a secret too far for my old legs to reach." He grunts and something gives a pop in his back. You can't tell if his face shows relief or pain, but he continues without acknowledging it. "You go gather it, and then you split the treasure with me, however you think's right. Couldn't be fairer, eh?"

options.label: A
options.narrative: Agree to quest for the old man, and split the loot when you've determined the difficulty.

outcomes.narrative:
The man directs you to the top of a nearby mountain. It's an arduous journey that puts you two days through thorn-filled paths to reach the crest, where you find a solid stone slab. Hours of back-breaking labor later, you've broken the stone and recovered a handsome chest full of gold and fist-sized rubies.

You make your way back down and the old man is waiting for you. "Told you it'd be worth the trouble! Now, let's see about my share."

outcomes.narrative:
"Alright, alright. An even split it is."

The man directs you to the top of a nearby mountain. It's an arduous journey that puts you two days through thorn-filled paths to reach the crest, where you find a solid stone slab. Hours of back-breaking labor later, you've broken the stone and recovered a handsome chest full of gold and fist-sized rubies.

You make your way back down and the old man is waiting for you. "Told you it'd be worth the trouble! Now let's see about my share."

narrative:
Words have power. Ever since you raised the Bladeswarm from the sands of time, you have had a heightened sense of the world around you. Each crawling entity, each fly buzzing by in the air: are they part of some secret network, waiting for the code to unlock them from their state? What else could be waiting for the latent command to spring to life?

A few hours outside Gloomhaven, you feel the instinctual pull of something. You stop, looking at the world around you. A beetle runs across your boot, and you know then and there that something is waiting for your call.

If "Bladeswarm" could summon a Harrower, perhaps other combinations of letters could do the same.

options.label: A
options.narrative: Make camp, meditate, and wait for a sign.

outcomes.narrative: You sit in the middle of the road, exhale a long breath, and wait for the world to point the way to your goals. Hours pass, and still you wait. Disturbing your patience, a dragonfly lands on your fingertip. Your eyes flutter open, and in that moment, you understand. The intention is right, but the place... the place is wrong. You pack your things and head off.

options.label: B
options.narrative: Spout random sounds in the ancient tongues.

outcomes.narrative:
Words have power, so lots of words very quickly should be exceptionally powerful. You babble incoherent phrases, casting them out of your mouth like arcane barbs. The bugs around you take no notice. You redouble your efforts. You can taste the power, and you will harness it for your own.

Hours later, the sun begins to set, and still you cry for strength. Then you spot them—a set of insects crawling out from under a rock. You don't know where their eyes are, but you can tell they are making eye contact with you. You. Are. Heard.

You scoop them up for a closer look, and they scuttle up your arm and into your ears. You feel fuzzy.

narrative:
An excited Quatryl flags you down as you approach a roadside stand. "Hello! I've invented the most highly advanced form of personal protection ever conceived—the negativity pump. I'm looking for field testers." An Inox carries out an unusual system of tubes and gizmos along with a yellow shield. Wait, is that—yes, it's your old friend the Bruiser working as a display model!

Before you can say hello, the Quatryl grabs the dagger. "It's demonstration time!" The Quatryl stabs it towards the yellow shield held by your old friend. It's a pitiful miss. The Quatryl stabs again and again, increasing in accuracy until his small frame manages to punch right through the shield! The Bruiser winces a bit, but then smiles an unconvincing smile.

The Quatryl looks pleased, then rushes off to get paperwork. The Bruiser takes the opportunity alone to level with you: "Listen, this thing is junk. Dangerous junk. But I get a commission for signups, uh, could you..."
